While my husband is fully supportive of my book habit , he rarely goes down the "you should read it " path when it comes to his books that he likes .
And I am rarely tempted to snatch one of the books off his " to read " pile and sneak it into my own .
In fact , with the exception of some classics from Tolkein and C. S. Lewis and a few others , we very rarely swap books .
I know him and his tastes ( and he mine ) well enough to know that he would n't insist that I read the book unless he really believed I would like it .
Got to hand it to the man .
Thirteen years of marriage have n't been lost on him .
He was right !
The Da Vinci Code starts off with a bang .
Jacques Sauniere , curator of the Louvre Museum , is trying desperately to escape his attacker .
Grabbing a painting off the wall , Sauniere trips the security gates , which close behind him .
Still , his attacker catches him anyway and shoots him through the gaps in the gate .
Sauniere knows that he is dying , and he knows that he alone holds an important secret that has been passed down through generations .
So in what he knows are his last minutes of life , he finds a way to leave clues to the secret for the one person that he knows can be trusted with it .
Agent Sophie Nevue , a cryptologist for the Paris police , is unconvinced of his guilt .
Together , they flee from the police interrogation and start to decipher the clues to discover why Sauniere was killed and to figure out Sauniere 's secret .
They are pursued by an overzealous police captain , the albino monk , a scheming bishop , and a mysterious man known only as " the Teacher " .
The chapters are short ( sometimes less than a page ) .
Author Dan Brown rarely deviates from the mystery .
There is no flowery dialog , and time is n't wasted trying to establish a hot relationship between the two lead characters .
Since the storyline covers a period of less than 24 hours , there really is n't much time for that romantic schlock .
But that 's OK .
It 's far more believable without it !
The Da Vinci Code is what my husband calls " a geek book " or , to be more exact , " a geek mystery . "
Rather than relying on conventional clues ( like footprints in the flowerbed , lipstick on the collar , and fingerprints on the wine glass ) , the mystery follows a trail of riddles and symbols .
Many of these riddles are based in history and are encrypted using a variety of techniques .
Mathematicians are sure to love this book !
I enjoyed it because many of the clues involved two of my favorite subjects : art history and theology .
The Catholic Church , which has enough public embarrassments to make it a viable topic for any mystery novel , and Opus Dei , which received much attention due to FBI spy Robert Hanssen , figure prominently into the plot .
The Da Vinci Code presents some alternative interpretations of religious history and involves paganism .
Ultra-conservative Christians ( or those who are n't secure in what they believe ) may want to steer clear of this one .
Since I finished The Da Vinci Code , I 've discovered that this is n't the first Dan Brown novel in which Robert Langdon has appeared , nor will it be the last .
Langdon first appeared in Angels and Demons ( 2001 ) , and Brown plans to write more books with Langdon in them .
Lucky for us geeks !
While I figured out some of the clues before the characters in the book did , I was still surprised and fascinated throughout the book .
Heck , take my husband 's !
Read it ! .
Although I purchased The Da Vinci Code by Dan Brown almost two months ago , I just got around to reading it last week .
I would have liked to have read it sooner , but unfortunately I had "prior commitments " ranging from work-related projects to Harry Potter .
I became interested in the book after reading the book flap which made the plot seem like it was about the exploits of this secret club made up of the intellectual heavyweights from the last five hundred years .
While my initial assessment was not totally off , I was both surprised and pleased to find out what the book was actually about .
The plot centers around Robert Langdon , a professor of symbology at Harvard who is in Paris to deliver a lecture .
As the story begins , Langdon is summoned to the Louvre during the dead of night to see a rather peculiar sight .
One of the curators , Jacques Saunière , has been found murdered ; not only has he been found dead , but the manner in which he was found is also peculiar .
Immediately , Langdon must evaluate his role in the murder because it quickly becomes apparent that Saunière left behind clues to help Langdon .
Langdon is aided in his quest by Sophie Neveu , a young cryptologist who has an interesting connection to the case .
You might be wondering what this "quest " entails and you might be surprised to find that Langdon and Neveu are not out to find
Saunière 's murderer .
As it turns out , that is the least of their problems .
Instead , Langdon and Neveu must follow the clues that Saunière left before he died and embark on what can be best described as a scavenger hunt .
Their work is complicated by the fact that they have the police chasing them and they are racing against Saunière 's murderer , an albino monk named Silas , a member of Opus Dei ( which is a prelature of the Catholic Church ) who has been sent to recover the same thing that Saunière was trying to protect .
It seems that Saunière was a member of the Priory of Sion and it is up to Langdon and Neveu to find whatever it is the Priory is hiding before Silas does .
They will have to use their skills to follow the clues that have been left for them and look for help from the few they can trust in a crazy race against a mad monk .
If the plot sounds complicated , I can assure you that it is .
However , one must keep in mind that I just summarized a 450 page book in one paragraph .
The reader starts out not knowing anything and slowly , over the course of the book , more and more is revealed .
As the story progresses , it forks off into three distinct storylines .
The first follows the perspective Langdon and Neveu on their quest , the second follows Silas the albino monk and the third follows Bishop Aringarosa , an Opus Dei bishop who is traveling to the Vatican and seems to be giving Silas his orders .
I found it a little frustrating to have these three storylines - every time something good was about to happen with one storyline , the chapter would end and the perspective would switch .
This did n't make me like the story any less nor did I find it hard to follow - the frustration I felt stemmed from wanting to know what came next !
Although it seems that nothing makes sense , things slowly begin to come together .
In addition to providing a first-rate action-adventure/mystery , Brown also introduces a series of fascinating theories about everything from art to history to religion and how all three are related .
While I must point out that very few ( if any ) of these theories are original , their appearance in the book serves as really great plot twists and Brown has woven a fascinating story .
Of course , I would also like to pique your interest , so here goes : before the patriarchic religions appeared , goddess worship played a large role in religion but this dissipated over the years .
Or did it ?
What if the Priory of Sion was devoted to goddess worship and had control over the secret of the most powerful relic in the history of Christianity;and that 's just the beginning .
Frankly , the book flap does n't do the book justice .
If you are a fan of art history or history or conspiracy theories or fictional mysteries , then Dan Brown 's The Da Vinci Code is for you .
This book is very hard to put down but it is well worth reading .
You will not be disappointed .
You can bet your bottom dollar that that book is at the top of my reading pile .
I highly recommend The Da Vinci Code .

A teacher of mine recommended this book to me , saying that all her friends loved it and could n't put it down , so when it came time to do a critique in her class , I chose this book .
Unfortunately , Mr. Pears book was not all that it was cracked up to be .
The are too many problems that drag this book down , preventing it from being the masterpiece that many are claiming it to be .
If the plot had been more gripping , more intense , this would have worked perfectly .
Unfortunately , it was n't , and by the beginning of the third narrator , I did not feel like reader the remaining two parts .
Again , this could have been excellent , save the fact that 2 of the narrartors are so arrogant and full of themselves that it made it hard for me to want to keep reading it .
Finally there was all the historical detail .
Mr. Pears obviously spent a lot of time researching to make his book as accurate as possible , including his writing style .
I commend him for that , however the details he gives are so numerous that they begin to over shadow the plot .
If you like the history behind what each narrator does ( i .e . the development of science for Da Cola 's tale ) then you will enjoy it .
If you find any one of the subjects offered ( say cryptography ) then it will hinder your enjoyment immensly .
I did enjoy reading some of this book , namely Da Cola 's tale , and the final tale , but the two tales in the middle dragged too much for me to be able to really recommend this book .
It wo n't be any spoiler to the literate masses to say that this classic Gothic horror story revolves around young Doctor Victor Frankenstein and the monster that he brings to life .
This unnamed creature , the culmination of years of painstaking work by Frankenstein , turns murderous after experiencing cruelty and persecution in his every encounter with humankind .
I was fairly surprised to find that I did not at all enjoy reading this book .
In fact , I found it enormously repetitive and tedious .
Despite the brevity of the story , I still thought the story dragged on , as if the author had padded the story heavily without adding anything of substance .
I was also surprised to find that the story held absolutely no suspense for me , nor could I say that the story struck me in any way as " creepy . "
Adding insult to injury were the leaden dialog , a completely unsympathetic main character and the lack of credibility in the actions and thoughts of the characters .
Here 's an example of what I mean when I say the dialog is leaden .
The scene is one in which a household servant of the Frankensteins has wrongfully been accused of a murder committed by the monster .
The excerpt is typical of all the dialog in the novel :
" She is innocent , my Elizabeth , " said I , " and that shall be proved ; fear nothing , but let your spirits be cheered by the assurance of her acquittal . "
" How kind and generous you are ! every one else believes in her guilt , and that made me wretched , for I knew that it was impossible : and to see every one else prejudiced in so deadly a manner rendered me hopeless and despairing . "
She wept .
If she is , as you believe , innocent , rely on the justice of our laws , and the activity with which I shall prevent the slightest shadow of partiality . '
-Surely some of this turgid stuffiness can be attributed to the time period in which Shelley wrote .
But it strains credulity to suggest that intimate family members would really converse with each other in this way , no matter the era .
After endowing his creation with life , Victor Frankenstein flees his laboratory , loses track of the monster and then goes about his miserable life for two years , apparently uninterested in what has become of his life 's work .
Is this plausible ?
His role during this time consists principally of languishing in nervous fever-wracked states , absolving himself of all responsibility , wallowing all the while in self-indulgent , morbid melancholy and revulsion towards the work of his own hands .
He waffles and dithers and generally acts like an idiot for chapters on end .
None of this behavior endeared him to me .
In fact , the monster possesses qualities , at least at times , that are far more ennobling than any his creator ever displays .
The words "miserable " and "misery , " "gloom " and "anguish " appear on almost every page , sometimes in multiple paragraphs per page .
If Shelley was trying to get the message across about Victor 's wretched state , she might have had a little more faith in her readers ' ability to absorb that message the first , second , third or fourth times around .
The reader is asked to not only endure , but to care about and empathize with the neurotic thoughts and behavior of Victor Frankenstein for far too long .
Yet another implausible aspect of the story creeps into the narrative by way of the narrator .
Frankenstein is actually a story within a story within a story .
What that means is that Victor Frankenstein is relating his story to the captain of an exploratory vessel in the Arctic , who is in turn taking the tale down in lengthy letters to his sister .
And when Frankenstein recounts the story told to him by the monster , yet another layer is added to this tissue of boredom .
But I digress .
What I found implausible here is the highly favorable impression that Victor Frankenstein - at this point a dying wreck of a man - makes upon the sea captain .
In his letters , the captain speaks of Frankenstein 's nobility of soul and of how he grows to love the good doctor as a brother .
Knowing Frankenstein through his own words left me with an altogether different impression of the man and I fail to see how the captain could be so taken with his acquaintance .
It has been and can be argued that Frankenstein is largely a moral tale .
To reduce the moral philosophy of the tale to its essence , kind treatment makes people good ; cruel treatment , revulsion and rejection makes them wicked .
And the monster , though treated most cruelly by all he encounters , retains an innate moral compass and yearning towards goodness even as he continues his annihilation of Frankenstein 's friends and family .
Another theme that Shelley raises but does not satisfactorily treat is the idea that man 's desire to master nature and to understand the world in which we live is futile without the all-too-rare qualities of self-mastery and understanding of human desires and limitations .
Frankenstein 's fatal immaturity allowed his hubristic faith in his own abilities to overreach his wisdom and his compassion .
Had the young doctor had the wisdom to predict his own reaction to his creation or the compassion to treat it benevolently , Shelley suggests , the disaster could easily have been averted .
Yet this message is merely hinted at and not drawn out to any clear explication or moral .
It 's clear that Shelley meant to play upon the parallels and contrasts between the creator and the creature in her novel .
Each of them is made miserable by the existence of the other .
Both feel cut off from the world around them .
And they both say of their sufferings " I bore a hell within me . "
Yet their differences are great too , for where Victor pursues science and rationality in his studies , his reactions devolve into hysterics and passivity ; while the monster , who comes into existence with no learning and no one to instruct him , resorts to empirical analysis of the world and consistently acts vigorously on the basis of his analyses .
In these contrasts and similarities , we can detect Mary Shelley 's background as the daughter of a philosopher and the wife of a poet .
Unfortunately , this after-the-fact sort of literary parsing does n't make up for the anemic and long-winded text that Shelley left us .
This is the first time in my memory that I have read a classic piece of literature and found virtually nothing to commend it or repay my time and effort .
It surprises me that a book of such a reputation falls so far short in every way by which I am accustomed to judge fiction .
Sadly , I cannot recommend this book to anyone .
I suspect that the book continues to be read today largely on the strength of its popularity in the era of its publication
Murder , Mutants , Abuse , Torture , Doctors , Scientists , Secrets , Gun Shots , Betrayal , Sex , Love .... these are just some of what you 'll find in James Patterson 's book , When the Wind Blows .
General Information
It was published in 1998 by Little , Brown And Company .
The hard cover version that I read had a total of 416 pages and unlike the other two books I 've read by Patterson , I could actually find places where I could force myself to stop reading for the night .
I 've only recently started reading books he 's written and confess that I 'm already a huge fan .
ISBN : 0-316-69332-4
The Story
Frannie as she 's called by her friends , has had her share of heart break and loss .
Her husband David , a doctor at the local hospital was murdered less than 2 years earlier .
Frannie is a real softy which is what many of her clients and their owners loved about her .
So there she was , minding her own business when one day this gorgeous hunk of man walks in and rents her cabin [which is being the Inn Patient] .
His name is Kit Harrison and while she ca n't stand him and at the same time she ca n't help but like him - just a little .
It takes quite awhile for Frannie to find out but Kit is not who she thinks he is .
Then , Frannie 's good friends husband is killed .
After much crying and several drinks , Frannie drives back home to the Inn Patient where she not only works , but has lived ever since David 's death .
She stops the car .
Wait .
What is that ?
Oh my God !
It looks like a human girl .
A beautiful little human girl - no more than 12 years old .
She can fly !
Frannie tries to gain her composure and then resumes the drive home .
By the time she reaches the Inn Patient she 's convinced herself that she could n't have really seen a girl with wings .
It must have been the alcohol ...... right ?
Sorry , but if I give you more than that I just may ruin the book for you .
And in case you 're wondering all of this happens in the first few chapters of the book !
About the writing
Patterson captivates the reader from page one and if you think you 'll find a stopping place at the end of a chapter - think again !
It was n't easy but I did manage .
In the beginning of the book is an Author 's Note .
In this note , Patterson states that what he writes in When the Wind Blows is much closer to the truth than even he thought it would be .
Overall
If you 're looking for an exciting book of fiction and science and doctors interest you , I recommend you give When the Wind Blows a try .
There are some graphic parts which made me mad to read , but I do n't believe it would be too much for anyone to handle .
Thanks for reading ~
Melissa
I got this book , because it was a Grisham book that I had not read ( the only one besides The Chamber ) so far .
In a nut shell , a homeless bum gets into the conference room of an upper crust law firm in D.C. and holds several lawyers hostage for several hours .
While there , he tries to lay a guilt trip on the lawyers who all took home at least 6 figures last year , yet donated almost nothing to the poor .
Most of them were too afraid for their lives to feel guilty , except for Michael Brock .
When the ordeal is over , Michael 's career takes a turn .
He and his wife are at a difficult time in their marriage , with him spending as much as 18 hrs at the office , she fills her time by going to medical school , and becomes a doctor , now neither has the time for the other--and divorce is inevitable .
A fighter for the rights of those who society has cast off .
While doing the research for a law suit , he finds that his former firm has been more than loosely involved in illegal activity regarding the homeless .
He decides to take on the world ( not unlike in Rudy from the Rainmaker )
Over all , it appears that the deadline to get this year 's Grisham book came a bit quick for John , either that , or he was specifically looking for a movie contract for this story , either way , it was not his best work--but it still held my attention through the whole book

The real theme of the book is about love and trust .
There is your man meets woman , but the two people who are thrown together in many thrilling situations fight this attraction .
Later on they give into their feelings and open up to each other .
They find out they have been betrayed by friends , co-workers and even the government .

He is sent on a vacation because he is being overly interested in a case and wo n't go with the conventional ways of investigation .
In other words he is an agent who is obsessed with a case and wo n't give up .
But the real reason is that he is getting to close to discovering what the agency wants to keep a secret .
This is the gene altered children .
Frannie is the widow of David .
David 's death is one of the deaths in the case that Kit is investigating .
They get off to a rocky start but soon fall for each other even though they resist the feelings that they have for each other .
Fannie sees Max in the woods one night .
Max is one of the altered children .
She and her brother Matthew escaped the compound by flying over the fence .
Max has learned to not trust anyone especially adults who have done nothing but tell her lies all of her eleven years .
Kit and Fannie eventually make friends with Max .
This where the action starts .
Kit and Fannie find out where the children are kept and make a daring rescue and then run into other thrilling adventures .

This book has all that anyone could want .
It is action packed with murder and mystery .

Michael Crichton has written some really fun , engaging , and interesting stories .
He 's also written some really bad stories , and it is n't one of those either .
" Airframe " follows the usual Crichton pattern of a suspense story whose plot revolves around a piece of science , medicine , or technology .
We have the plucky heroine , an executive at the aircraft company determined to find the truth behind an accident .
We learn a bunch of stuff about the politics and engineering of airplanes , and eventually , we learn what happened on that ill-fated flight .
The only problem is , we do n't really care .
The trouble with " Airframe " is that the stakes are too small .
In " Airframe , " it 's an order for new planes .
In the most suspenseful moments of " Jurassic Park , " we wonder how the humans will escape the dinosaurs .
At the climax of " Airframe , " we wonder whether the TV reporter will escape being airsick .
( As Dave Barry would say , I am not making this up ! )

UPDATE : I am writing this update after owning my 2001 Ford Focus wagon only 4 1/2 months .
After taking my vehicle to the auto dealership to have them why when the windows go down (especially the rear ones ) an extremely loud painful vibration occurs .
When the service tech was in the car for a drive to understand the problems noted to him my husband rolled down the windows .
The tech described the sound discomfort to when his ear drum broke a few months back .
As you see the noise is painful ! !
The tech then called the engineering department at Ford to find out how to deal with the problem .
Ford is selling Focus wagons knowing there is a window problem .
I am now in the process of finding out how to handle this problem .
How discouraging to buy a brand new car be making payments ca n't even roll down my windows ! ! Beware when checking into purchasing this vehicle .
We are spending too much on gas for that van , I told my husband .
I knew I needed wanted something big enough to still haul stuff like lumber my kids bikes .
So , I knew I was n't getting another gas eating van it have to be some sort of station wagon .
Now , narrowed down to body type I went on my search of different makes models of station wagons .
My first priority was price .
Being a family of 5 money is tight I needed something affordable , but of good quality .
I checked the prices of the VW Jetta wagon the Saturn wagon .
Both were quite a bit more expensive !
The Ford Focus was by far the more affordable of the three .
Having access to a Ford A plan was another deciding factor .
Ford also at the time of my purchase was offering rebates interests rates of 500.00
cash back 6.9 % interest 1000.00 cash back 7.99 % interest .
We all know you get what you pay for , maybe thinking it is cheaper because it is in features .
The Focus Wagon has standard features such as ; power door locks , power windows , CD player , air conditioning ,and cruise control .
The ease of getting in out of the car was another factor in my purchase .
Unlike a lot of small cars the Focus Wagon seats sit higher .
I really like the crank under the seat to adjust the seating height .
I hate sitting in a car where my head almost touches the roof .
That is a problem in the Focus Wagon .
The storage space in the back is extremely roomy the pull over cover is an added plus .
I went shopping for 2 weeks of groceries for a family of 5 had problems getting all the bags in comfortably .
Space is definitely a problem .
The gas mileage is the most important feature of this vehicle .
With today 's gas prices going up this is a feature to be looking at when choosing a new car !
The engine in mine is a Zetec 4.25 L. It still has pep , but does n't need a lot of gas to achieve the goal .
I was on vacation in Florida in 2003 during that time I had the opportunity to rent the 2002 Ford Mustang Convertible .
I drove it for more than a week , so I that I was able to see the good the bad sides of driving this particular car .
Engine transmission .
The Mustang that I drove had 3.8 liter V-6 in it mated to a 4-speed automatic transmission .
The engine was adequately powerful did n't need to downshift a single time , matter what the road was .
It was a silky smooth engine too , with deep , low , satisfying engine note ; as a matter of fact I mistaken it for V-8 at first , but then out of curiosity I opened the hood , saw that it was a V-6 .
The engine sounded just like V-8.
The transmission that the engine is mated to is very smooth also , with barely noticeable shifts .
Even the kickdown was smooth .
that 's where good stuff ends .
Handling
The car handled like a van .
While the car has very good ride in the straight line , doing a very good job isolating driver from the road bumps , you need to make a turn ( I am talking about just a slight turn , something extreme ) , you better have your seatbelt fastened , you have a good chance of landing somewhere outside of the car .
Granted it is a convertible , so it is as stiff as a coupe , but still , it is a sports car afterall , so it at least drive like one .
Design Ergonomics
The car looks good from the outside .
It has nice curves but boy racer look , so it appeals to both older younger drivers .
The visibility from the driver's seat is very good .
The front seats are cramped for such a large car .
It is as long as many sedans , wider than most of them , but it is pretty cramped in the front , I am even mentioning the backseat which is suitable mostly for children .
I am 6 feet tall weigh 200 pounds , which is pretty average .
Whoever was in charge of ergonomics 've been fired limited to designing floormats for Yugos .
It took me a while to find it the first time when I was trying to get out of the car at night .
There is trunk release lever inside the car , so you need to get out of the car , use the key button on remote control .
On the fifth day of driving the car , I finally found the controls for moving the driver seat , they were located in the front of the seat ( power seat in this case ) , on the left right edge of the front side of the seat , but right behind driver's legs .
When you try to open close the top , you have to use the two levers , one on each side of the windshield , which be troublesome for a single person .
In Ford Thunderbird , they finally replaced them with single central lever , which is foolproof easy to use .
For example : you use air conditioning , you direct the airflow to the desired spot , because there is separate button for A/C.
Rather there is separate position for A/C on the same knob that is used to direct the airflow , so the knob is in A/C position , it be in defog position .
I use the A/C for longer than 40 minutes , since I was wearing flip flops ( Florida ) was risking of freezing my toes off .
In the end , I recommend this car to anybody , as after short period of time , the feeling of rip-off will set in , as you start thinking about how much money Ford saved by giving the Mustang interior design job to a group of 5 Detroit bums .
Ford Mustang 2002 convertible .
A few years ago Ford redesigned the Mustang gave it back some its mid 1960 classic look , I really understood Ford 's decision to drop the so popular style of the 60 's Mustang .
I always that Chevrolet keep the sleek racing style of the Corvette than why Ford have done the same only for the Mustang .
you notice Ford had also done the for the fantastic T-Bird that lost all its classic styling in the early 70s .
The Mustang convertible 2002 does have the look body that tends to make cars become a classic .
Who knows it will ever be as popular as the original Mustang but it really does matter because this automobile is a fun sport car to drive .
Looking at the interior of the Ford Mustang with the top is down is impressive .
I like the beauty of the interior how all the gages controls to be so compact easy to read reach .
The car I drove was equipped with leather trim Sport bucket seats , they are optional for the Mustang 2002 but they certainly make that interior look very special .
Once behind the steering wheel , I did a bit cramped in , but after a few minutes I got use to it .
The armrest on the front console was at the right level resting my arm on it brought my hands at the right place on the steering felt good to hold it .
The sound system is well located on the front console is fairly easy to understand operate .
I did that the sound was as good as it be but I guess who cares when the top is down you are going for a early evening summer drive down a scenic country road .
The hood side panels have air scoops the trunk has a rear spoiler that will give this vehicle a real sport car design .
I was too impressed with the 17 inches aluminum wheels ; to me it that wires wheels look so much better with this car .
This is something to consider to change in the after market for new Mustang owners .
I be a bit younger I certainly consider buying one for myself .
The car handle very well on the highway , you have the feeling that it hugged the road very well .
As for city driving this car is a dream , it is to big to be a pain to drive around the city at the same time it is big enough to be noticed .
The Ford Mustang convertible I drove was had a V8 4.6 litter SOHC 16 valves engine , developing 260 horsepower .
The transmission was a 4-speed electronic overdrive transmission .
It also was equipped with 4-wheel disc brakes with ABS
As for the Mustangs of the mid-60 's after sitting a while in this car you will start to less comfortable but that put aside this is a fun car to own drive , I that the price is right anyone who buys a 2002 Ford Mustang have years of pleasure driving it .
The 2002 Acura 3.2TL is an excellent value .
The only option is a DVD-based navigation system that holds the entire US map on one DVD disc .
The features that are optional on other cars in this segment are standard here .
Value
The list of standard equipment is very long .
ABS , traction control , automatic transmission with manual shifting capability , automatic climate control , leather simulated wood trim , keyless entry , security system with panic alarm , Bose stereo system with both CD cassette , heated power front seats , cruise control , power locks , windows mirrors , steering wheel mounted radio controls , high intensity headlights , cruise control , sunroof , alloy wheels , front side airbags .
I did include other small goodies like grid antenna leather gear shift knob steering wheel , etc .
The engine is 3.2 liter V-6 with Honda's VTEC variable valve timing lift technology that uses two-lobe camshafts switches between lobes depending on the engine RPMs to increase torque power .
This V-6 produces 225 hp 216 lb-ft of torque .
There is a new TL Type-S model that gets 260 hp , has 17 " 5-spoke wheels stiffer suspension .
Transmission
The car is available with manual transmission , but you shift the standard 5-speed automatic manually you wish .
Unfortunately , automatic transmission , even with manual shifting , is substitute for manual gearbox , the torque converter "eats " some power plus you still have less control .
Mash the pedal it downshifts .
What 's the point of having manual control then ?
Styling
Some people like it , but I prefer something more distinctive .
Although the exterior was improved recently , the rear is still bland .
Interior is nice , however , the steering wheel that looks too bulky the wood that looks too fake .
The fit finish are very good materials look fine for the price .
The instrumentation cluster is excellently lighted at night the HID headlights provide enough illumination .
The car employs a floor-mounted parking brake , which I don't like .
It's A Front Drive Thing
The TL is a front-driver , which makes it better suited for slippery conditions .
The torque steer is virtually nonexistent .
The acceleration is quite fast , however the automatic transmission "eats " some power .
In fact , BMW Audi manage to go faster with less power .
It be due to the gearing weight .
Safety Pricing
you go to crashtest.com ,
you will see that TL was rated worse than it 's German competition , Audi A4 , BMW 3 Series Benz C-class .
However , they are substantially more expensive in their higher trims ( A4 3.0, 330 C320 ) with the same equipment as TL.
The Lexus IS300 is TL's closest competitor , yet IS300 is better suited for younger people who want a sporty car .
IS300 is a rear-wheel drive I it lookos better .
The TL is a car for those who want good value , reliability comfort .
Bottom Line
Overall , the TL is a good value with lots of standard equipment smooth engine .
But styling the crash protection be better .

The Mercedes C320 ( a disappointment , terrible ride ) Volvo T6 ( very nice car , but still too skittish for a Swedish make )
Audi S4 ( awesome car , but questionable reliability )
Three Lexus models ( RX300-did n't want SUV, IS-300 , cool car but leather option did n't want RWD , the GS300 , which is a really nice car , but glove compartment-mounted CD player ruled it out )
Toyota Camry , a disappointment , like to see a sports version ( I 'm glad to see they finally updated it , it was overdue )
BMW 330xi was nice but way too cramped questionable reliaiblity .
Mazda Millenia was also nice , but was key features had significant cost advantage
VW Passat , which I was very impressed with , but again questionable reliability .
Maxima 20th anniversary edition , an awesome car with the best V6 engine ever made , with a long history , but it had cost advantage over the Infiniti I30 , which was the car that gave the TL a run for the money , but the TL won out with more powerful engine , higher resale lower insurance costs .
I took delivery in March , of one of the very first TL-S' available .
I 've seen 0-60 numbers in the 6.2-6.3 second range , I have trouble believing it .
When I press the accelerator , the 260 horses are ready to run .
It 's great for evasive maneuvering , which I 've had to use twice .
Once was literally ten minutes after I picked up the car , when an adjacent car literally crashed into the car in front of him , while gawking at my new TL.
I swear this is a true story .
I almost had a heart attack .
Luckily , of the flying debris hit me .
As with most Japanese makes , the fit finish were almost flawless on delivery .
There is one small flaw in the paint , a bubble on the front fender , less than the size of a pinhead .
So far I 've found other flaws in the car .
The minor cosmetic differences in the '02 go a long way in improving the looks of the car , which many consider bland .
I chose the silver exterior , with dark ebony interior .
The fake wood for this exterior color option is black only , which looks better in my opinion than the tan with brown wood , which is obviously fake .
I know the black wood is also fake , but somehow I it 's better looking than the fake brown wood .
Another advantage to the TL is the flat pricing structure .
You get a lot of "bang for the buck " with the TL.
Just compare it to any of the cars I mentioned above you will find it 's extremely well equipped .

-3.2 liter aluminum alloy 24-valve SOHC V-6
-260 hp ( Type-S) , 225hp for the TL
-VTEC technology
-Programmed fuel injection
-Dual stage front air bags plus side airbags
-Automatic climate control system
-Heated front seats with 8-way power driver seat

-self-dimming rearview mirror ( the greatest invention ever )

( excellent for parallel parking )
-auto up/down driver 's side window , very handy
The engine is incredibly smooth shifts hesitation .
The seats are very comfortable there are two memory settings coded to the keyless entry fob you carry , which is a nice feature .
The car has excellent road manners I 've found it to be a smooth comfortable ride , despite the sports-tuned suspension .
The rear seats sit a little low , but there are rear air vents an armrest with two cupholders for passenger comfort .
The back seat has more legroom than you anticipate is actually quite comfortable .
The cabin is quiet road noise is minimized through lots of soundproofing .
The 6-disc in dash CD player is very convenient the 7-speaker Bose sound output is quite good , although I like to be able to crank it a little louder .
But keep in mind that I came down from a 12-speaker 240-watt Harmon Kardon system .
There are plenty of handy storage bins , including in the door , behind each seat , a double console cover , with a deep cover ( for kleenex CDs ) shallow cover ( for pens , etc. ) over a single storage compartment in the center console .
There is an additional power outlet in the center console .
The cup holders are excellent hold a variety of sizes , from a Coke to the largest fast-food cups .
I have yet found a cup size that wo n't fit in one of the two cup holders .
WARNING ! !
you buy this car , DO use the coin holder in front of the shifter for coins .
I know that is its intended purpose , but I had a coin that somehow slipped up behind the compartment , preventing it from closing , was about to have to take the entire console out to retrieve .
Only after a couple of hours of cramming wire hangers fingers up into the slot , was I able to get the loose coins out .
So whatever you do , do n't put any coins in the coin holder .
The one problem I have with the interior is the foot emergency brake .
I much rather have a hand emergency brake .
This be extremely frustrating until you get a for it .
The key fobs have excellent range , include a power release for the trunk deck .
2001-I just took the car to the dealer for a recall of the power window control unit ( which I have had any problems with ) .
They had it replaced in less than 30 minutes .
July 2001-I just rolled over 3,000 miles changed the engine oil myself .
The drain plug oil filter are the easiest I 've ever accessed on any car .
The engine layout logical all the necessary reservoirs tanks are clearly labeled .
I 've had mechanical difficulties of any kind .
I was given this car as a company vehicle when I first arrived in the US 2 months ago .
My first on seeing it was "what an ugly heap ! " .
Next nuisance item was the multifunction stalk for controlling lights , wipers etc . Really , these functions be seperated but the use of a column gear change prevents that .
These column mounted gear stalks are very quaint , but personally I see one again it will be too soon .
Performance was , well how I put this cussing , absolutely useless .
I do n't know its top speed as I felt sufficiently in control to test it .
Brakes are adequate being startling .
I did find that parking brake to be hopeless .
Handling .
Handling ?
Nope , on this thing !
This is the sort of softly suspended barge on wheels American cars used to be like .
This have been acceptable in 1975 , but things have moved on a long way since then .
My last 3 cars were 2 SAABs an Audi A4 so criticising the handling is a little unfair .

Review of my 2002 Nissan Altima SE 3.5 , black on black .
I brought this car new Feb 28 , 2002 with 256 miles on it .
I had originally wanted a Maxima to replace my 1998 SE model which was going off of lease had to be replaced .
But as it was near the end of the month , there was n't anyone among 4 different dealers who find a 2002 Maxima SE with the right combination of options color that I wanted in California Nevada .
OTOH , when you buy a Honda Acura , there are options color .
Everything is standard all the cars have the same "options " .
So I settled on an Altima .
I had tested this car back in October on an invite from Nissan was impressed with the power looks .
The car has every option offered for the xenon headlights .
-ABS
-4 speed auto transmission
-Bose Audio w/8 speakers integrated 6 CD changer
-Sunroof
-Wind Deflector
-Cold Package
-Traction Control
-Leather [very fake ] wood
-Floor mats
-Splash Guards
-In-car micro filter
-Side side-curtain air bags
-Wheel locks
Superficially , the car is fast handles reasonably well .
It 's very easy to hit 90 mph [grin] .
Outward view is OK but the roof pillars do get in the way during certain maneuvers during angle parking .
I focus on the good points of the car like so many others but that side of the story has been covered ad infinitum by the car magazines , newspaper supplements professional car reviewers , so I will focus on the shortcomings design flaws .
Why ?
Like the Chinese water torture , a few small things , over a period of time drive you crazy .
there are a lot of small things that taken together make for an annoying experience .
IMO , Nissan has cut a LOT of corners on the 2002 Altima .
This be acceptable to meet financial constraints in a 15-20k car , but is inexcusable in an approximately 30k ( list ) car .
the mistake that Nissan has made is to try to bring the car upscale too fast by offering the expensive 6 cylinder model .
In the 4 cylinder econo-car class , the Altima be a very acceptable package priced at say 19-22k max .
Were I in Nissan management , I have offered the 6-cylinder model leaving that to the Maxima line .
So remember , my comments below are directed strictly at the top of the line SE 3.5 model .
After living with this car for one month , I 've discovered a LOT of design deficiencies , poor design choices extensive corner cutting in materials .
You call me anal for the list below , but I contend that the designers have been even more so .
In this day of computer design with so many fine examples to copy from , is it unreasonable to that a 30k car be designed with considerable thought and ergonomic considerations ?
Many of the complaints below have easily been rectified at little ( even ) additional cost given proper forethought .
, it like they put the " B" design team on the Altima project with [hopefully ] the " A" guys sent to work on the new " Z " car .
-Interior design material quality is equivalent to a cheaper car , say one costing maybe 15k .
The interior is unrelenting stark .
of a nice smooth finish , look closely you see the undulations uneveness of the paint job .
Is it cheaper to do a poor paint job is the problem that the car was built in the USA ?
-Cheap looking flimsy plastic are used throughout the interior .
-There is mistaking the plastic wood highlights ( extra cost option ! )
for anything but cheap plastic .
-Open/close latches on console box are flimsy do n't release engage well .
-Map pockets on doors are thin flimsy .
Why make the arm rest top raise provide a pocket there for maps other storage ( which I I had on a Mazda Millenia 2 cars back ) .
-Overall , the plastic in the interior looks feels cheap .
-Many switches are in the wrong places .
-Heated seats switches are on the console behind the driver 's hands out of sight .
You have to look down back to see them buried by the center console box .
They also stay on when you shut the car off .
They shut off when you shut down the car there be an indicator on the instrument panel that they are on .
-With my arm on the armrest , my fingers are at the mirror control .
To get to the window controls , you have to slide your arm backward take your eyes off the road around for them .
The mirror control is rarely used once it is set be put in a less prominent place .
-Garage buttons ( home link ) be on the visor particularly on the left side of the visor .
They be in the roof center near the sunroof controls .
you have the visor down pull to your garage , you have to raise the visor to get access to the home link buttons .
-Sun visors are poorly designed .
When down , they do n't cover the full space between the mirror the windshield pillar , letting the sun in through the side .
-Sunroof functions ( back forward tilt ) are all controlled by one button .
There be two buttons .
-Lock for the rear seats fold down be somewhere near the driver (electronic ? )
of making us climb into the back seat to manually lock/unlock the seats .
-Light wiper stalks are short stubby , 1/2 " to 1" too short .
-With hands at the 9 and 3 positions , part of the view of the radio heater left side is obscured .
-Driver sill is too high too far away from the seat , making it uncomfortable to rest my left arm on while driving .
-Instrument lights are an ugly orange with one overly bright daylight setting which ca n't be adjusted .
They have copied the older Maxima white instruments of using these deep instruments .
Change simply for the sake of change is wrong .
-Fog lights only work when the headlights are one , which defeats the purpose of fog lights .
Fog tends to hover 12-18 inches above the ground .
But with the headlights also on , the light from them is scattered , making the fog lights useless .
-Granularity on speedometer tach are poor .
Speedometer to be inaccurate by plus 8-12 mph .
With the gauge on empty the little , tiny light on at the bottom of the gauge ( empty ) , the car has 2.5-3 gallons left .
-Can't lock the fuel door hood .
Someone inside the car always open the gas tank hood .
-Trip computer is highly inaccurate .
It 's always showing between 20.2-20.9
mpg but my spreadsheet ( based on gas fill up ) is showing 18.7 mpg .
The time to tank empty is also off .
-Lots of reflections in the front window , particularly on a sunny day .
-There is ashtray option for one .
I do n't smoke , but have friends who do .
What do you do they want to smoke on a long trip ?
Tell them to flip the butt out the window ?
Stop every hour so they smoke throw their butt on the side of the road anyway ?
Tell them to put it in their pocket ?
Hang a garbage bag ?
what you want to sell the car to someone who is a smoker ?
-There is a lot of tire noise .
-Tires are all-weather MandS tires , true performance tires .
they are hard ( 300 rating ) which means longer wear but poorer handling grip .
-Car has the Bose stereo with 6 CD slot-type radio .
-I do n't like these slot type 6 CD changers .
It 's annoying to sit there load unload all 6 CD 's .
As it stands now , you have to select the CD 's you want in your house .
You load them into a carrier to bring them to the car carry them to the car in their jewel cases .
Then you put the jewel cases in the glove box center console .
You ca n't put the carrier in the console box because it wo n't fit , so it has to go in the glove box .
Hopefully , you do n't have any gloves other stuff in there .
to me that it make more sense to have a CD cartridge like I 've had with the trunk mounted units previously .
You load one two of these up in the house so as to have to mess around with individual CD 's while sitting in the car .
Better yet , the cartridge fit into a slot in the dashboard on in the radio ( rather than the trunk ) .
Then when you leave your car with someone else ( that you did n't trust ) , you just pop the cartridge out of the dash take it with you , addressing the issue with CD theft .
-Sound on the Bose system is kind of flat with neutral settings .
-This is 2002 .
It is inexcusable that this top of the line Bose system offered by Nissan does n't playing CD-R/RW discs MP3 recordings .
-Seat bottoms are uncomfortable ( too short ) .
-Drive ratios for the transmission are poorly chosen .
At an 80 mph I 'm at about 2800 rpm , though this is difficult to pinpoint exactly given the poor granularity on the speedo .
since the speedometer be high by 8-12 mph , this actually be the RPM at 70 mph .
be a 5-speed to allow for more drive ratios lower RPMs ( better gas mileage ) when cruising .
-It be nice the shifter gate area was lit .
-Brakes are over-boosted good .
-Steering is numb there is a good deal of torque steer when applying power turning .

For instance , traffic is stopping in front of you you want to move across 5 lanes form the left lane to the right lane .
I wonder how this car in a cone slalom ?

---April 3 , 2002 update---
For instance , an 70 mph is about actual 67.2 mph +-.5 mph .
An 85 mph is actual 80.5 mph This is about a 4-6 % error which I assume is within spec for a non-calibrated , mass produced mechanical device .
I now have 1475 miles on the car the last gas fill-up covering 308 mostly highway miles shows an average mpg of 18.94 ( spreadsheet calculation ) .
The car computer is showing 21.2 mpg , an 11 % error .
Since the computer calculation for mpg is wrong , the associated calculation for tank time to empty is also wrong .
I now have about 6500 miles on the car .
On the positive side , I have to say that I really like the looks people still look at it as I pass them by .

Parked next to a 2.5 , the 3.5 looked a lot better .

But this clears up when the car warms up .

Exterior Styling

18 " wheels really fill the wells make the car look even better .
The lines of the car provide the driver with a high hood shoulder line but this is acceptable to make one more like they 're sitting in the car , despite the flat bucket seats ( more on that later ) .
The dual , stainless exhaust tips accent the rear of the vehicle , my favorite aspect of the styling is the front fascia , headlights grille with the chrome mustang .
A good compromise was made , I , between aggressive sleek design options .
The wrap-around headlights indicators provide a sleek , aerodynamic appeal while the fairly sharp-cornered bumper raked grille add a slight harshness to the smoothness of the other details .
Overall the car looks great .
The only downfall I see with the exterior design is the that it look a little dated in a few years , much like the mid to late 90 's Mustangs do .
On a slightly similar note , one problem with the exterior of my vehicle is that the driver passenger doors do n't to line up flush with the rear quarter panels .
While this does n't detract from the overall styling , it 's annoying none-the-less .
I 'm really excited about the '05 Mustang styling it force me to buy another one a few years down the road .
This really is a love-hate relationship .
The beige dash , carpet leather go really well with the red exterior beige top .
I have had a number of people comment on how nice the interior of the car looks upon entering the vehicle .
, for the most part I agree .
The center console , where the HVAC. , radio miscellaneous buttons for fog lights , traction control rear defrost are located , also light up in the same green glow .
The three HVAC.
knobs are simple looking but effective .
A nice touch to impress upon the passengers that this is in fact a true American icon .
The problem is , like the exterior styling , I fear the interior will also dated in a couple of years .
Also , while some of the materials good to the touch provide a soft , almost spongy , others , like the door handle inserts , shifter bezel , A-pillar covers center console panels like , really are , cheap plastic .
A few months ago , the retainer tab that keeps the on off button in place broke , causing the button to fall off .
Fit finish is also a bit below par .
The A-pillar covers do n't line up well with the dash , the center console panel does n't sit flush with the shifter bezel the door handle inserts bow out leave a gap between the main door panel the insert .
The last problem , with the door panel inserts , causes an annoying buzzing issue when the radio is turned up there is a large bass hit from the speakers in the doors .
lastly , the seats for this version of the Mustang use some attention .
They provide very little lateral such that when cornering , one is inclined to slide around a fair amount .
Further , they do n't look like true pony sports car buckets but they are flat unappealing .
The head rests on the front two seats are small because of the seat back design almost worthless in preventing any sort of whiplash .
I 'm almost inclined to say that my friend 's cloth GT seats are better than mine .
Even though I like leather better than cloth , it makes it hard to overlook these shortfalls .
Another such short fall was at about 10,000 miles some cracking in the driver 's side seat back requiring a replacement of the seat cover started to .
Performance
Performance : one of the main reasons for the purchase of this car .
While this is highly debatable , it does n't get much better than the Mustang considering the cost of the vehicle what it was designed to do .
My GT is outfitted with Ford 's 4.6L 2V SOHC V8 from their modular line of eight cylinder engines the Tremec T3650 5-speed manual transmission ( as I understand it , an original Getrag design , though I be mistaken ) .
While the car pulls pretty well below 2500 RPMs, the real acceleration power is definitely felt in the 3000-5000 RPM range .
The exhaust note adds the exclamation point to the power acceleration making the car a bit faster than it is .
The car possesses a willingness to go from a standstill has problems accelerating onto an interstate overtaking a semi at highway cruising speeds .
There 's an addictive quality to downshifting from fifth gear into forth even third at these higher speeds , watching the revs ramp up eagerly while the engine responds appropriately .
The car feels just as capable cruising along at 70 to 85 mph as it does between 35 45 mph .
Surprisingly to me , it that the engine be out of its element to cruise along at 85 mph all day long , much like the machinery under the hood of a BMW.
I the durability dependability will live up to this .
Another surprising pleasing aspect to the performance of the engine was the fuel economy .
With this driving , I have been able to obtain an overall fuel economy of just over 22 MPG using standard 87 octane unleaded .
On longer road trips , with expressway driving , I have been able to squeeze out 27.7 MPG !
This provides a range of about 400 miles ; for a V8 , I was impressed .
The transmission does an adequate job sending the torque to the rear wheels .
First gear short fifth quite tall .
Overall , the ratios appropriate the transmission does n't over tasked with the power torque being sent through it .
It is perfect though .
The throws , especially from forth to fifth , are quite long .
It feels good for going from first to second from third to forth , but I a bit over extended in the last up shift .
The shifter also a bit notchy .
I understand that these two issues be solved with a Steeda similar aftermarket brand shifter but I wonder the notchyness sometimes the difficulty of getting into a gear is the fault of the shifter some other problem .
I worry too much but I 'm concerned about the longevity of the synchros .
On cold days ( less than 20°F ) I 've also experienced a strange whistling/whining noise at about 2000 RPM that I to be gear whine from the transmission .
I have n't heard it since the weather has started warming up but this is still a concern that I have investigated .
lastly , there 's a fair amount of driveline lash that causes a clunk in some accelerating situations from low RPMs.
Overall , the performance of the Mustang GT be defined as a smile inducing , great value .
Handling/Steering
Some of the best handling cars that I 've driven include a 1997 BMW M3 , a 1991 Jetta GLI with aftermarket Pirelli tires , a 2003 Mazda 6 surprisingly a 2002 Focus ( all models , including the wagon SVT handle quite well ) .
While the Mustang is n't among that list of cars , it certainly is slouch providing MacPherson struts in the front a variable rate , Quadra shock rear suspension with Traction Lok rear axle stabilizer bar .
Some of the most fun I 've had in this vehicle has been entering the freeways from cloverleaf entrance ramps .
Accelerating around these slightly banked curves as the car holds its line tightly , exhibits the fact that the car has a nicely tuned suspension .
The Mustang has very little body roll when attacking corners curves but unfortunately a large amount of dive squat is when braking ( slightly hard ) accelerating .
With all the torque going to the rear , the GT be pushed into a fun over steer condition ( with traction control turned off ) I 've rarely encountered under steer .
Two times come to mind .
The most surprising least , due to the good weather conditions low speed , was most the result of some glazed blacktop on a two lane road .
The other time involved some sand .
Under steer does to be much of a problem in this car .
On the whole though , steering is decent boosted sufficiently at low speeds but as much at higher speeds providing good road feedback .
The steering is tight linear : a steering wheel input provides an vehicle turning output .
The wheel is appropriately sized requires about two a half turns to go stop to stop ( I 'm estimating because I 've really counted ) .
The wheel has four spokes to provide a comfortable one-handed two-handed grip .
The tilting wheel puts it at the driver 's preferred angle .
There is a stretch of freeway on my commute that is so bad I sometimes fear the car will rattle apart .
Sometimes , body flex is in the convertible due to the suspension absorbing all road abnormalities but this be in any convertible .
Some axle hop be brought about when accelerating into a turn from a stop over broken pavement .
This is a definite annoying aspect of the solid rear axle .
While I still have the stock tires on my car ( Goodyear Eagle ZRs ) they adequate provide decent grip in dry wet weather .
I have about 10,000 miles left on them then it will be time to get new rubber .
I have n't decided what tires I will go with but I will get the OE.
I like a tire with a little better traction in wet snowy conditions , .
Driver/Passenger Comfort Miscellaneous Items
When it comes to the quality of cars , I be picky .
Squeaks rattles drive me nuts unfortunately , since my Mustang is a convertible , various squeaks rattles accompany every outing in this car .
I had to complain about only one thing in this vehicle , this be it .
The list is quite long : the vibrating door handle inserts , the center HVAC vents rattle , when the blower is on , there is a rattle coming from the passenger foot well , the two rear quarter windows squeak when they 're rolled up , there 's a squeaking/buzzing , on occasion , from the windshield/dashboard area at speeds around 70/75 mph , there 's a rattle from the passenger side A-pillar , there is a rattle coming from the passenger side rear quarter glass area ( sounds like it 's inside the body ) , when the passenger window is rolled down all the way , the headliner buzzes lastly when driving at about 40/45 mph with the top up , sometimes there is a buzzing noise that sounds like the vinyl from the top is loose .
Maybe I 'm picky but of these things occur ; though , most of these NVH issues go notice to an average customer ( which I do n't consider myself to be ) .
On the whole the car is fairly comfortable to drive , providing decent visibility fairly comfortable seating with the lumbar .
Despite this small annoyance it really is a fun car for long distance driving ( longest nonstop drive I 've had is about five hours ) I to get it down to Florida on a future vacation for an extended drive .
Some small annoyances but problems I 've noticed in the car include the following : of a floor vent mix selection on the HVAC system ( a defrost floor option is available but I try to minimize my use of this to avoid the parasitic quality of the compressor on the engine during defrost use ) .
I wish there was a built-in compass thermometer in the vehicle ; I it be nice to have it incorporated with the digital odometer much like the new Explorer ; further , two trip odometers be nice , as opposed to the one offered ; the glove compartment is a bit small .
Summary
Despite the small nit-picky complaints I had in the previous section , I am very pleased with this vehicle .
you 're looking for a fun-to-drive , American icon with good power acceleration , take a look at the Ford Mustang GT.
, with the looks of the 2005 concept , this vehicle line will continue its success well into the future .
Overall I it works well is evidence of a strong commitment to design at Chrysler .
Inside , the driving position is almost perfect , although the driver 's seat in the model I drove did adjust for height , it was extremely easy to get comfortable .
Luggage space , too , is a strong point , with lots of room underneath the rear hatchback , useful storage trays .
Negatives , unfortunately , outweigh the positives , at least on the model I drove .
Fifteen years ago , an autobox this poor have been the norm , but in 2002 it 's unacceptable .
Many manufacturers , including Honda , Toyota VW , offer far superior automatic transmissions , even on their low end models .
That said , I get the chance to drive a five speed model any time soon , I 'll update my review accordingly .
Handling is only average , with some significant body roll steering that is all but of accuracy .
handling quality has been sacrificed at the expense of the smooth ride , but many other manufacturers able to balance these qualities far more effectively .
Forward visibility is excellent , thanks in part to the upright driving position large , steeply-angled windshield .
The large exterior mirrors help to a certain extent , but they also to generate a lot of wind noise at high speeds .
While the interior does have some nice touches , such as the chrome-rimmed , white-faced dials body-colored accents , it is dominated by expanses of cheap plastic .
Switchgear does n't have quite the same brittle , low rent as most GM products , but it is n't in the same league as the Japanese competition , let alone VW.
Overall , I ca n't recommend the PT Cruiser .
Competitors such as the VW Golf New Beetle , the upcoming MINI Toyota 's Matrix still to be a long way ahead of Chrysler in combining style a great driving experience .

Mitsubishi has finally decided to bring an up to date compact to American shores .
The Lancer has been available in other parts of the world for a while so the mechanicals of the car chassis are reliable .
Mitsubishi gave the car crisp lines which establish a clean look .
The headlights integrated turn signal assembly look more European than Asian in origin .
The only area which looks a bit plain be the tail light clusters , but remember we 're talking about a sub $ 16k car , most other compacts are better in this regard .
Now on to more mechanical matters :
I test drove Focus , Elantra , Protege , Civic high level trims .
The Mitsubishi engine is simply a jewel while running absolutely puts the Ford Zetec Hyundai engine to shame .
The 5spd manual transmission shifts nicely has a real 5th gear overdrive which drops the revs for quiet highway cruising .
In 5th gear at 70MPH , the Lancer is only turning approx 2750RPM.
The clutch has a high engagement point compared to other manual tranmission cars I test drove , but it 's a big issue .
EPA fuel economy rating is 28/33 with the 5spd manual .
However on my first tank I got 33mpg in mixed city/hwy with the A/C on almost all the time .
Considering the car now has only 272 miles on it , I 'd say that 's pretty encouraging .
Additionally , the Lancer 's engine provides very decent off the line punch to get the car moving up to speed .
You do have to rev the engine up to near redline in order to achieve satisfying acceleration .
The Lancer 's chassis is an area that will disappoint pocket rocket enthusiasts expecting race car type cornering go-kart like reflexes .
However , for the rest of us , a Lancer in stock form ( across all trim levels ) provides a quiet , comfortable , controlled ride across a variety of pavement surfaces .
Handling is sloppy , but a bit behind the Protege .
Protege is much more controlled during quick cornering , but at the expense of a somewhat harsh jittery ride - especially on bad pavement .
The Lancer OZ is to be a bit more sporty , but does n't have anything mechanically to "kick it up a notch " in the handling department versus the LS ES trims .
My Lancer came with Goodyear Eagle LS tires , which are a pure passenger car tire with performance inclination .
Brakes are front ventilated disc / rear drum provide sufficient stopping power for normal duties .
All the other cars I 've mentioned with the exception of the Protege ES use a disc/drum setup , but it have been nice Mitsubishi had installed four wheel disc brakes ( on the OZ at least ) for increased stopping power .
The only quirk is that Mitsubishi only offers ABS on the Lancer LS trim level , it 's available on the ES OZ.
You simply as you have a larger car beneath as you go down the road .
Interior design-wise , Mitsubishi provides a very roomy interior within a small size car .
I they stole a little space from the trunk to give to back seat passengers , but I have three friends in the car , I they 'd appreciate it .
I rate front seat comfort as very good - I 'm 6'3 245lbs long legged .
The driver 's seat goes far enough back that I stretch out while driving a dead pedal is provided for your left foot for even more comfort .
The benefit of the OZ for me was that a slightly upscale black interior is used with nice looking black fabric cloth for the seats .
Another nice perk for the OZ is that the gauge cluster is styled after Mitsubishi 's Evolution rally car .
Gauges are creme faced , round , easy to read , glow a soft orange/red at night for easy visibility .
I am going to grad school wanted to get a much more economical car that was more suited to my needs .
After a week with my new Lancer OZ , I 've gotten all that much more , including a vehicle which is fully paid off .
you 're in the market for a new compact , you 'd be negligent you did n't go to your Mitsubishi dealership to at least test drive a new Lancer .
I 'm sure that Honda Toyota loyalists decree that Mitsubishi does n't have the goods to compete since they 're the more established players in the arena .
However , a quick test drive enlighten you to the fact that Mitsubishi has done their homework here at the very least now offer a product on par with their Japanese rivals .
The Mitsubishi Lancer is all new for the 2002 model year , replacing the cute , yet infamous Mitsubishi Mirage .
While the Mirage was a cheap car made with cheap materials , its successor boasts only slight quality improvements at a much higher price .
While the commercials have young trendy adults singing to ' Barenaked Ladies ' seeming to have a great time with this car , I have come to the that singing along to trendy rock tunes with the Lancer 's 100 watt stereo system be one of this car 's only fun attributes .
For 2002 the Mitsubishi Lancer comes in 3 trim lines , the ES ( my tester ) , LS , OZ.
All trim lines come with a 2.0 SOHC 4-cylinder engine that pumps out a lackluster 120 horsepower at 5,500 RPM , 130 lb-ft of torque at 4,250 RPM.
Power is distributed to the front wheels via a standard 5-speed manual transmission , a 4-speed fully automatic transmission ( as was in my tester ) .
Note : you plan on buying the sport model 'OZ ' Edition do n't plan on getting any better performance than with the base models .
The OZ has the same 120 horsepower 2.0 4-banger mated with the same transmissions .
According to the November 02 issue of Motor Trend Magazine , a version of the high performance Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VII will be available sometime next year .
Driving impressions :
With a hefty curb weight of 2,700 Lbs , 120 horses , peak torque reached a relatively high RPM , off-the-line acceleration mated with the 4-speed fully automatic transmission came , at first with slight hesitation , then with needed patience .
Although the 4-speed automatic transmission is somewhat smooth , it is the best pick for this SOHC 2.0 set-up .
I 'd recommend going with the 5-speed you choose this car .
Despite the heavy curb weight , the small wheels and tires , I felt that I was going to lose control on the twistys , was I conscious of this car 's relatively hefty curb weight while driving .
Bumps rattles be present on certain road surfaces , but this usually is too annoying .
Hills are taken fairly well .
The 4-speed automatic will shift down into 3rd gear on almost any incline , but the ride remains calm , the engine does n't get as loud as fussy as with some car 's engines in this class while accomplishing these sorts of tasks .
The Lancer ES comes standard with front wheel disc/rear drum brakes ABS.
Despite this cost effective , health hazard set-up , the Lancer stopped with little effort felt more like a 4-wheel disc set-up than the dinosaur set-up which it was equipped with .
Fuel economy is a little disappointing .
The EPA rates this car with an automatic at only 31 MPG during freeway driving .
This EPA is almost 10 MPG less than the EPA ratings for the Honda Civic Toyota Corolla .
Engine Gripes : Mitsubishi is going to charge this much cash for their cars , they are going to need to pay much more detail to their powertrains .
SOHC engines in expensive cars , even sport oriented cars are at all desired .
More technology , DOHC designs , including VVT be welcomed .
Interior Accommodation :
I have read a few reviews on this car over at www.cars.com ,
despite many reviewers saying this car has the interior set-up of the 1980s Chrysler K cars , it is nowhere near that bad , but the interior does leave a lot to be desired .
The drivers position is also very good which offers great vision in all directions , easy access to the instrumentation .
Dual Air bags , AC , intermittent windshield wipers , tachometer , a 100 watt , 4-speaker Mitsubishi sound system is standard .
This sound system is clear , but Bose by any means .
The convenience package adds some items such as cruise control , 60/40 split bench rear seats .
www.mitsubishi.com
has more info on all standard optional equipment that be had for the ES other Lancer trim lines .
The front bucket seats are a major complaint , I found them hard to the 'butt touch' , offered little back .
The Lancer ES 's cargo storage is adequate at most , the trunk is small , but there are plenty of pockets in the cabin for small items , like broken knobs etc .
Exterior Innovation :
The exterior of the 2002 Lancer is really nothing to write home about , but it 's ugly duckling .
Mitsubishi played it pretty safe with the styling of this small sedan .
I do like the front fascia , as it offers a chrome grille , an 'open mouthed ' front bumper which adds a little more sexy modern appeal to this otherwise blase 'get lost in traffic ' car .
The headlights are with see-through effects which also help this car keep with the 'times ' .
Price , Reliability , and Warranty :
For 2002 the Lancer ES with a manual transmission starts at around $ 14,000 , however , with options , such as an automatic transmission the price quickly rises to near $ 17,000 as was my tester 's sticker price .
Looking for a faster , yet more fuel efficient economy car ?
You want to check out my review on the Toyota Corolla

Two weeks ago , I spent several days behind the wheel of a 2002 Ford Taurus SE (you see a review based on my week in a Taurus at http ://www.epinions.com/content
) ./SYM Lo behold , when I picked up a rental car the next week , the kind folks at my neighborhood Enterprise handed me the keys to a Mercury Sable .
Over the next five days , I put slightly under 500 miles on the vehicle ; the bulk of which was highway driving .
The Car
Enterprise rented me a 2002 Sable GS model , a four-door , with Lincoln-Mercury 's stock V6 Vulcan engine four-speed automatic overdrive transmission .
The vehicle came equipped with dual airbags , power doors/windows/mirrors , cloth seats , AM/FM/Cassette , tilt wheel , cruise control , intermittent wipers , AC.
This model (unlike last week 's Taurus ) also included remote keyless entry .
Styling Notes
The trunk , however , is carpeted in the same gray as the Taurus .
Much of the difference ( what little there is ) between a Taurus a Sable is in the styling .
Since frame body components of the two vehicles are identical , any additional "luxury " be imparted by changes in pieces parts that are inserted , attached , otherwise appended to the core of the automobile .
That , for the most part , means additional chrome : the Sable 's grille has a chrome surround ( reminiscent of the Jaguar grille ) the body trim molding boasts a chrome insert of the plain color-matched molding on the Taurus .
Head - tail-lights are subtly different ; the Sable 's lighting modules have a more traditional appearance the elongate teardrop motif of the Taurus .
The most striking body difference is in the trunkline .
The Sable 's trunk bears the slightest of a bulge at the rear , with the addition of a chrome emblem on the rear-facing surface to the classic Lincoln Continental .
A luxury note is added by the faux walnut surround on the central panel , viewing which makes me wonder : is there but one supplier for fake burled walnut in the world , does everybody make that same color pattern of ugly plastic ?
The instrument cluster remains unchanged , as does the central panel containing the climate control entertainment centers .
The radio controls feature the same tired black rocker switches used in the Taurus ; the climate control is the stock three-knob system used by Ford for decades ( an automatic temperature-control system is optional ) .
Driver-Car Interface
Cornering braking , as in the Taurus , are acceptable but unremarkable .
The overall ride is comfortable on smooth roads , with a slight sway on bumpy uneven surfaces .
The stock 155-hp Vulcan V6 is the same engine used in the SE model Taurus ; it suffers the same acceptable high-end torque deficient low-end acceleration I noted in the Sable 's twin .
As in the Taurus SE , the engine was coupled to a four-speed automatic overdrive transmission ( steering column-mounted ) .
My mileage on this trip came in at 22 MPG , much the same as my experience in the Taurus .
The cockpit , too , is identical to that of the Taurus , with controls switches arrayed within comfortable reach of the averaged-sized driver ( me ) .
An available pedal placement control option , which raises lowers the accelerator/brake pedal complex , prove useful to shorter drivers .
The Sable , like the Taurus , provides illumination in the door window controls so that they be found in the dark .
Driving Environment
Seating in this trim level of the Sable is identical to that of the Taurus SE ; with comfortable but unremarkable cloth seats .
The GS , like the Taurus SE , motor-driven seat adjustment also has minimal lumbar .
Rear-seat room is sufficient for three average-sized passengers , though all three find the configuration uncomfortable for more than an hour so of riding .
The glove compartment is of a reasonable size the somewhat strange shape of that found in the Taurus .
There are map pockets in the door ( surprise ) a small cubbyhole for change , other small items below the climate controls .
The trunk capacity is , like that of the Taurus , about 17 cubic feet has an moderately high sill .
Unlike the Taurus , there is cargo net , but there are two small plastic wells molded into the floor at the sides of the space .
At the GS trim level , the back seats do fold is there any form of pass-through ; long cargo hang over the trunk lip be relegated to the roof .
Wind noise is very pronounced at highway speeds , even moreso than in the Taurus .
Engine noise is somewhat intrusive , although road noise is minimal unless the road surface is especially coarse ( fresh chip-and-seal surfaces , for instance ) .
Highs Lows
These are my personal observations about this Sable model , with additional explanation where necessary :
+/SYM good rear-seat room
+/SYM large trunk capacity
+/SYM clear dash instrument-panel layout
+/SYM fuel economy
Mmmmm , Maybe : The Neutral Zone
