On Quality
This particular Sable was as poorly constructed as the Taurus I drove last week ( ergo the 3-star rating as opposed to the Taurus 's 2-star ) , but there is still room for improvement .
Quality problems I noted in a cursory inspection included :
- The two-tone dashboard is actually one piece ; the boundary between the two color areas was irregular
- There was a color mis-match between the dashboard the panel covering the passenger airbag .
Rant
One area in which the Taurus the Sable ( other Ford products , I remember correctly ) are deficient -- in my humble opinion -- is in the climate control engineering .
There are three knobs for this system : fan speed , temperature , a "position " selector .
Other manufacturers give you the option for recirculate vs external circulation in any position ( face , floor , defrost ) with the AC on off ; in a Ford it 's only available in AC.
When on AC ( Max AC ) you have to play with the vents to balance air in the face on the floor .
Other manufacturers give us control over the AC unit is running in any vent position also over the circulation in any vent position .
Why wo n't Ford 's engineers do the same ?
There 's a dime 's worth of difference between the Sable GS the Taurus GE in the realm of engineering , handling , comfort .
The minor differences in styling are insignificant to the intrinsic value of the car , but are there only to add a taste of "luxury , " so they 're worth it , I guess .
you do n't mind paying an extra $ 200 so ( base price Taurus SE vs base price Sable GS ) for the chrome trim that fake walnut on the dashboard , free to pony it up .
your Lincoln-Mercury dealer is much more convenient than your Ford dealer , it 's a no-brainer .
Otherwise , shop 'em both see who 'll give you the best deal .
you buy a Camry , -- get a dish of Japanese-flavored plain vanilla of US-flavored plain vanilla .

The ZX2 is wonderful , but then I'll admit I'm enamored with smaller cars , I see reason to pay big $ $ $ just to impress the parking valet , also our kids are grown , so the back seat is mostly just for storage on trips .
Before we bought the ZX2 we also looked at the Dodge Neon , the Honda Civic the Ford Focus .
The Neon was unimpressive , but the Civic was quite nice , just $ 3-4K nicer , that our local dealers were charging for equivalent options .
We like Fords , but when they replaced the solid little Escort with the Euro-esque Focus ( although both it the ZX2 we bought , are actually assembled in Mexico ) , I had to gulp .
I've tried to like the Focus , mechanically they're on par better than anything else in this price range -- but I guess my ancestors have been gone from Europe way too long for me to appreciate that wedge-of-cheese look .
The ZX2 reminds me of the little Audi I brought back from Germany in the 1980s , although the ZX2's fit finish is much , much better than I remember from my Audi ( which I also liked very much ) .
Although there is any doubt that you're in a 4-cylinder car , the ZX2 is noticeably faster than our Escort SE , twin cams , etc . I've seen 0-60 times under 8 seconds in some articles , although I've timed it , the performance is in the neighborhood of what I recall from my mid-sized 327 Camero , only the ZX2 gets a little over 35mpg on the road ( we usually get better than EPA said ) .
We've had several Escorts over the years ( something over 400K miles worth ) , despite how the consumer publications always try to steer buyers much further upscale , I really they're the true meaning of value sport .
We've had our ZX2 on a couple long trips , like we've said about our other Escorts ( after driving `em all over the United States , driving for days on end ) , two "AARP Land " candidates are comfortable in them , then they're comfortable ( we to drive 30K++ miles every year , but these cars make the going inexpensive ) .
Our ZX2 is the most comfortable of the bunch , however .
At first the ZX2 was a compromise that to be forced on us because Ford longer makes the 4-door models .
But now , my only fear is that Ford will soon discontinue the Escort ZX2 line altogether ( I 've talked to the factory rep about this ) .
I just they send the Focus to one of those Hollywood plastic surgeons in the meantime , it badly needs a facelift before I'd be as happy with it as our ZX2 .
a ZX2 on the horizon , that Civic just be worth the extra $ 3K over the Focus , in the meantime we're happily piling the miles on our ZX2 .
Almost 40 years old now , the Mustang is still going strong .
According to specs sells have reached over 150,000 units for 2002 alone ; people continue to flood into showrooms to get the 'best bang for their buck ' .
The Mustang for 2002 comes in 4 models , the 2 base trim lines which feature a 190 horsepower 3.8 liter engine that is offered in a convertible coupe .
The other 2 trim lines are performance models , known as the GT.
The GT features a SOHC , 4.6 liter unit , is also offered in a coupe convertible .
NOTE : There is Cobra offered this year , next year there will be a 390 horsepower , supercharged , Cobra Mustang .
Driving Impressions :
Since 1999 the Mustang GT has underwent dramatic styling , performance changes , minor interior chassis modifications .
Most people favor these changes made by Ford .
The Mustang GT longer has a 'just adequate ' 215 horse power as it did in 1996-1997 , does it have 225 horse power like it had in '98.
For the 2002 model year the Mustang GT now has an exciting 260 horsepower at 5,250 RPM , 302 lb-ft of torque with its modified 4.6 liter SOHC modular V8 . 260 horse power for a Muscle car/sports car sound 'super powerful' , especially since its rival , the Camaro Z28 has 60 more horses .
The 2002 GT does very well with the the 260 horses provided .
The 5-speed allows the driver to get the most out of this engine , although it be appreciated a silky smooth 6-speed was added to the line-up .
The considerable power increase in the mid-range after 1999 means the GT really moves !
Burnouts are almost inevitable when matched with the 5-speed manual , especially when in the hands of a driver with a heavy foot .
The top speed is reported to be near 150 MPH , but you wo n't see me driving one that fast , at least on the street .
I have only taken my friends 2002 Mustang GT Coupe ( my test machine ) out for a few runs by myself , each time it 's a blast .
I do test drive quite a few cars , out of all the cars under $ 30,000 , the 2002 GT is one of the most involving to drive , one of the fastest to boot .
The GT 's dual exhaust offers a beefy note , letting other drivers know you are in a serious muscle car .
The Mustang GT is very compliant on bumpy roads , especially for a performance natured car , does quite well in slippery conditions , thanks to its genius traction control .
A stiff chassis well-tuned suspension means the 2002 Mustang GT really takes to twisty roads with enthusiasm .
A fairly wide-track , large 17 " rims , with all season radials result in excellent stability impressively high levels of grip .
My Test car came with 4-wheel discs with 4-wheel ABS , this is standard safety equipment on all 2002 Mustangs .
Note : to get around 26 MPG with conservative driving with the 5-speed manual .
Also a 4-speed automatic transmission is optional .
About the engine : In 1996 , the Mustang GT ditched the 5.0 OHV unit , got a new engine in the form of a 4.6 liter V8 modular unit .
While rated at only 215 horse power in 1996 1997 , 225 in 1998 , the 1999-2002 Mustang GT 's offer basically the same 4.6 SOHC engine , only with 260 horse power 302 lb-ft of torque .
This welcomed increase in power is mainly because of higher lift , longer duration cams , bigger valves , a revised intake system .
The 2002 Mustang GT also got a revised suspension in 1999 , namely a wider rear track , greater suspension travel .
The 1999-2002 Mustang GT 's also have received revised shock absorbers anti roll bars to improve handling .
note : The base models equipped with the 3.8 liter engines do get this treatment .
Interior Accommodation :
The interior of the 2002 Mustang GT is very well laid out , very well equipped .
Test car came with power everything , a thick leather wrapped steering wheel , an optional 460 watt stereo system , with a 6 disc CD changer .
Some other amenities included a super cold AC , daytime running lamps , a tachometer , a theft deterrent system , tinted glass .
Ergonomics are near perfect in the 2002 GT , so is the drivers position .
The GT offers excellent visibility , easy-to-use controls , superior comfort for long journeys .
The Mustang GT 's 2 front sport bucket seats were dressed in leather boasted 6 way power .
The seats in the Front are very comfortable supportive , but because of the of leg head room in the rear , the experience is quite as positive .
The front passenger driver are given plenty of room however .
Exterior Innovation :
There really is much difference from the look of the base models , some minor cosmetic treatments , some include side hood scoops , a GT badge on the side of the car , a ' Mustang GT' badge in-graved in the rear bumper .
The front Headlights are flush , very slightly 'cat eyed' , triple taillights continue to be part of the Mustangs theme , but they now have sharper edges like the rest of the body .
A GT model will run in-between $ 22,000-$ 28,000 .
My test car has 8,000 miles on it , my friend has had to take it to the shop , but with only 8,000 miles it 's kinda hard to comment on her car 's reliability .
The GT has always been a fairly reliable car , even in its pushrod days , the GT has offered years of reliable performance , just look at all the older GT 's we see on the road .
I you ask around , I 'm guessing you will hear good news from the owners of these cars .
Ford does offer the best warranty , Ford offers a 3 year 36,000 mile bumper to bumper warranty on the GT.
Final Notes :
It takes a certain type of person to appreciate the Mustang GT , you are into high revving 4-cylinders this is definitely your car .
The 2002 GT offers excellent muscle accommodation at an excellent price .
you liked this review , you also like to read my review on the Mustang 's rival , the Camaro Z28

For 2002 , Acura gives the Type-S treatment to its formerly bland TL sedan .
Now you don't have to buy a coupe to get the 260 horsepower engine , 17" wheels , sportier interior that have made the CL Type-S so popular .
With a price of $ 31,700 , the TL Type-S continues Acura's "more stuff for less money " strategy .
The TL Type-S offers more power more room for much less money than a BMW 330i Lexus IS300 .
Does this make it a genuine bargain among sports sedans ?
Since this is the category I am personally most interested in , I took an extended test drive to find out .
Styling Accommodations
But maybe it was just the fussy wheels that came with the basic TL its first few years .
The Type-S's larger , thick-spoked wheels bring out the slightly aggressive quality previously hidden in the TL's angular lines .
While the car is still short of striking , in this incarnation I easily live with it .
The TL's interior has always been a great place to sit .
The front seats are very supportive , with excellent lateral .
A bump on the leading edge of the cushion provides better than average but still ideal thigh .
The interior details added by the Type-S,champagne instrument faces , perforations in the leather , , with the ebony interior , smoke-colored simulated wood,lend a sporty look to the excellent interior of the standard TL.
I personally prefer lighter-colored interiors .
One problem with this in the Type-S is that the parchment interior has the standard simulated wood .
Its shade is far too orange for my taste .
there is a ton of it .
The trunk is at best average in size on paper but fairly large usefully shaped .
Unfortunately , the rear seats do fold down .
Only a pass through is provided .

The manual feature of the standard automatic transmission is easy to use , reacts as quickly as most of these .

Unfortunately , in the areas of ride handling it has a number of major flaws .

When accelerating , the front end feels light the steering gets squirrelly .

The tires stick well , when accelerating the steering provides good feedback .

But the TL Type-S remains less than eager to turn in .

I'm now eager to see they will have the same problems .

It's just plain awful , worse than anything I've driven in recent memory .

Update : Xorg in his own excellent review says that the hard ride I experienced be caused by overinflated tires .

But that 's assuming they have brains ...

It significantly affect your evaluation of the car .
They also felt the car did handle all that well .

A 260 horsepower engine 17" performance tires do a BMW killer make , even the price to be amazingly low .
The basic car , derived from the Accord , is simply up to this mission .
Given the pattern of the car's faults , I'm beginning to wonder Honda hired all of those engineers that took early retirement from GM in the early 90s .
It's a shame , because the world really needs a great high performance sedan for around $ 30,000 .
Is anyone listening ?

Acura's decision to junk real model names in favor of two-letter designations did n't help .
But now they've found a new formula , it to be working for them .
Like the successful 1999 redesign of the TL , with which it shared a Honda Accord-based chassis , the 2001 CL Type S came standard with everything a navigation system ( even a Bose sound system with a six-disk in-dash CD changer ! ) .
Nothing significant has changed for 2002 .
The most notable standard feature is a 3.2 liter six the produces 260 horsepower at a high but still accessible 6100 RPM.
This is 35 more than the 225 of the standard CL of the new 3.0 liter in the roughly $ 10,000 more expensive BMW 330Ci .
Only one transmission is available : a five speed automatic .
in an attempt to placate those who wonder where the manual is , this automatic comes even in the regular CL with a "sequential sportshift , " which supposedly offers the control of a manual the bother of a clutch .
Update : For 2003 a manual is finally available in the CL-S.
I have driven this car , posted a review of it under the listing for the 2003 CL-S here : http ://www.epinions.com/content
So the CL Type S poses as a serious yet much less expensive challenger to the BMW 330Ci .
Does it really measure up ?
To find out , I took one for a drive .
Styling
The more serious mission of the second-generation CL is evident in its styling .
The first CL was attractive , even pretty .
But the styling of the first CL did exude substance luxury .
Its styling connoted playfulness , lightness , agility .
Yet , despite some of the flavor of the late BMW 6-series , it did n't have the look of a serious luxury car .
Acura has fixed this with the new car .
Though roughly the same size,the largest dimensional change is a two inch increase in length,the new car much larger .
This is largely the result of shrinking the greenhouse bulking up the body .
Though similar in size , the new car is about 500 lbs .
heavier .
What designers refer to as the DLO ( for daylight opening , the side window outline ) is strikingly similar to the last Nissan 240SX , which to stand out against other coupes in the marketplace .
Where the old DLO curved up quite a bit towards the rear , the new one curves subtly down .
The rear end of the car is longer strongly tapered .
It now looks much like that of many other cars .
I personally lament these styling changes .
But I admit they make grant the new CL a much more substantial , more serious , considerably more luxurious appearance .
To hammer this message home the CL Type S rides on 17" wheels with a strong five-spoke design .
On the inside the serious performance message is conveyed by perforated leather , metallic gray gauge faces , , with the ebony interior , "black wood . "
( The parchment interior comes with the brown wood of the standard CL. )
The last , similar in appearance to that found in high performance Jags Mercedes , covers large portions of the door panels center console .
you want still more of it , the dealer add a piece around the instruments .
How Acura afford such extravagance in a $ 30,000 automobile ?
Easy : unlike that in the European brands this "wood " is plastic .
Especially those who dislike the trendier gray variety .
Accommodations
The view forward is especially nice , with the steering wheel well below even a short driver's field of vision .
I like to see the instruments , but I mostly want to see OUT.
Though the side windows are much shorter than in the old CL , the beltline is uncomfortably high , about on par with the BMW.
The front seats only look impressive but are very comfortable hold you in place very well due to their large bolsters .
They are slightly softer than the traditionally hard ( though still comfortable ) seats in the BMW.
My only complaint about the driving position is that the steering wheel feels a bit close .
Though the Acura is over a foot longer a few hundred pounds heavier than the BMW, simply feels like a significantly larger car , it is similarly tight in the rear seat .
Though I'm only 5'9" , I barely fit in the rear seat behind a similarly sized driver .
the extra length weight went towards the flowing exterior lines rather than the interior .
At least it is easy to get into the rear seats compared to other coupes .
The CL does pretend to seat five : the center of the rear seat is occupied by a storage console .
The major problem with the rear seat is that it does fold down,there is only a pass-through behind the armrest .
The BMW does offer this feature .
I personally want a car it unless I planned to use it to carry moderately large objects .
In both of the cars I own the rear seat folds down , I've used this feature many times to carry large objects such as book cases cribs .
The Type S's throttle is tuned to make the car jump the moment you tip into the throttle .
This is both good bad .
It conveys the capabilities of the car .
But it also makes a smooth , subtle launch difficult .
Your passengers you 're having trouble growing up .
Then again , this be the image you are after .
Give it gas , the engine immediately responds .
This engine does n't only make 35 more horsepower on the high end , 500 RPM further up the tach .
It also has a higher , flatter torque curve through the mid-range , so it will stronger even in relaxed driving .
The torque peak is 16 lbs.-ft .
higher , is reached 1200 RPM sooner .
This paradox is made by a sophisticated two-stage manifold found in the standard CL.
As a further bonus , the Type S engine earned the same EPA numbers as the 225 horsepower one : 19/29 .
Honda certainly has a way with engines .
I add that the engine also makes nice sounds .
When pushed , it does attempt to be silent .
Fortunately , the mellow growl at high RPM connotes refined power .
Anyone interested in this type of car will rev the engine from time to time just to hear it burble .
I really wish a manual transmission were available in this car .
It also make the car more fun to drive , at least for me .
This allows you to quickly easily control which gear you are in .
But , at least for me , nothing replace the responsiveness "at one with the car " feeling you get from a good clutch manual shifter .
As I 've already mentioned , this wish has now been granted .
In my review of the 2003 I describe the happy results .
The key difference between this car the BMW is that this car , due to its Accord roots , is front-wheel-drive .
Generally , channeling a great deal of power through the front wheels results in torque steer : the car pulls to one side during hard acceleration .
Remarkably for such a powerful front driver , torque steer is all but .
Under hard acceleration the steering acquired an additional degree of stiffness ( partly an artifact of the way the variable assist is set up ) , but it did tug to one side the other .
Many other car companies study this car to figure out how this was done .
Though weight distribution is far from even , understeer in hard turns is moderate ( though always present ) .
The nicely-tuned suspension , despite tires with only a 215 mm cross-section , sticks very well .
The front-drive layout , matter how well it is tuned , simply does allow the kind of power-on oversteer that readily be had in the BMW.
Otherwise this is a fine chassis .
I felt more cosseted than connected .
For those who really like to make a car dance , I am among these , I'd still recommend finding the additional cash for the BMW.
But most people shopping these cars will find the Acura's chassis more than sufficient for how they typically drive .
But when the car is driven in a spirited manner , steering jumps all over the map , going heavy , then light , then suddenly heavy again , sometimes within the span of a few seconds .
Over most surfaces the CL Type-S rides quite well , especially considering the capabilities of its chassis .
I've noticed this characteristic in some other cars with low-profile tires .
I personally this is an unnecessary trade-off to make to get that final bit of steering response .
I have driven the standard CL , so I only guess at how it compares .
The extra power of the Type S sounds nice , 260 is a big number , but make such a large difference in actual driving .
I urge buyers to drive both CLs make this judgement for themselves .
In the end I was impressed by the CL Type S , but in love with it .
It's a matter of personal preference .
It certainly appeals to me more than the Toyota Solara , its closest competitor in terms of features price , even some more expensive coupes such as the Volvo C70 .
This is a lot of coupe for the money , it has a number of strengths .
But you want the most enjoyable coupe to drive , with other factors being secondary , the BMW, even the less powerful 325Ci , remains a better choice due to its superior steering handling .
It 's even close .
The new Eclipse GT continues the Galant-platform front-wheel drive coupe ' ethos of the Eclipse , but any real sporting edge .
, the current top-end Eclipses are basically family sedans with a body kit .
Platform cars be good - witness the top-end Golf-platform Audi TTs .
The Eclipse however makes too many practicality sacrifices for appearance , too few for performance .
A heavy car for a front-driver , the GT dynos about 50 horses short of the crankshaft power output claimed .
( c .
147 for autos , 160 so for manuals . )
Considering the car weighs over 3100 pounds , the GS' indifferent four-pot mill is hardly worth considering .
Better straight-line performance cornering thrills be obtained from a cooking Mazda MP3 , saving the driver $ 7,000 , gaining in rear seat room .
While arguably resisting understeer better than some older Eclipse front-drivers , the inherent of grip of the FWD drivetrain simply does n't work when married to an overweight platform , soft springing that exacerbates weight transfer away from the drive wheels .
Cornering in the dry on stock rubber similarly brings out the of corner-exit drive , a sinking feeling as applying power has the nose of the car heading for hedges low-flying pedestrians .
while queasy , low-speed four-wheel drift feels fun in a Subaru Impreza , two-wheel drive wheelspin impresses no-one .
So as a performance vehicle , the Eclipse is a lousy effort .
For example : the Civic Type R; the Renault Clio 172 .
The handling setup has its good points .
The car won't tramline noticeably , its soft , reasonably damped suspension is effective at insulating the driver from poor road surfaces .
While the nose of the car will push horribly wide is difficult to place accurately ( even throttle-understeer ) in sub-50 mph cornering , the steering setup gives a strong on-center with considerable stability , the vehicle will track straight with a bare touch , - on the wheel .
In faster corners , the car is pleasant predictable , like a good mid-size family sedan , though the V6 needs attention to stay in the upper reaches of the rev-range meaningful drive is to be made .
Brakes powerful , slightly over-servo'd at low speeds ( like most cars ) , but above 70mph are less good .
Worse , the soft springs encourage the back to pass the front hard braking is attempted from high speeds , especially on mild uphill inclines .
The exhaust system has obviously been tuned to give it its mellow burble , much quieter less Harley-like than a Ford pushrod V6 , just off idle .
The manual transmission's slight notchiness is hidden by a solid , heavily-weighted throw that gives it a "quality " , though one conducive to the fastest upshifts .
Combine the substantial of the shifts with the excellent engine note , solid , meaty steering reasonably powerful brakes , , the overall impression is one of distinctly non-agricultural engineering .
Surfaces are substantially less "plasticy " than the new Celica's , with interesting shapes flowing , well coordinated lines , while being more adventurous than the likes of the new Impreza .
Leather , though exactly top-quality extensively used , is infinitely preferable to the cheap n nasty Mitsubishi cloth .
The Japanese really leave velour to Saab , who know how to make it work .
Interior room , though limited in the back , is decent .
As with many such 3-doors , it 's always better for the front-seaters , bad elsewhere There is a distinct of headroom for any drivers over 6 feet tall ( strange , given the target market ) , but windscreen rake is less aggressive than the atrocious Mustang , even the Volvo V70 .
However the of headroom the large blind spot rear pillars simply worsen the inherently poor all-around visibility .
Reverse parking is quite tough unless seat belts are released , the head is stuck right out of the window .
Visibility down the nose is average sub-average for tall drivers , who will have to keep their seat pretty close to the floor .
you want to avoid side-swiping people , headrests be kept firmly in their stowed position at all times .
It's a heavy car , with handsome looks , an engaging ( over-powerful ) big-hearted engine , a good ( factory option ) premium sound system , a solid at the controls , good long-distance comfort decent luggage space for 2.
you like performance , you'll more prefer the raw uncontrollability of a true modern muscle-car , the precision ability of modern compacts like the RSX Impreza .
The 2002 Acura 3.2CL is an all-around car .
Exterior
One look at this car , this section of the review speaks for itself !
The curves of this car truly makes one drool upon the sight of it .
All in all , the car is very well modeled , especially with the dual exhaust in the back , allowing for a nice symmetry .
The curvature of this car also facilitates the washing of the car , since curves are much easier to get around than corners .
One ask for a more well-equipped interior than the one Acura provides you with .
Because the car is coupe , the driver passenger 's seats are designed to be much more comfortable , than say - a sedan .
This is definitely evidenced by this vehicle .
The driver passenger 's seats are both somewhat deep bucket seats that allow you to sit snugly in the seats being overly comfortable .
However , I have sat in the back , just for a trip .
It the back use a little more leg room , but this of course only depends on the seating of the driver and/or passenger .
Regardless , the seats in the back are rather comfortable .
I have also been told this by my passengers .
Of course , you do intend on having more than 1 passenger in your car at a time , you want to consider the Acura TL - the CL , just with 4 doors , pretty much .
Handling
The handling on the CL is pretty decent .
It drives very smoothly , but a bit heavily .
you're the type who speeds excessively around corners enjoys being thrown into your door armrest around these turns , you consider another vehicle , such as the Lexus IS300 , Subaru Impreza WRX , other competing models .
It does n't exactly have the fastest acceleration of its competing models , but it 's pretty decent , provided the car's weight ( 3485 lbs .
, with Navigation ; , 3470 lbs ) .
All in all , the handling of this car is pretty good , unless you're one with a passion for speed hard cornering .
Features
The 3.2CL is equipped with pretty much everything standard , which I is a big advantage of owning this car .
Navigation/GPS ( optional )
The GPS ( Global Positioning System ) is exceptional on this vehicle .
It is a touch-screen navigation system , which makes it much more convenient than some of the current navigation systems that are on the market .
Many require the use of a small knob-like object to select your choice , which make typing in long addresses a hassle .
However , you do prefer the "joystick " style knob , that is available as well .
The navigation system is pretty concise .
In addition , you select places by their name , it sort the places by distance , so forth .
This is an all-around comprehensive system that covers all aspects of navigation GPS.
The navigation unit/screen also controls the A/C air flow of the car , you want A/C itself on , the speed at which the fan is blown .
This feature is extremely necessary , but it does add a nice touch to the "high-techness " of this car .
Also , you are using the navigation A/C controls at the time , it display the time for you set in a background of stars .
This is a con because there are other points on the car in which it displays time , making the driver , who always races against time , have to make an extra effort to sometimes lean over to the right to check out the time .
This be a safety hazard , for those seconds trying to find the time be seconds spent surveying the road ahead .
Basically , navigation is all a personal choice .
It's just up to the buyer he is willing to shell out approximately $ 2000 for something he she need , depending on amount of travel sense of direction .
Maybe you get it to show off , you are the conceited type : ) .
Safety wise , the navigation system is n't much of a distraction , unless you are constantly looking at inputting things into the screen .
Music
The Bose system in the car ( standard ) is pretty decent .
It delivers a adequate bass , though I it use a little more bass , another woofer .
All in all , however , the sound quality is pretty good , is suitable for most types of music .
A nice feature to its sound system is the 6 disc in-dash CD changer .
This is a very nice convenient feature for you don't have to go to the trunk to change the CDs , like in many other CD equipped vehicles .
Overall , Bose equips the CL with a pretty nice system , though a pinch of bass always be added .
Additional Features
TCS , Traction Control System , This feature keeps your car "straight " sliding spinning after those fast sharp curves .
TCS , others like it , with other cars , always be when purchasing any vehicle .
"Automatic" Seats , This is a very nice feature .
Because this car is a coupe it seats 4 , it is pretty obvious that the front seats have to move forward in order for the rear passengers to get in the vehicle .
However , most of the time , you have to lift up a lever near the bottom of the seat manually push it forward .
the case with the CL.
In the CL , you simply give the lever on the side of the seat a little push , the seatback will fold down , the seat will come forward automatically , giving the rear passengers entry .
Then , after the rear passengers are in , you simply push the seatback back , the seat moves back to its original position .
This function is very nifty , efficient , saves the energy of those who constantly have multiple passengers .
Sequential SportShift , Many current cars now carry this feature , though each has its own name .
It's for the driver who has interest in learning how to drive manual transmission , the one who prefers automatic , but likes the of a manual .
I personally have driven a manual , but people who have say the SportShift is nothing like driving real manual .
It like its just a cool little useless feature that give the driver a bit of power when he she downshifts .
I personally have really had the chance to take a ride in SportShift mode , but when I do , I will post an update !
Sure , the CL has SportShift , but it the manual transmission , desired by those "hardcore " drivers who really like to get the most from a car .
On the right-hand side , there are buttons that control Cruise Control , which are also easy to get to .
Automatic power window , Like many cars nowadays , this car has the Automatic window function , however only on the driver's window .
The passenger window is like any old power window though .
HID ( High Intensity Discharge )/Xenon lights , This , I , is a very considerate of Acura to include standard .
These lights provide a brighter , whiter light that allows the driver to fully see the road while driving in the dark .
Though you know/have known the name of these lights , you know what I'm talking about , when you're driving down the road , seeing all these continuous yellow lights , then one , which is n't yellow , all of a sudden catches your eye .
It has a slight blue tint to it , it really stands out .
I consider Acura very considerate to include these because on many luxury cars , it 's still an option .
Also , it enhances safety for the driver , his her passengers , other drivers on the road .
The specifications conveniences of this car are practically endless .
Please visit Acura at www.acura.com
request a brochure you wish .
through updates , I add what features conveniences I find to be worthy of posted .

In , this car is worth its every penny , because it comes very loaded with everything standard .
you're looking for a combination of performance , luxury , convenience , this is the car for you !
However , you're looking more into performance , are willing to shell out a few more thousands , then I maybe consider Lexus's IS300 .
Competing Models
you are interested in this car , I recommend you also check out its competing models , as I don't really know your tastes interests in vehicles .
Though it looks to be styled towards a younger generation , it still is an awesome car , despite that it be a bit more since everything is standard with the IS300 , like it is with the CL.

Why ?

memory serves , I do that the 1999 Taurus SE at least featured that luxury .

THE DRIVING EXPERIENCE
I will admit that I 'm jaded because of the 2002 Chevy Impala LS.
That car has a lot of energy , pick up , is easy to drive .
The 2002 Taurus SE on the other hand feels like a dog .
Once you get up to speed , the car functions decently , though perfectly .
Passing is a laborious process .
What I say is at least the brakes work well on both highways city roads .
The steering wheel-mounted cruise control is easy to use functions pretty well .
Just a tiny tap of the brakes the cruise immediately shuts off .
So far as gas mileage , to get an average of just over 20 miles per gallon ( despite Ford's claims of higher ) .
As compared to my Impala ( with a much larger engine ) that 's too good .
That larger vehicle gets about 25 miles to the gallon on average .
The Taurus ' smallish engine in reality be more efficient .
So , basically , you get a low energy car with iffy gas mileage .

During its introduction in 1992 as a '93 model , Nissan boasted all sorts of things about the 'new ' Altima .
Some advertisements had the audacity to claim that the 1993 Altima looked like a Jaguar .
Do n't ask me what Jaguar looks like a Nissan Altima , but the person who made that AD knew something I did n't was in need of prescription glasses .
The 1993 Nissan Altima had many flaws , so did the 2nd generation .

Driving Impressions :
The 2002 Nissan Altima comes in 4 trim lines , the 2.5 , the 2.5 S , the 2.5 SL , the 3.5 SE.
The 2.5 , 16 valve , DOHC 4-cylinder is loads more refined over its predecessor .
Hesitation is longer an issue like it was in the 1st 2nd generation models .
My test Car was a 2.5 S , which offered adequate-borderline strong engine performance .
Even with the 4-speed optional automatic transmission ( a 5 speed is standard ) the car moved from the light with fuss whatsoever , with a slight sporting growl from the single , dual tipped , Exhaust pipe .
Torque for this engine comes in at 181 lb-ft at a relatively low 4,000 RPM , so hill climbing passing large trucks are accomplished with much less strain than most family cars that are powered by naturally aspirated powered 4-cylinder engines .
Cruising was also very refined , as quiet as a V6 Accord , but the driver is in a totally hushed environment while cruising at 65 MPH ; given a well built freeway .
Handling is a shade more refined over the 2nd generation models , but do n't to see too much improvement , which is ok , because the Nissan Altima has always been a good car on the twistys .
My test car came with 4 wheel disc brakes with 4 wheel ABS , which assured excellent braking .
This set-up of course was an option , so unless you are willing to pay the cash , you will see the ABS. 4 wheel Discs although are standard equipment .
The Chevrolet Impala is heavier , has more horse power , has a bigger engine , less technology , yet gets better gas mileage , what gives ? ?
All 2002 Nissan Altima 's ride on a 110 " wheelbase , this is around 7 " longer than its predecessor .
The overall length of the car is also longer , measuring around 192" .
The suspension consists of struts coil springs .
Interior Innovation :
The interior while being as refined as many other cars on the market , having as much standard equipment , was quite surprising .
The dash is a little on the cheap-o material side , but did come with a tachometer a optional trip computer .
I actually found the interior of the Hyundai Elantra GT , Kia Sedona to be much more accommodating .
This option came with a convenience package .
For the entire package , which also included AC , cruise control , power everything , remote keyless entry with leather trimmed seats came close to adding on 3 grand to the sticker price .
Speaking of seats , they were both supportive comfortable , the driver seat was 8 way power , the rear seats were of the 60/40 split variety which folded down .
I give you a comment of the ease of doing that , but I did get the chance for conversion .
The interior is very spacious , much larger than the 1st 2nd generation Altima 's .
Exterior Innovation :
The exterior ( all new for 2002 ) is much more sleek/sporty over its predecessor .
The 2002 Nissan Altima is fitted with flush mounted headlamps with see-through effects , are slightly 'cat eyed ' to give a modern appearance .
The same theme is incorporated with the rear lights , only are more triangular .
The 2002 Altima is very 'cab forward , ' a new theme by any means , I the 1986 Ford Taurus was one of the first designs to be 'cab forward . '
From the side of the Altima you will undoubtedly notice that the rear is higher than the front , will notice the sloping roofline .
This car is the sexiest Altima yet !
For 2002 , a base Nissan Altima will run you around $ 15,000 with just standard equipment .
With options however the price rises quite dramatically , the price on my test car was just over $ 20,000 , this was even the 3.5 SE model .
Both the 2.5 liter 4 banger , the V6 are both new for 2002 so it 's way too early to comment on reliability , but anything happens to your car at the manufactures fault , it 's covered under a , 3 year 36,000 bumper to bumper warranty a 5 year 60,000 mile powertrain warranty .

Let me start by saying that I'm a "car person" .
I view driving as a necessary evil , a car is just the thing that I sit in while I am forced to drive .
When it 's time for me to buy a car I figure out my price range , look in Consumer Reports to see which cars in that range get the best ratings for safety reliability , then pick the ones that look good to test drive .
That being said let me tell you that I absolutely love my 2002 Nissan Altima !
I've owned the car for almost three months now , I'm still as excited about it as I was when I drove it off the dealer's lot .
I'm almost embarrassed to admit this , but there are times when I'm in the garage that I have to stop what I'm doing just so that I take a moment to admire my car .
I have even stopped in parking lots said to myself "Wow !
That's a good looking car ! " only to realize that it 's mine !
this car get me excited , it 's definitely worth writing about !
Before I get into the details , please know that I don't know much about engines , suspension systems , brakes .
I can't explain the technical workings of the car .
Luckily , you don't need me for that .
The Nissan Website http ://www.nissanusa.com/vehicles/ModelHomePage/0,9438,20700,00.html
your local dealer give you plenty of technical information ( note that the website now details the 2003 Altima ) .
What I share is my own unique experiences with the car , why I am so thrilled with my choice , the few things that Nissan do to make next year's model even better .
I got my drivers license at 17 , but did n't own a car until I moved to Florida at the tender age of 32 .
At the time , my employer was paying for the car , so I leased .
The Integra had only four cylinders , sometimes while merging onto highways it gave me cause to pray !
I turned in the Integra bought a Honda Accord V6 .
Meanwhile , my husband had been driving "Denty" .
Denty was our 1989 Nissan Maxima .
The car was n't beautiful , but it gave us a moment of engine trouble .
The entire driver's side was smashed .
Denty had some "issues " after the accident , only three doors worked , only one window worked , the air conditioned sometimes got temperamental , the sun visor had been ripped out , but the engine was a finely tuned machine !
When a fender-bender finally "killed " Denty at 180,000 miles , we were completely sold on Nissan as the maker of reliable cars .
We went to look at new Nissans .
The Altima , on the other hand , looked great !
I remember the first time I saw the new Altima .
I loved the silhouette of the car , the shape of the tail lights .
The car looked large comfortable , yet sleek sporty .
The price range on the new Altima , however , was outrageous , with sticker prices starting under $ 17,000 top of the line models selling in the low $ 30,000s .
Quite frankly , I was confused .
Altima offers 3 basic models :
The 2.5 S is the basic car .
It boasts a 175 horse power engine , 4-cylinders , cloth seats , AM/FM/CD Audio system , air conditioning keyless remote .
Consumers seeking to enhance this basic model purchase the "convenience package " which gives them 16" alloy wheels , 8-way power driver's seat adjustments , manual lumbar adjustment , leather-wrapped steering wheel , steering wheel mounted audio trip controls , automatic on/off headlights , a security system , some other minor convenience items .
The SL model is also 4 cylinders , comes standard with all of the items in the convenience package , as well as leather seats , the Homelink Universal Transceiver , a Bose stereo with 6-CD Changer .
Finally there is the 3.5 SE model which features a 3.5 liter V-6 engine .
Strangely , this "top of the line " model does come standard with many of the luxury convenience items included in the SL.
These other features be added on , but that is what drives the price on the 6-cylinder model into the Maxima price range .
I that Nissan designed the packages to be confusing to force consumers to buy features that they don't really want .
It's a great system , it will frustrate many buyers .
I can't defend Nissan's marketing strategy , I will try to provide the details for all of these packages .
Again , the website sales brochure spell out all of the options for you .
Initially , the new car was going to be for my husband .
I had problems with the price of those cars .
Then , the salesman told us that the 4 cylinder Altima had more horse power than my ?
Accord , that pick up be an issue .
All of a sudden we had the opportunity to purchase a great looking , less expensive car that that offered great gas mileage that save me gas money on my long commute to work
I ended up buying a 4-cylinder SL model .
It's lovely - silver paint with black racing stripes , black leather seats , sun roof , leather-wrapped steering wheel .
I love the Bose stereo with 6-CD changer !
I can't do things drive at the same time .
Can't drink coffee , talk on the cell phone , change CDs .
With the 6-cd changer steering wheel mounted radio controls , I have easy access to many music radio choices , the Bose system sounds great ( I even that my singing has improved since I got the Bose , but you'll have to take my word for that ) .
I am very pleased with the way the car handles .
I have problems accelerating onto the highway stopping on short notice .
The car rides smoothly comfortably .
It's fast peppy .
I have heard some complaints about the seat comfort , but I am satisfied .
I am short raise the seat to its highest height to be comfortable , but the driver's side seat has 8 way electronic adjustments , it is easy for me to find a comfortable driving position .
of these have changed my decision to buy the car , but there certainly is room for some small improvements .
1 ) The center console / arm rest : The arm rest is set further back than in most cars which makes the front seats roomier .
There is a button that you pop to push the arm-rest forward so that it actually be used as an arm rest .
I the mechanism is a bit flimsy , the design a little bit silly .
Maybe a taller person actually use the arm rest , but I can't .
In its defense , the arm rest opens into two separate compartments that are useful .
2 ) Power outlet covers : In the deeper section of the center console there is a power outlet .
This is a second outlet ( there is one on the dash ) , it is a nice feature for someone who want to charge a cell-phone but keep it hidden from view .
One thing that I don't like is that the outlet covers are attached , therefore , be easily lost .
I that Nissan attach them so that when the outlet is in use , the covers will stay nearby .
3 ) Sun visors : The Sun visors are poorly placed too close to the rear-view mirror so that the sun shine in from the sides .
There are visor extenders , but they are useable since they hit block the rear-view mirror .
Nissan moved the visors out , away from the center , the visors be more effective in blocking the sun , the extenders be used when needed .
4 ) Location of the hazard light button : The hazard light switch is poorly placed low on the dashboard towards the passenger's side .
we're lucky , we don't need to use our hazards often , at least in dangerous emergency situations .
Here in Florida , however , we often get horrific rain storms that reduce visibility on the highway .
Everyone uses hazards in those storms to help other cars see them .
I want the hazard light button to be in a spot that is easy to reach .
I'd like to see Nissan move the switch higher up closer to the driver's side .
5 ) Cup Holders : The cup holder is in front of the center console .
It is big roomy accommodate two large cups bottles .
I like the overall design , but I that Nissan needs to offer some sort of inset to raise smaller cups up make the holders more user friendly .
6 ) Glasses Holder : The car comes with a built in glasses-holder above the rear-view mirror .
I also had this in the Honda , I really like this feature .
The holder in the Altima is designed with a door that folds down to access the glasses .
When the door is down , it completely blocks the rearview mirror .
Granted , the door does stay down for long , but this is a poor design .
The glasses holder in the Honda rolled open into itself , so that it blocked the driver's view of the road mirrors .
I that Nissan will adopt a similar design for future models .
7 ) Side View Mirrors : The side view mirrors are slightly small taper at the outside .
The car does have fairly significant blind-spots , I that larger mirrors help eliminate the need for the driver to "bend crane " before making lane changes .
8 ) ABS standard : The car did come standard with ABS brakes , , here in Florida it was almost to buy one off the lot with ABS.
In the end , I did buy a car with ABS , in Florida , this is fine .
I lived somewhere where we had ice snow , however , I insist on an ABS braking system , I be irritated to have to pay extra for it as an upgrade .
Now that I've detailed the car's problems , I'll conclude by saying that I am 99.7 % satisfied with my car .
Despite these few "problems" , the car has many small delightful features .
The rearview mirror has a built in dimmer which automatically adjusts so that I'm blinded by headlights from cars behind me .
The trunk is massive came with two cargo nets which allow me to keep things neat organized .
The gas tank cover is attached so that it can't be left behind .
The keyless remote only locks unlocks the car , but also roll down the windows to help air out the car on those hot Florida summer days .
( Too bad it can't also raise the windows when those sudden Florida summer rain storms hit ! )
The headlights have auto-off which I like , but I like even more that they have an "auto" setting that senses when there is enough light puts the headlights on off automatically .
I'm getting great gas mileage !
On the highway I get over 31 mpg , overall I'm averaging over 28 mpg ( that's with a commute that is about a 50/50 mix of highway local driving ) .
I'll enjoy driving , but I do comfortable safe in my car .
It looks great , it performs wonderfully !
I drive two hours a day to from work , the car is a joy .
Coming from me , that is a huge endorsement !
Now that the Xterra has been for sale a few years , Nissan has decided to freshen up the appearance to more closely mimic the stand-out styling of the Frontier pickup .
The Xterra has always boasted rugged , chunky exterior styling , but the front end treatment the edgy quality of the rest of the car .
Now a more aggressive looking front fascia adorns the Xterra complete with round , almost oval shaped headlights , a honeycomb type grille .
The 2002 Xterra is much more in keeping with how one an off-road capable SUV to look .
The interior has a sportier look as well ; separate round , backlit gauges a slightly more stylish center dash give the Xterra's interior a youthful look .
This a welcome addition as the normally aspirated V6 in the Xterra Frontier makes a barely adequate 170 hp .
The supercharged engine in the Xterra is a first in its class .
The main advantage the Xterra has over its competition is size .
Only the Hyundai Santa Fe comes close in terms of interior volume overall size .
Physically , the Xterra is more similar to mid-size SUVs like the Toyota Highlander 4 Runner than any compact SUV.
Cargo room in the Xterra is plentiful , fold the split rear seats down there is even more room .
Rear seats fold down easily , but do fold all the way flat , a feature most other vehicles in this class have .
you still can't fit all your gear inside , the Xterra's sizable roof rack accommodate almost anything .
The Xterra purpose built for exterior mounted , aftermarket travel containers .
With the rear seats folded up , there is more than adequate room for adult passengers .
Although there is plenty of leg room , there to be precious little foot space .
It's a great , but an unintended consequence is that rear seat passengers get their feet to slide under the front seats .
Therefore the back seat feels more cramped than it really is .
Front rear seats are average in comfort , many Nissan cars truck have comfortable pleasant seating positions , this is true of the Xterra as well .
Rear seats do recline , but to be in a permanent partial reclining position .
Some passengers like this , others it felt odd .
The Xterra also has the competition beat when it comes to towing capacity .
With a towing capacity of 3500 lbs. , the SE S/C Xterra out-tow virtually every vehicle in its class with the exception of the Jeep Liberty .
In many cases the Xterra is able to handle from 1500 to 2800 lbs more than other SUVs like the Ford Escape Hyundai Santa Fe .
you have 3500 lbs towing capacity the ability to traverse rugged terrain , the Nissan Xterra has you covered .
But you want a decent handling , drivable family vehicle with a civilized ride , then scratch the Xterra off your shopping list .
The Xterra is a body-on-frame vehicle , in short , it is a truck .
Chevrolet's Tahoe Suburban utilize body-on-frame construction the ride on those vehicles is actually quite pleasant .
Even the smallest of pot-hole uneven pavement upset the Xterra's ride .
This truck squirms shakes shimmies like nobody's business .
This is true at both low speeds higher speeds .
A 15mph trip down an alley ( in less than average condition ) resulted in so much teeth clattering shake I almost returned home to get another car .
"Nobody do the Shake ; Like I do .
Nobody do the boogaloo ; Like I do ; " that is exactly what Xterra is capable of , it shake shimmy bump jostle like other car I know .
Even the lowly Suzuki Vitara feels a tad bit more stable .
When unoccupied ,the passenger seat-back vibrates back forth terribly .
Rough roads are cause for concern as the Xterra often felt like it was "dog-tracking " driving slightly sideways whenever uneven pavement large dips were encountered .
I often felt like I was in danger due to the fact that the Xterra rarely respond the way I .
On straight , smooth roads the Xterra has a tendency to wander .
Constant input to the steering wheel is needed to keep this truck on the straight narrow .
The only plus in the handling department is the Xterra's relatively small turning radius , this proved helpful in tight parking lots garages .
Although the 210 hp is a welcome addition to the Xterra , the vehicle does n't to be able to effectively handle that much power .
During hard acceleration , the Xterra lift twist end up pointed in some direction I intended .
Acceleration is better than average , but the brute force from a 3.3L , supercharged V6 .
The 6 does take a few seconds to catch its breath , but once the supercharger is really pumping , there is a noticeable surge forward that only to grow stronger as the revs climb higher .
Maximum output is at 4800 RPM.
Even with the 210 hp , the S/C Xterra still use a few more ponies , even the normally aspirated Altima 3.5 makes 30 more hp than the supercharged Xterra .
Still , the supercharged Xterra offers more power than vehicles such as the Mazda Tribute V6 , Hyundai Santa Fe V6 , Toyota RAV which is only available as a 4-cylinder .
The much pricier Toyota Highlander with a V6 makes only 10 more hp but cost thousands more when ordered with a few basic options .
Bringing the Xterra to stop is drama-free in most cases , but in panic stop situations , the Xterra nose-dives terribly .
In heavy traffic , low speed short-stops are common .
In this situation , the Xterra's brakes touchy the vehicle rocks back forth once it comes to a full stop .
I understand it on the $ 18,000 4-cylinder version , but on the supercharged 4x4 .
Finally , due to the Xterra's weight ( 4229 lbs . ) its thirsty supercharged engine , fuel mileage is a miserable 15 mpg city / 18 mpg highway .
This puts the S/C Xterra in league with a bigger V8 powered SUV like the Chevy Tahoe which makes 75 more horsepower .
you value fuel economy , opt for the Xterra XE with the 2.4L engine .
I used a half tank of gas in just three days of normal commute driving .
Yes the freeways in Los Angeles are crowded , but my office is 8 miles away from my home .
Add a few side trips to the store lunch that still does equal a half tank of fuel gone .
Overall , the 2002 Nissan Xterra XE S/C is a mixed bag , but the bottom line is that I simply recommend this car .
Granted , it is a stellar off-road performer tow more weight than almost all others in its class , plus holds a bunch of cargo inside on the hefty roof rack .
But the shortcomings are just too much to overcome .
A vehicle like the Land Rover Freelander has a lot of aspects to it as well , but at the end of the day , it is a car that most people live with enjoy .
Car based SUVs offer superior comfort drivability , but the Xterra's truck like qualities , both good bad .
retail pricing on the Xterra to start at $ 18,000 run all the way up to $ 27,000 for a 4x4 SE supercharged V6 .
Anyone looking to spend $ 27,000 more on an SUV seriously consider the Nissan Pathfinder , Mazda Tribute , Toyota Highlander , Chevy Tahoe .
Unless you're running the Paris , Dakar rally , skip the Xterra .

For the 2002 model year the Ford Taurus Sedan comes available in a multitude of trim lines that include the base LX , the SE , SES (tester ) SEL.
The wagon is offered in SE SEL trim . 2 powerplants are also available .
Transmissions include a standard , clunky , unrefined , 4-speed automatic .
My tester ' Taurus SES Deluxe ' had the optional 3.0 DOHC Duratec engine ( almost a $ 900 option ) .
Off-the-line acceleration with the Duratec V6 is fair , but the DOHC Duratec lackadaisical compared to the 3.0 V6 in the 2002 Accord totally anemic compared to the 3.5 V6 in the Nissan Altima .
On take-off the Duratec almost strains to get this 3,500lb vehicle up to speed .
Do n't get me wrong , the car is slow by any means , it just has to work much harder to get up to speed than the competition .
The 4-speed fully automatic transmission coupled to this engine only makes accelerating problems worse .
The transmission , while loads refined over the AXOD tranny equipped in the 1986-1995 Tauruses still the precise shifting associated with cars like the Camry even the Chevy Impala .
Clunky automatic shifting between 1st gear 2nd is still noticeable , shifting too soon ( high gear around 30 MPH)is still annoying , as the car has virtually power at this speed in high gear , so automatic down-shifting up-shifting while driving through town is almost inevitable you do n't manually take it out of overdrive .
Handling in the 2002 Taurus is good , however like most family cars on the twistys , this car tends to lean which be quite prevalent around bends at high speeds .
Cruising in this relatively large family sedan is exactly another downfall for the Taurus SES but it 's also an attribute worth boasting about .
Since it 's redesign in 2000 , the Ford Taurus to take bumps much easier , rattles are kept to a minimum ; jolts are also much easier on the spine .
I remember driving the 96-1999 Tauruses believing how many rattles unexpected jolts be present on bumpy surfaces .
There is a major improvement vs. the last generation in this dept .
Hills are taken well .
Surprisingly the Duratec V6 enables this heavy weight to tackle up to 7 % grades having to automatically down-shift to maintain 75 MPH , even gain speed up these sorts of inclines given good 'right foot power , ' again the need for the automatic to down-shift .
Braking in the 2002 Taurus SES deluxe is average-good .
The EPA is 20/27 which is lower than the larger , less sophisticated 3.8 OHV engined Chevrolet Impala .

Storage is also good .
Tons of room for a family of 5s ' weeks worth of groceries .

The of the dual exhaust system on the Duratec equipped models just makes it that much harder for this car to look sporty .

I 'm rolling west out of Houston along I-10 in a riot of color .
Carpets of bluebonnets line the roadsides , as yet unsullied by the inevitable amateur photographers those families in their finery .
Here there I spot clumps clusters of primrose in pale pink evening gowns ; brilliant yellow coreopsis purple henbit lurk in the median as embarrassed to pit their tiny flowers against the showy 'bonnets .
In the shade of an overgrown fencerow I catch glimpses of the winy tones of a stand of claret cups ; simple fuchsia heads like wineglasses waving on slender stems ; over yonder a prickly phalanx of California poppies has invaded from a nearby pasture , long , fuzzy dark green stems crowned by delicate white petals around a lotus-like core .
On hillside meadow alike , the Indian paintbrush nod wisely , shafts of color ranging from startling orange to fire-engine red waving contentedly in the humid breeze .
Overhead a squadron of turkey buzzards circles lazily above some carrion buried in the tall grass , flying in a perfect missing-man formation .
As for me , I 'm fighting a well-nigh uncontrollable urge to roar off the pavement , spraying mud left right sending battalions of Ladybird Johnson 's legacy to their heavenly reward .
As I resist the urge , I keep wondering : " Does Nissan install a testosterone dispenser as standard equipment in the Xterra ? "
Is this the Ultimate Boy Toy ?
Immediately on seeing your first Xterra you know that every inch of the vehicle breathes essence of (young ) male , from the buffed , muscular body to the simple lines of the manly interior .
The standard roof rack as well be a backwards-billed baseball cap ; that strange flat spot on the rear hatch is a precise analog for the perfect circle imprinted on ten million teenage boys ' wallets .
There 's question at all that Nissan aimed this vehicle , with laser targeting , at a youthful male market .
Unlike Honda Toyota (among others ) whose smallest SUVs ride on a car platform , Nissan has built the Xterra around the frame of its Frontier pickup .
It 's a meaty , beaty , big bouncy bruiser of an SUV, positioned squarely to take over the Jeep Wrangler market from the sixteen-to-twenty-six age group .
The brutish good looks of the Xterra - tall slender , with a two-step roofline what looks like an over-engineered roof rack - serve it well in that market .
The pot 's sweetened by a passel of wild colors - who among us has yet to see a canary yellow model on the streets ?
- a standard 100-watt stereo with CD , tinted windows , ABS , anti-skid plates ; also aimed to please .
Throw in the optional first aid kit ( it screams , "Xtreme Sportsman Here ! " ) , 300-watt six-disc in-dash CD changer , - the piece de resistance - the new-this-year 210-hp turbocharged V6 engine , the teenage boy inside us will be in seventh heaven !
for Everybody ?
The very features that make the Xterra boy-bait place serious limits on its popularity outside the target audience .
With the disappearance of station wagons the waning popularity of minivans , the SUV has become the new family cruiser for Sunday afternoon rides in the country .
Families , however , tend to like their creature comforts : car-seat latches , two cupholders for every seat , DVD players that drop from the ceiling , six-way adjustable chairs , -- above all - a cushiony ride .
The Xterra is definitely aimed at this crowd , its creature comforts its ride .
Have you tried the Toyota Highlander yet ?
' Cause the Xterra 's what you 're looking for !
The Driving Experience
I put about 450 miles on a four-wheel drive Xterra XE ( the base trim level ) , with the stock four-speed automatic 2.4-liter ( 140-hp ) 4-cylinder power plant .
anybody cares , it was silver .
Again , anybody cares , I got about 18MPG for mainly highway driving ...
I engaged the shift-on-the-fly 4WD only for a trip down my driveway , though I have used it a few times in downtown Houston 's interminable road construction .
Handling is intended to be fun - it is , as long as you 're going fairly slowly .
There 's a reason all Nissan 's commercials show the Xterra grinding up the countryside of rockin' down the highway .
The Xterra turns on a relative dime at low speed , which be a blessing in true off-road situations ( on Milam in downtown Houston ) .
At higher speeds , the steering has a tendency to wander on smooth roads , especially the surface is a tad slick ; its high profile gives the vehicle just a hint of tippiness through high-speed turns .
The ride ... what you say about the ride ... truck-like ?
bouncy ?
unlike a Kenmore washing machine with an unbalanced load ?
Be prepared to buckle up firmly , for this truck put you through the wringer on rough pavement .
The little four-banger had great difficulty shoving around the Xterra 's 4300-pound carcass , with lousy acceleration a great deal of noise .
The automatic transmission spent about as much time hunting for the proper gear as it did performing quietly .
This is definitely the proper configuration for a truck this size weight - purchasers are well advised to at least spring for the 170-horse V6 ( which is also rumored to be gutless ) the turbo version .
The driving position is high - heck , everything is high , including the cargo bed , which hits this 5'11 " guy right at Gluteus maximus level ( I 'd hate to have to load anything heavy into an Xterra ) .
My rental came equipped with step bars lots of grab handles to help the less nimble clamber aboard .
In a bit of inspired styling ( form over function , I 'spect ) , the rear door handles are mounted high on the door behind the window - let 's see your average six-year-old operate those !
Critter Comforts Car-Driver Interface
The stock six-speaker AM/FM/CD player ( tape ) puts out above-average sound , but the climate-control system just a little overwhelmed at times - summer 's still a long way off !
Nissan has gone all-out to give the cockpit a kicky look , including retro-looking climate-control knobs ( straight off a 1930s gas stove ) bizarre little three-LED indicator lights .
The triple-headed instrument panel ( derivative of the PT Cruiser you ask me ) has good sight lines so you notice that Nissan - being different again - uses an italic typeface on the gauges .
The brake release , though , is at the right side of the steering wheel .
Why ? Do n't ask me ...
Headroom is great all around , plus the cargo area is advertised as the largest in its class - I it .
The cargo area comes with a tonneau cover for hiding the contents ; it pretty flimsy rather awkward to use .
Part of the reason the rear sill is so high is a full-size spare mounted beneath the frame ( at least Nissan does n't stick you with a rolling donut ) .
There are numerous cubbyholes - several of useless size placement - on the insides of the doors around the console , plus a large locking glove compartment .
A single power port graces the dashboard - mine did n't work , by the way - there 's a second inside a generous console compartment .
Two cupholders are molded into the console , their removable rubber boots make 'em large enough for a 1-litre bottle .
Also standard on all models are power windows locks ( another irritant - keyhole on the passenger door ) , remote keyless entry , cruise control .
Overall
This baby is in way intended to compete with luxury SUVs like the Lexus / BMW / Mercedes crowd ; is it a competitor for the small-family dollar with the likes of the CRV / RAV4 / VUE.
Given the weight of the truck , it amazes me that Nissan even offer a four , especially when competing head-to-head with the peppy 3.7L V6 in the Jeep Liberty .
Nissan as a company has a good reputation for reliability ; in its third model year the Xterra also to be holding up well .
I note that my rental - which was delivered with 10K miles on the clock - had already had a couple of plastic parts break , though , the dashboard power port was on the fritz .
Many of the plastic parts pretty cheesy .
Still , Datsun / Nissan has put out durable , long-lasting trucks for decades .
Recommendations
The washing-machine ride amenity-poor interior are a dead giveaway that SUV is n't intended for hauling around groceries ; it 's built to carry mountain bikes snowboards get them where they be used .
You get into a base-level model Xterra on the cheap , though getting 4WD enough power to get out of your own way requires significantly more outlay of cash .
For the class of cars it represents , the stock 4WD is at best average .
That gutless four-cylinder engine automatic transmission pairing are downers , particularly given the unimpressive gas mileage for the four .
Upgrading to the stock V6 is marginally better , though reviewers are waxing rapturous over the of the V6 turbo .
The ride is awful , but that 's the hallmark of a truck-based SUV.
It 's better suited to hauling - in the cargo bay on a trailer - than it is to elegance .
Based on my driving experience the of the V6 , I rate the Xterra a provisional four stars .
Be forewarned , though , that your driving experience be diminished by that doggy four-cylinder engine , so the four-cylinder version only gets three .
Fair enough ?
The folks at Nissan really be in the business of shooting themselves in the foot .
Why do I say that ?
Surely because they are starting to manufacture cars that are worth buying : Nissan vehicles across the board have received more power , feature content , even attitude .
No, where they to make things difficult is by making cars that are so good , you 'd twice before buying another more expensive Nissan model .
Take the Xterra , for instance .
True , it 's a different SUV compared to the Pathfinder , but until its introduction , the Pathfinder was the only SUV option buyers had .
I n't be surprised the Xterra had siphoned off a few Pathfinder sales .
Enter the new Altima .
Up until now , Nissan had remodeled the Altima into oblivion , making it a ho-hum choice .
Definitely worlds beneath the new Maxima .
I 'll tell you right off the bat : I really liked the Altima .
So much so I 'd be hard-pressed to shell out the extra dough for a Maxima .
Here are my impressions ...
EXTERIOR : 8
Let 's just say this car 's new look is a head shoulders improvement over the previous iteration .
Big , too ... the wheelbase is 7.1 inches longer , its overall length bumped up by 5.7 inches .
The body is 1.3 inches wider with wider tracks front rear for better stability .
Height was increased by 2 inches for more cabin space .
Plenty of sound insulation has been added to this vehicle , too .
The overall appearance of the new Altima strikes the observer in a completely different way than the old one did .
" Me too " quasi-luxury styling be seen in the old model , whereas this model looks like it actually make good on such a promise .
only is the new Altima about as large as the Passat , but it looks just as upscale you look at it from the right angle .
IT looks well put-together solid all around .
...
I 'm particularly fond of the clear tail lights that just to make sense on this body .
So , with all these compliments why a 9 10 rating ?
This part is harder , less tangible , all a matter of personal preference .
From some angles , the Altima a little porky-looking rather than muscular ... the bubble-butt in the rear comes to mind .
While the car is much more of a looker than the old model , it did n't really speak to me .
INTERIOR : 9
I 've already made references to interior space , when you sit in the car , you 'll see what I mean .
The trunk is large , too , with around 15.6 cubic feet inside .
Let 's start off with the most important stuff ...
I loved the eight-speaker Bose audio system !
Large well-placed controls made it easy to use , the in-dash six-CD changer was a real nice touch .
The steering wheel controls were a nice perk , though I 've read they are illuminated at night , which is just silly .
After a while though , I had learned how to operate them looking down .
Overall sound is awesome , with crisp highs punchy lows sandwiching perfectly balanced mid-ranges .
Nissan really knows what they are doing when it comes to stereos .
It 's even better than the 10-speaker Monsoon stereo I so openly praised in the VW Jetta .
That says a lot .
As for interior quality , a few cost-cutting cues be noted , such as the less-than-substantial to the switchgear , wimpy cupholders .
The leather seats are nice , but wo n't bring thoughts of Lexus to mind .
The Altima use some more .
The gauge cluster is easy to read , looks like it belongs on a more expensive car .
All the controls are well-placed , intuitive , within reach .
Both Car Driver as well as Edmunds.com
have complained about sun glare coming from the windshield , which I did n't notice , even after searching for it .
There are plenty of nooks crannies to store your stuff in .
The 60/40 split-folding rear seat increases cargo carrying capacity , but you neeed to go around the back to do it .
The hinges on the trunk are of the luggage smushing variety , as opposed to the hydraulic hinges found on the VW Jetta Honda Accord .
ENGINE : 8
The Altima comes with two engine flavors : the base is a 2.5-liter DOHC 16-valve four-cylinder that churns out 175 hp 181 lb-ft of torque .
The second , more enticing flavor is the on the 3.5SE model .
It uses the same 3.5L V6 as the Maxima , though toned down a bit , producing 240 horsepower 246 lb-ft of torque .
I drove the latter of these two choices , accompanied by a manual transmission .
The engine itself is a gem , revving very smoothly producing a satisfying growl when pushed .
Acceleration has been clocked at 6.3 seconds 0-60 , you definitely this urgency off the line .
Oh , did a mention that this car comes with a 20 gallon gas tank has pretty decent gas mileage even when driven hard ( like I did ) ?
My complaint is with the friggin' manual shifter .
Throws are longer than I like , it 's easy to tell when you 've actually engaged the desired gear .
This is the first car in which I prefer an automatic transmission .
RIDE : 9
With a multi-link suspension taken from the Infiniti Q45 , this car rides very comfortably .
Outside sounds are well-muted , road irregularities are well-dampened .
It serves well in a family hauler enthusiast setting .
What more you ask for than that ?
HANDLING : 7
The Altima impressed me here .
Body roll is hardly evident , braking is equally strong ( though I felt the brake pedal to be slightly spongy on the way up - a new car thing ) .
My usual " cloverleaf test " was handled with poise confidence .
Overall , this car is a hoot to drive , yet has the balance of a car with a totally different purpose , like taking the kids to school .
Although the Altima performs admirably in the hard corners is fun to drive , it has its drawbacks .
All of the " sport " that the car promises practically goes out the window .
Put simply , this steering feels like it belongs on a mini-van .
It has real weight to it , as the assisted steering is assisting too much .
Understand what I mean here ?
Anyway , it was pretty disappointing is the only reason why I did n't give the handling over a seven .
SAFETY : ?
The model I drove was equipped with the " ABS/Airbag Package" , which included ABS , dual front side airbags , as well as front rear head curtain airbags .
This is all well good , though I ca n't rate this car just yet until crash tests have been performed .
I 'll change my rating as soon as the tests are done .
The 2000-2001 Altima scored an " Acceptable " rating by the IIHS in its offset tests , received 4 out of 5 stars for driver 5 out of 5 stars for passenger frontal crashes .
Side impact ratings were lower at 3 out of 5 stars for both front rear occupants by the NHTSA .
RELIABILITY : ?
While Nissan usually makes well-assembled cars , this is an introductory year for the Altima .
The engine is fortunately all-new since it was merely taken from the Maxima modified , rather than drawn from the ground up .
Other than that , this is a new car , which means a few problems come up .
Hey , it happens to everyone even the folks at Honda ( read : Honda Odyssey ) .
The Altima represents an excellent bang-for-the-buck value .
No, let me rephrase that ...
Nissan has really taken the phrase "affordable luxury " to a whole new plane be commended for it .
This car seriously be sold for a price in the upper twenties , an argument be made to sell it for more .
It essentially comes with all the stuff the Maxima does , but costs less ... here is where I make the joke ( sort of ) that Nissan have shot themselves in the foot by making such a value-packed yet excellent vehicle ( I had to add "yet excellent " because sometimes "value-packed " is hardly complimentary ) .
My car also had the leather trim , automatic climate control , Bose stereo system , heated seats/mirrors , more .
All for around $ 26,000 .
That 's loaded to the gills , folks .
This car be found nicely equipped in the lower twenties .
( Sound like a commercial ? )
The jury is still out on the Altima will have a good resale value , but has always been around average slightly above so .
Regardless , this car stacks up well against its competitors , such as the Accord , Camry , Jetta .
In fact , I 'd say it is the best value out of all of those listed .
Still , bear in mind this is a brand-new car you want to hold off on budget-minded buying for now , as dealers wo n't be able to resist charging sticker above sticker until demand goes down .
VERDICT : NISSAN MAKES GOOD ON ITS " AFFORDABLE LUXURY " PROMISE
Out of the ashes from this totally new redesign has come a mid-size car that has sprung from middle-of-the-pack to the front runners .
Is it perfect ?
Well , obviously .
There 's a few flaws that Nissan definitely look at ... the steering manual shifter come to mind .
But I still come back to my original question : where does this leave Maxima buyers ?
For the money , I 'd actually buy this car over the Maxima .
Nissan hopes you see enough of a difference between the two cars by increasing the horsepower rating on the Maxima , but I see right through their desperate move .
Outside the increased horsepower , better steering , a few nicer quality touches , little separates the Maxima from the Altima... for several thousand bucks , of course .

When ordered with the 5-speed , the Focus quite powerful , second gear tire chirps are easy to come by .
When shifting hard , there is noticeable torque-steer , but it does dangerous as with other front wheel drive cars such as the SAAB 9-3 .
During normal driving , torque-steer is noticeable at all .
Overall , the Focus ZX5 is a very competent compact car .
While most performance enthusiast eagerly await the pavement scorching SVT Focus , many want the practicality of a sedan , with the increased cargo room of a hatchback .
The ZX5 is a compromise in many ways , yet a stint behind the wheel makes one realize how little is actually sacrificed .
The ZX5 offers nothing more less than other Focus ' offer ; youthful styling , peppy performance , superb handling , room for 5 adults , lots of convenience features , a price well below $ 20,000 .
Essentially the Focus ZX5 is roomier than it looks , sportier than it has to be , The Who said it best , "I'd call that a bargain; "
