The SVT ?s most difference is its powertrain .
Although the engine is larger , variable valve timing is employed to boost horsepower from 130@5300 RPM to 170@7000 .
Torque gets a smaller boost , from 135@4500 to 145@5500 .
These numbers tell much of the engine ?s
story : you ?re going to have to work it to extract any power , , with the redline at 7200 RPM , you ?re going to have to shift soon after hitting the power peak , dropping you back to about 150 horses .
Power delivery is very linear , with obvious surges dips due to alterations in the intake valve timing .
During my test drive the engine felt weak , but it felt all that powerful .
Generally it makes just enough power to be entertaining .

The SVT includes a unique six-speed manual transmission .
( An automatic is available . )
Unique in general in that these six speeds are obtained by using two final drive ratios .
I don ?t quite understand how this works , but it does .

One of Newton 's laws of motion states ( paraphrased ) that a body in motion tends to remain in motion .
The principle under discussion is commonly known as inertia .
Inertia , we all know , is merely a physical phenomenon , it 's also a phenomenon that exerts influence over such varied arenas as the stock market personal relationships -- how many couples do you know , for instance , that stay together far too long because the act of breaking up takes too much energy ?
Inertia occurs in the marketplace , of that we be certain .
I grew up in an unusual family : my parents drove Pontiacs , Fords , Chevvies , Dodges , Chryslers , Oldsmobiles , Studebakers , Ramblers ... you name it , they drove it some time in the fifties , sixties , seventies .
America 's Most Popular Car ? ! ?
Advertisements tell us that the Ford Taurus is America 's most popular car .
Note , however , that you always tell when an advertising man is lying because his lips are moving ... What is true is that the Taurus is one of the most popular cars ever sold in this country ; ( you lump Mercury Sable in with the Taurus ) there are as many of them on the road as there are of any other vehicle .
More importantly , the Taurus -- an ugly , melted-looking critter at its birth -- marked Ford 's re-emergence as a power in the mid-sized car market after more than a decade of shoddy quality , ill-advised experimentation , simple ignorance of consumer trends .
Finally , America was making a car that was competitive against Japanese imports , so much so that it actually began making inroads into that import market .
Hooray for American ingenuity engineering !
As such , the Taurus developed a near-cult following ; giving a new generation a vehicle on which to lavish the family 's Ford addiction .
Suddenly you ached to drive a stylish , dependable car , you did n't have to hide the Toyota from Dad watch Uncle Stan sneer at the Honda .
so the Taurus ( its "name-plate twin " the Mercury Sable ) became Ford 's " comeback kid . "
Three cheers for Henry , Edsel , the rest of the Fords !
Fast Forward to 2002
I 've driven them through snow , in the baking desert sun , at the beach , on winding mountain roads .
While I 've been tempted to buy a Taurus ( frankly , it 's larger than I need ) , I 've been unimpressed by the car , .
This is a vehicle that 's always to be a solid , dependable -- somewhat boring -- performer ; but then I 'd reviewed one for Epinions , .
So here 's my chance , after having looked at a 2002 Taurus with a critical eye :
The Car
My ever-faithful suppliers at Enterprise rented me a 2002 Taurus SE model , a four-door , with the stock V6 Vulcan engine a four-speed automatic transmission .
This particular model has a " convertible " front seat , which is a bench seat with a center panel that unfolds into a console and/or armrest to create the illusion of bucket seats .
The vehicle came equipped with dual airbags , power doors/windows/mirrors , cloth seats , AM/FM/Cassette , tilt wheel , cruise control , intermittent wipers , styled aluminum wheels , AC.
I picked it up with about 5500 miles on the clock ; I turned it back in with just over 6000 - five days 500+ miles .
About 400 miles were highway driving , the rest on city streets freeways in the Austin Houston areas .
Weather was mostly dry , though my return to Austin encountered some moderate showers .
Styling Notes
For those interested in such things , the vehicle was a metallic charcoal gray with a multi-shade gray interior .
That particular combination is quite popular ; one night in my hotel parking garage I had to choose among the Taurus , a Mustang , a Contour all in that color combination .
I stayed with the Taurus 'cause I did n't have keys for the Mustang .
This model was restyled by Ford with the 2000 model year .
Speaking from memory , earlier models were far more dependent upon the oval motif , still retained some of the original version 's melted external contours .
The restyling possesses slightly more angularity than the old version , with sharper slope breaks at the base of the rear window on the trunk line .
Blocks of foam-filled "naugahyde " tend to fight for supremacy with contoured plastic panels in the dash on the doors .
The seating arrangements do to have changed from earlier models ; the instrument panel dashboard layouts are little changed , at all .
Driver-Car Interface
The Taurus handles moderately well for a mid-sized family sedan ; cornering is responsive with crispness poor control .
The driver has a good connection to the road when compared to larger vehicles such as the Lincoln Continental , but is more isolated than when driving most Japanese sedans ( Mitsubishi Galant , Toyota Camry ) .
Braking tends to a bit mushy at highway speeds .
The stock 155-hp Vulcan V6 possesses adequate reserve power at highway speeds , but is noticeably weak on acceleration from a standing start ( this is the least powerful of three available V6 engines ) .
I averaged about 21.5 MPG with this engine ( note : mostly highway driving ) .
The four-speed overdrive transmission shifts smoothly responsively for the most part .
In this model , the shifter is mounted to the steering column .
The cockpit is laid out comfortably , with most controls easily accessible few ( any ) surprises .
The cruise control buttons are on the face of the steering wheel ; on-off on the left accelerate/coast/resume on the right .
The driver 's seat in this configuration has a seat-back tilt adjustment forward/backward adjustment , both manual .
There is lumbar adjustment .
There are sturdy anchor-points for two child car seats on the car 's rear deck .
There is a single small , rather strangely-shaped glove compartment the ubiquitous door-side map pockets .
Ford provides a single cubby in the dashboard for front-seat passengers .
Rear-seat passengers have pockets on the seatbacks suitable for stowing a magazine little else .
There are two power ports , both in front ( one doubles as a cigarette lighter ) .
The rearseat passengers have two flip-out cupholders ; front seat passengers have two cupholders molded into the underside of the fold-up seatbottom .
This latter surface also has minimal storage for cassettes a few coins ; it dumps its contents when inverted ( surprise there ) to form a seat cushion .
The only locking space in the cabin is the glove compartment .
Note , that when the seat is in "bench " configuration , there are cup holders little storage ( moot , anyway , since the room be rather limited ) .
The circumference is notched for a cargo net , though there was in the rental vehicle ( it be standard have "disappeared " ) .
The lid opens with a key a dash-mounted remote ; there is also an emergency latch for opening from the inside .
The rear seats do fold down , is there any sort of "pass-through " for carrying long cargo ; a disappointing of a feature available in other trim lines on competing models .
Engine noise is somewhat intrusive , partially because this particular engine to be rather "grumbly . "
Road noise is minimal unless the road surface is coarse , but wind noise is also rather pronounced .
Highs Lows
Positives : the Accelerator Pedal
+/SYM good rear-seat room
+/SYM large trunk capacity
+/SYM fuel economy
Mmmmm , Maybe : The Neutral Zone
= engine acceleration
= road handling braking
= an average climate-control system
= road noise wind noise
Negatives : the Brake Pedal
- fold-down rear seat
- amateurish-looking design to interior components , especially the " console "
- cheesy stock sound system
- poor quality control ( see below )
- that stupid front-seat console of interior storage .
On Quality
One of the reasons many US buyers deserted American carmakers in the seventies early eighties was the perception of poor quality in US cars .
In only four day 's exposure , I noted the following defects :
- The ignition key was hard to turn more than once to release from the "START " position -- this left the starter motor engaged until I manually released the key .
- At least one body seam had variable width along its length , a definite no-no ( one panel is therefore misaligned )
- Flashing ( excess plastic from the molding process ) had been trimmed off the interior of the trunk , especially in the clips for the cargo net .
- The fuel gage rise above 7/8 even when filled .

As you know , large SUVs have been stirring up a lot of controversy lately that buyers know about before purchasing .
I recently purchased a new car , but an SUV first did a lot of research into them promptly changed my mind .
Of course , unless you have $ 40,000+ to spend on one , you are going to have a high car payment .
Which is obvious , most consumers this .
But did you budget the high fuel cost as well ?
A Lincoln Navigator weights between 5,424 to 5,774 pounds .
Because of this , it has a V8 engine .
Meaning that a Navigator driver is paying on average 3 to 4 times more for gas that a car driver .
This will add somewhere between $ 100 to $ 250 a month to your car payment .
Okay , gas is cheap now;..but for how long ?
When it goes back up , typically the resale value on the Navigator other large SUVs goes down considerably , one wants something that is going to use that much gas when the cost is unsteady .
That's a lot of money to lose .
Because the Navigator is big heavy , the driver gets into an accident , it will cause a lot of property damage injuries that your insurance company will have to pay for .
On top of that , there is a big risk that the drivers drivers family of the smaller cars will sue you .
Which means you and/or your insurance company be out a lot of money .
They plan for this by charging a lot higher premium on SUVs than normal size cars .
This vary with no-fault states .
You get a quote from your insurance company first .
Now , on average , the Navigator puts out over 3 times the carbon dioxide of a normal sized car .
This really angers people who care about the environment causes them to do things to protest against this .
Where they'll put bumper stickers on your SUV say things like your changing the climate you don't care about the air .

At 170 bhp , the new SVT Zetec engine was the most advanced four-cylinder engine ever produced .
Its variable intake manifold complimented well with the variable cam timing .
With 145lb-ft of torque 80 % of that @ 2500rpm , torque-steer was still non-existent .
The best feature in this car was its handling - it is a 1/4mile car .
Its revised suspension consisting of higher spring rates , larger stabilizers 1/2 " lowered stance , made this car corner like it was on a slot-car track .
I was quite aware of this when after just 4500 km of daily driving , I had finally performed the official "breaking-in " at a local road track .

I carried most of my speed through the corners having to brake .
Though once I reached the straightaways , I had to say goodbye to all the distanced gained from the corners , watching helplessly as supercharged Mustangs passed me by .

PT Cruisers are cute looking little cars .
Our experience with the car , the large Phoenix area Chrysler dealership that we bought it from is that it is a horrible vehicle to own .
In 40 years of car ownership , with at least 12 new cars numerous used cars purchased , this was our first genuine "lemon . "
Aside from being a gas hog , comfortable enough for anything other than short trips around town , the car has proven to be unreliable for use as basic transportation .
In two years of ownership , the PT Cruiser had warranty recall work on the electrical system , suspension system , windows , tires , fuel system .
My wife had a high-speed unexplained blow-out/tread in heavy urban traffic that nearly resulted in an accident .
Granted , this ( ) have been the PT 's fault , BUT when she called for the "roadside service , " a feature touted as part of the 3 year bumper-to-bumper warranty , ( towing , tire changes , lock-outs , gas , etc. ) the Chrysler warranty folks refused to honor the request to come to her aid to change the blown out tire .
They told us that according to THEIR records , " we were n't the actual owners of the car ! "
The VIN was ( in their records ) registered to someone we heard of .
This was a shock , since we ordered it waited exactly one year for delivery ...then paid cash ( the full sticker price ) at the dealer 's only eighteen months ( 8,000 miles ) prior to the mishap .
Three different times , the wife had to call me to " jump start " the car drive it to the dealer because of sudden , totally batteries .
At 6000 miles , the OEM tires mysteriously " slipped " on the chrome wheels , creating a bad out of balance situation .
( Again..."normal , " according to the dealership . )
When I asked the dealer 's service department to evaluate it , ( while they changed out another dead battery ) our " service manager " glanced at it said : " Normal !
Since " they all do that , " I asked him to show me another car on his huge lot that had a brake drum that was defoliating layers of iron anywhere nearly like ours .
He got defensive walked away , snapping that they " check it out ."
There was a strong , sour ( as in sour milk ) odor each time the air conditioning was turned on after the car sat for a few hours in hot weather .
It usually took about 10 minutes to abate .
In total , the PT Cruiser was easily THE SINGLE WORST new car I have ever had the misfortune to own .
We 're very happy to be rid of it .
You know you're in trouble when , after driving a certain car for just three days , you find yourself desperately looking for something to like about that car .
"Gear shifter looks cool" the reasoning begins .
But alas , it just is mean to be , the Mercury Cougar is simply a great car .
Cougars of past have been big , luxury cars , high powered muscle cars .
This Cougar is .
It is front-wheel drive a V8 engine is nowhere to be found .
the badges , you'd be hard pressed to figure out that this is a Cougar .
so with many other Ford products ; Mustang , Thunderbird , F-150 .
They all look like what they are .
Even you don't know the first thing about cars , a Mustang still looks like a Mustang .
The Cougar XR (essentially an appearance package on the Sport ) offers many standard features : V6 , 6-disc , in-dash CD changer , leather seating , traction control , split folding rear seat , air-conditioning etc .
The outside is jazzed up with a hood scoop , rear spoiler , 16 inch alloys , fog lights .
There is actually quite a lot of stuff packed into this little car considering the price .
XR Cougars come with special logos on the door pillars floor mats .
Coming soon ; a 35th anniversary edition , you guessed it , just another appearance package .
The Cougar is its strong points , mainly , stand-out exterior styling an interior to match .
The Mercury Cougar is a good looking sporty coupe .
Its edgy styling gets noticed in a crowd .
Whatever your perspective , you'd have to admit it is different looking .
Note to Ford : The Cougar is a half-bad looking car , loose the fake hood scoop FAST !
So many modern cars lure us with their rakish good looks on the outside , only to fall short once we're inside the car .
so with the Cougar , the edgy styling theme continues inside the Cougar with metallic looking surfaces racy gauges .
Aftermarket style pedals , chrome accent door sills , sport seats with body color inserts , bucket rear seats , an elegant but simple door panel design continue the style-fest inside .
that is where the praise ends , a simple summation of all the Cougar's strong points easily be stated as such ; "looks cool inside out ."
Although the interior is great looking , it is essential useless for carrying more than two people .
Rear seats are for kids only , even the front seats cramped times .
Storage space up front is limited , what storage containers there are cheap plasticky .
The glove box alone as the hard plastic it is made of break with just one overly assertive slam .
Switchgear feels durable , but the ergonomic correctness of many Japanese cars .
On the road the Cougar handles well .
In fact , at times , the Cougar be downright fun .
The P215/50R16 tires provide more than adequate grip when carving up back roads , traction control is a welcome addition on a budget priced car .
On paper , the Cougar to have it all , but in the real world "just ok " comes to mind .
Road noise is unacceptably high on all but the smoothest streets .
Certainly one a $ 20,000 sporty coupe to like a Lexus , but the harshness of the Cougar's ride is enough to make an owner want to avoid long trips .
Even the Dodge Stratus has more pleasant road manners on the open highway .
Yes , it is great that the Cougar is available with a V6 , but that 170 hp V6 is noisy unrefined , running through the gears be so much more rewarding the noise level was kept down .
Power is adequate , but more .
An imprecise shift linkage saps some of the driving fun .
The compressor switching on off so taxes the engine that a jolt , slight buck results , fun !
Again , a car like the Dodge Stratus boasts a more refined engine transmission .
The Cougar is available with a 4-cylinder engine as well , but given the barely adequate performance of the V6 , one can't help but skeptical about viability of the 4-cylinder version in everyday driving situations .
A bright spot in the Cougar's power train is fuel economy .
The 2002 Cougar's 2.5L DOHC V6 has an estimated 30 mpg highway 21 city , bad for a little V6 .
The Cougar is an attractive looking sporty coupe , with many features at a reasonable price .
While one argue with the fun of a V6 hooked up to a 5-speed manual , there are plenty of other cars that offer twice the fun , twice the refinement at about the same price .
one is shopping for a new car the Cougar is the first car they drive , it will most impress .
But , as soon as that same shopper drives a VW GTI , the Cougar will be but a distant memory .
Fitting , because the Cougar will soon be a distant memory for us all , Mercury will longer make the current Cougar after the 2002 model year .

The name Apple Computer is synonymous with quality hardware happy users .
Many will be happy to find that the latest high-end system from Apple does n't break the mold .
Hardware Overview
The specs are listed for this computer by Epinions so I wo n't waste space with those .
However , I 'll point out some interesting things that are new and/or noteable on this system .
The 1.42 ghz system has a better looking hardware package than its 1.25 ghz sibling .
This computer 's enhancements include :
166 megahertz speed increase
120 gigabyte hard drive ( 40 gb more than the 1.25 system )
512 megabytes of RAM ( 256 mb more than the 1.25 system )
2 mb L3 cache *see : http ://www.apple .com/powermac/architecture .html*
( 1 mb more than the 1.25 system )
The following are improvements over the previous generation of Powermacs are included in all current Powermacs :
An optional DVD/CD reader burner ( Superdrive ) .
Firewire 800 technology ( an advanced form of the origional firewire interface allows for external devices to be connected to the computer at up to two times the speed of the origional firewire . )
Airport Extreme ( the next generation of wireless networking capabilities .
Uses the "g " technology of wireless interfacing to allow for up to 54 mbps , which is improved from the former 11 mpps . )
Experience
Truly a joy to use .
I 've loved this system from the day I opened it up .
It comes boxed packed precisely carefully .
After I got it up running , I put my old backed up data onto this system was running immediately .
I realize that many are unfamiliar with the Apple world , however .
For you , I say that this system works just like the other Apple systems , just much faster .
There are n't any additional hurdles to learning the operating system specialized hardware .
This computer is very quick accessible to anybody .
The operating system is called " OSX" .
The X is for 10 .
Look for reviews for " OS 10.2 : Jaguar " you want to read about experiences with the Apple OS.
I 've had hardware problems .
I 've upgraded the RAM added an Airport Extreme card into the computer .
The total time spent on these tasks be less than 2 minutes .
I 've been impressed with how intuitive everything is .
Performance
This is a great computer .
The reason it wo n't recieve a full score is that it does n't have the speed of the current PC systems .
Motorola , Apple 's G4 chip makers , has put the money into RandD necessary to keep up with Intel AMD.
It will finish many tests with a slightly slower score than a PC with over double the megahertz ( 3 ghz Intel systems are now commonplace ) .
I make these points to illustrate that the gap is devastating .
I burn CDs at 32x have the cutting edge wireless technology in Airport Extreme , mentioned earlier .
Productivity in all areas is perfectly acceptable .
OSX is revolutionary addictive .
That being , I 'd rather take the best software mid-line hardware .
I absolutely love the OS so slightly slower test scores dissuade me from purchasing this computer .
My recommendation to everybody is to try out Apple 's OSX .
you like it , then this computer is more than worth your money .
Those interested wait until June 27th to find out Apple releases their newest systems then .
Keep an eye out at Apple 's website ( Apple .com )
other sites to know when your dollars will be best spent .

Why ?
Plus , with the extra wide screen , you fit it in an average laptop bag .
The size of the laptop itself makes it harder to move from place to place .
You movie it from room to room from house to house , but I recommend using it in where your lap is your only option .
This laptop requires a desk .
I 've found one , but it barely fit requires some squeezing .
Bottom line .
Great for movies , so great for your lap .
HP has come out with their own 17 inch widescreen notebook labeled the zd7000 which is the customizabe version of the zd70XX series .
so you see other notebooks with zd70XX , everything apply for certain things like the processor speed , amount of ram video ram , size of the harddrive , the wireless option is installed .
now that you know the difference , lets get on with the review .
my specs are :
3.2 ghz processor
512 MB ram
128 mb nvidia geforce graphics
dvd+r dvd writer
this work better since embedded behind the laptop screen , there are antennaes which greatly increase the effectiveness of the wireless .
other than that , I am extremely happy with this laptop .
its quite as nice as my apple g4 17 but then what is ?
so here 's the run down :
screen
thats really impressive , i definitely have more work space , the colors are crisp , although it will a bit dull under flourescent lighting , but this is due to them installing a protective shield like the toshiba p25-s607 which also uses this screen , but crisper .
but their screens dont look great outdoors .
so its a trade off .
one thing that weird is that the screen is narrower than what you be used to with other laptops monitors , but this is a wide screen , therefore you get more sideways real estate but also lose the top-to-bottom real estate .
all in all , the screen is fantastic .
I have been able to work with 2 full windows of word excel ( that doesnt mean maximized ) its just great expecially when editing documents .
keyboard touchpad
the keyboard is also cool because it features the numeric keypad which i havent seen on other laptops .
you also get a full size backspace key too which comes in handy a lot .
as for the touchpad , one annoying design issue is that they decided to make the touchpad wide , so when i do type through the keyboard i tend to rest my palms on the laptop , my hands tend to somehow glide onto the touchpad which puts the cursor somewhere .
this movement is annoyingh especially when editing documents because i accidentally move the cursor somewhere so that when i do look at the screen to see what else i need , i find the text in odd places .
This is definitely annoying , but I havent heard of any other complaints .
even decreasing the sensitivity doesnt completely fix the solution .
sound
the speakers on this laptop are harmon kardon speakers , they are fanastic .
i have n't heard sound this great on a laptop ever .
i had a bunch of mp3 from my last computer that I played on this laptop at first , I the speakers were n't any good because of the tinny sound , but then I realized that it was because of the bit rate encoding , it was encoded at 96 bits of 128 196 for cd quality .
with these speakers .
battery life ...battery life ...battery life ...
it wont last longer than 2 hrs , but you do some power saving things such as reduce the brightness of the screen , dont use the dvd drive , etc , but then whats the fun ? this is definitely meant as a desktop replacement .
otherwise you purchase extra batteries one of those solar panels that power it up .
along the lines of battery power , is the actual power converter brick .
its slightly larger than other converters too .
its also a 3 prong plug going into the brick , so you plan on using a mini power surge protector , belkin has a nice one , i dont targus makes one , at least they didnt have one at best buy .
my overall impression of the laptop is two thumbs up . the blue lighting is very mesmerizing , the dvd drive is very responsive .
i havent tried burning a dvd yet , i have to find some tiem to buy dvd r blanks , i wish it were a multi drive , but ca n't have everything .
also , the dvd drive is a 4x drive , the included roxio software lists it as a 2.4x but when I installed nero 6 , it read it as a 4x drive .
the case definitely sturdy , there is flex in the keyboard , at least that i tell ( i dont want to break this ) also this laptop is heavy .
its about 10 pounds with the battery the adapter .
there are 4 usb 2.0 connections a firewire conenction , the small one , parallel port vga out .
there is also s-video out which i havent tried , but will do soon .
downsides
some of the design problems i have with this are that the ac plug goes into the back left of the laptop of at the back .
this is ok , but annoying .
the placement of the volume buttons being on the top of the keybaord , near the quick launch buttons , who of this ? i guess ive been spoiled with volume buttons being on the sides .
the only firewire connection is on the left side which is also weird , b/c I tend to just leave my firewire external hdd plugged in , so i usually have this plug protruding from the left side .
thats somewhat annyoing .
the size of the beast also makes it difficult to purchase bags .
since it just hit the market , most bags that are able to carry it are bulky ugly .
the ones that fit the G4 wont fit this .
which blows because now i have to find another bag .
i was hoping the timbuk2 bag which just came out for the g4 fit , but to avail .
it was made to tightly fit the apple .
another thing is when typing with this on yer laptop , which i dont recommend since you will be covering the fan inlets , the positioning the keybaord will make it weird to type .
that definitely takes some getting used to , the heat makes it so good .
one other thing is that this laptop doesnt have themedia controls that many other laptops have , that allow you to play your cds turning on the computer .

this machine is great .
its definitely an investment to be happy with .
i especially liked the fact that i customize it to my liking , when yer buying a laptop , especially a wintel machine , you want to about the future what you 'll be able to do .
the HT hyperthreading on this is great an all , but there arent that many applications that take advantage of that just yet , other than some of those intensive graphics apps database apps .
but its cool to have !
also the 128MB of video ram also allows me to play future games as well as todays latest .
i havent had a chance to load up some graphics heavy games , but from what i saw on my friends with only 64 mb on his toshiba p25 , i am sure mine will blow his away !
However , I have found lots of flaws with this computer .
First of all , it does n't have a disk drive ( the hard square disks ) , you have to buy that seperately ( which runs about 100$ ! ) .
only that , this computer has frequent crashes ( about once every week so ) .
That is a problem in itself , but to make matters worse there is set of keys that you press to restart the computer .
You have to hold down the power button for about ten seconds for the computer to turn off .
A few times even that has n't worked I actually had to unplug my computer .
However , the computer does have a lot of memory , it is pretty quick , is good you do n't constantly have to import export things from your computer .
The tech is very helpful too ...however , I have WAY too many friends there considering this is to be a very reliable computer .

bought this computer 12 of august '03 at the apple store in the mall of america , additional apple care ( i'll buy that before the 1 year warranty expires ) products to go with it .
i got a sweet deal on it with my higher education discount .
the machine was easy to "assemble " right out of the box , by default booted into OS X after user setup .
this was an easy task that does require a philips screwdriver , but that by following the instructions provided in the user manual , even a novice user be able to perform .
a word of caution however , when purchasing ram , apple has somewhat strict standards , it is best to purchase ram from a dealer that caters to apple hardware specifically , e.g .
crucial.com
et cetera .
a week later i purchased an airport extreme card to accomodate a new networking scheme in our house .
i was disappointed to realize that airport extreme cards are only compatible with OS X , so that any time i 'm using OS 9 , i am limited to an ethernet connection ( modem ) , using Classic mode under OS X . gaming performance is very satisfactory on this machine , but i 'm sure i 'm getting mega-high framerates that 128mb video cards get , but unreal tournament 2003 is very playable at 800x600 full details set .
the speakers are *adequate* , but i choose to have my comptuters hooked up to my home stereo system for a higher fidelity sound .
about the monitor...people who are sensitive to refresh rates but want a high resolution will be disappointed .
in OS X , the best combination of resolution is 1280x960 at 72Hz . this is plenty fine for me , but i have known people who get eye strain at looking at anything slower than 80Hz .
the refresh rate goes up to 89Hz at 1024x768 , which fine to me in OS 9 , but things look too silly large in OS X . the new mouse keyboard are nice .
one more thing , in sleep mode , the white power light next to the right speaker pulsates , be irritating to some people who are sleeping in the same room as there computer , as it does give off quite a bit of light when it pulses bright .
i find the pulsating a lot less irritating than fan noise however .
I have been a Mac user for many years .
When I started a consultancy business recently I bought an Apple Ti Powerbook .
It nearly cost me the business .
The packaging was delightful as was the design .
Lots of curious envious looks whenever it came out of its bag in meetings , presentations cafes !
Unfortunately I was forced to sell it due to on-going reliability engineering issues .
These became so bad the unit was longer reliable .
I trust it - even started to really really hate it .
The battery connection was very unreliable .
I have had many embarassing unexpected shutdowns midway through important presentations .
What made it worse was I work with predominantly Windows-based clients , having to defend this non-Windows laptop was enviable task .
The screen did close properly from day one .
The right edge floated above the bottom chassis when shut .
There was protection for the screen when shut - one day I found a wad of business cards had actually fallen in between the screen the base , this was with the lid shut !
I hated the slot drive after about the 5th use .
Imagine being able to return a disc a client had asked me to look at because it was stuck inside this expensive " toy" !
Bad news was I remove the useless drive , thus having to still carry it around despite using it .
Heat was an issue , the very loud fan was a right embarassment in the boardroom ( where there were other noticeably quieter Windows laptops around ) .
To top it all off Apple 's service was slow dogged by part shortages ( good intentions only went so far ) .
There were only so many weeks I be a computer .
I my business (certainly my sanity ) suffered because of the poor quality of this laptop .
I switched to an IBM thinkpad after this .
It was cheaper , very solidly built , quiet , came with 3 year return to base warranty ( compared with Apple 's 1 ) .
Let me just start off with a little background about me before I get into the review .
I 've been involved in PC 's for about 10 years now in various capacities , from PC tech to Network Administrator .
Now , on to the review :
Back in 99 we got a digital camcorder as a wedding Christmas present I was so excited - we edit our home movies on our computer do all sorts of neat titles such !
Well , after $ 150 for the FireWire card 2 PC 's later , I was able to get it to work well .
The software was buggy , the card manufacuturer claimed my PC 's chipsets were bad as I was able to get the finished product back to tape , etc .
Then in 2001 , I picked up a new digital camera .
Since photography has been one of my hobbies for years , it only natural to try out a good digital camera .
Along the way , it as our current PC just was n't cutting it .
with digital photos ....
I had always heard Macs were the best for photo video , but I was really drawn to them - the iMacs were ugly ( sorry ) , the towers were EXPENSIVE.
Besides , who uses a Mac anyway ?
Then in February I saw an ad for the new iMac.
I fell in love !
This was what I was looking for , a fast computer with all the bells whistles !
I just knew this had to be the computer for me .
We took a trip to the Tyson 's Corner Apple store one Sunday to check it out make sure it was for me .
Arriving there , it was an awesome experience - you play to your hearts content really experience the hardware .
Definitely worth the trip .
Unfortunately , I had to wait about a month for the money to come in before I even about the iMac again .
So , at 5pm I left on a 2 hour journey ...Got there around 7:30 was out the door with my ner toy by 8pm , home by 10:30.... I the salesperson was in shock when he learned I was from 2 hours away to pick up the computer .
Out of Box Experience - Apple has , hands down the best .
Opening up the box , you saw a cardboard poster with unpacking instructions .
Everything was precisely placed laid out very well .
Initial Setup - Again , flick the power switch in 10 minutes you were off running .
Just answer a few simple questions you are all setup .
Performance - Performance is great .
OSX really needs more memory than the standard 256MB ( so does WinXP) , expecially since I love to multitask - I 'm one of those people that have 10 things running at a time !
Display - THE BEST !
I have a work issue IBM laptop the iMac is the best .
Big ( as big as a 17 " monitor ) , bright , beautiful .
What more I say - everything looks gorgeous , from my Pictures to text !
Stability - I 'm a stickler for stability .
I 've managed to coax more than 10 days of uptime out of any of my Windows boxes ( my Win2k server ) that are in daily use .
With the Mac OSX I regularly get 20+ days of uptime before I need to reboot .
It just runs runs runs .
"reboot to fix this " any stuff like that - it just chugs away .
Software - What I say - this thing is truly the digital hub .
I 've made more movies DVD 's with it in the past 4 months than I have with my PC 's in 10 years .
It 's so easy just works .
Recently , my wife I completed a DVD VHS tape for her brother 's wedding the results are better than the PROFESSIONAL we hired to do ours !
Compatibility- All my files hardware work with it .
I made the transition to all USB devices ( printer , scanner , memory card reader , etc. ) a while ago they are all Plug-and-Play with the Mac !
Complaints
These are small :
Being a Windows guy , learning OSX has taken some time .
In the first couple days I wanted to return the machine , I was so frustrated with it .
But after "forgetting " my Windows stuff Mac OS was/is so intuitive .
*/SYM Scanning in OSX is a disaster .
For some reason , few scanner manufacturers OSX . Epson ( whose scanner I love ) has beta software that works well , but it be a lot better .
Again , I use Epson .
Their drivers are OK , but some of the features of the " Classic " versions ( even the Windows versions .
I hear the new version of OSX will fix this .
*/SYM Networking with Windows .
You connect to file shares on a Windows network , but use printers share files from your Mac on the Windows network ( installing AppleTalk on the PC ) .
When you do connect , the Mac has a nasty habit of leaving weird files on the server ( .DsStore a couple others ) I hear the new version of OSX will fix that as well .
All in all , it 's the best computer that I 've ever used .
I purchased am quite satisfied with the IBM ThinkPad G40 PC .
My comments relate to the whole family of G40 ThinkPads .
Prior to purchasing the G40 , I was also interested in , tried out , several Sony Vaio Dell notebooks .
In contrast , the G40 be booted with 98SE , 2000 , both versions of XP.
Despite what many people claim , PCs are a commodity , in that the of the keyboard the resolution of the screen differ from company to company model to model .
I was attracted to Dell because it offered customization over the Internet .
I select what I want ( more memory , better screen ) dump what I did want ( overpriced high-end Intel chips , Humvee-sized hard disks ) .
But you want to actually touch a Dell , in most of the world , forget it .
I called Dell from a Chicago location asked where I see a demo model , was told that the nearest location was Florida .
Since the operator was in an Indian call center , he mentioned the Floridia location as it were the next street down from me , because he had of North American geography .
I began to wonder what happen I had a technical question had to talk to someone in India .
I finally managed to play with several Inspirons in Tokyo , but was disappointed by their cheap , creaky plastic parts the keyboard with substandard key spacing key travel .
Too bad , otherwise the Inspiron 8600 is a nice machine , but I type lots of reports articles , I need a machine with a superb keyboard .
I do n't have space to add a separate keyboard on my desk .
Here is where the G40 shines .
I use my PC mainly for reports , comments , spreadsheets ,etc.
I do n't use it for games ( that 's what a PlayStation-Game Cube-Xbox are for ) I do n't use it to read email while I travel ( that 's what a PDA is for ) .
The G40 accepts a PS/2 plug for keyboards , although the built-in keyboard is excellent by itself .
The PS/2 jack is being phased out of notebooks , like the serial port , but there are n't that many USB keyboards available who wants to use up all their USB ports with basic equipment ?
Besides the keyboard , I was attracted to IBM 's responsible service .
Sometimes , the repairs were free .
Other times , they were as expensive as elsewhere .
one ignores the keyboard the service , the G40 is a plain vanilla PC .
It is only 2.4GHz , it only ships with 256MB memory (upgrades to 1GB) , this model has a 40GB hard disk but that only spins at 4200 rpm of the newer 7200 rpm , the memory cache is on the processor separate , etc .
Since memory drives are commodities available cheaply , one wonders why IBM does n't splurge a bit include the latest stuff , but IBM was the low-cost leader .
Other PCs have only 2 , trust me , they will be full from the first week of use .
It also comes with CD RW/DVD , 1 PC card slot , parallel , monitor ports , built-in floppy drive , built-in T100 ethernet , audio jacks a modem .
I did want a built-in wireless card , they typically are incompatible with third-party transmitters .
I have been looking to replace our aging laptop for a while .
I bought the zd7040 which is the version available at Best Buy .
Most other computer stores have the zd7020 , the only difference is that the 7040 has a 60Gig hard drive the 7020 has an 80Gig .
Best Buy had a great 18 month interest deal the extended warranty was better .
The screen has to be seen to be .
It is 17" diagonally with a widescreen ratio .
This substitute for your main TV in a pinch .
The contrast is very good the images are very sharp .
Different models have faster/slower versions .
I there is even one with the new hyper threading processor for bigger $ $ .
This model has the GeForce to go FX 5600 chip with 64Megs of RAM.
I ran 3DMark2001 benchmarks got over 10000 !
This thing really is a nice desktop crammed into a "portable " package .
Don't mislead yourself into thinking you will be working away on a long flight .
This thing won't even fit on an average tray table , it is that big .
It weighs about 10 pounds with the AC adapter .
The battery life is also that great .
I worked in our living room for a while got about 45 minutes when the battery read 50 % , so I am guessing about 1 ½ hours with "normal" use .
Hey , at least you play some 3D games .
This graphics chip supports Direct X9 .
How many laptops say that !
There are ports-a-plenty : ( 4 ) USB 2.0, one firewire , one S-video out , one VGA , one parallel , headphones , mic , 10/100 Ethernet , modem , IR , 5 different digital media reader ( compact flash , SD , memory stick , etc. ) , ( 2 ) Type I PCMCIA slot ( 1 ) Type II slot .
This actually has more ports than my desktop !
The keyboard is full sized there is a numeric pad on the right ( the Toshiba model that also uses this screen does n't have the numeric pad does n't look nearly as cool ) .
The touchpad is pretty good the software lets you do some neat stuff .
One weird thing is that HP has the tap-click feature ( that everyone else uses ) disabled by default , but you change it in the settings .
This model has a DVD +R/RW drive but I have n't tried it out yet .
It reads CD just fine plays DVD's great .
The sound is by Harmon Kardon is OK .
I have Harmon Kardon in my car I am overly impressed .
I Bose do a better job .
It still sounds way better than most tinny laptop speakers .
For the amount of room they had to work with though , I they have done even better .
One thing that is bothersome is the amount of power it consumes .
I can't find an auto adapter to power it .
It looks like it draws about 120 watts but the new Targus 120 watt auto adapter does n't say it supports it .
Maybe in a few months the situation will improve .
Overall I am very happy but this is the Hummer of laptops .
For what it was built to do it does very well .
Just do n't it will be something it is n't ( like light ) .

The Bottom Line
I 've been a " Mac girl" ever since the introduction of the Classic I say that this is one of the best computers I 've ever owned .
Many of the other Apple computers components I 've owned have been plagued with problems , yet after 6 months this one has been virtually problem-free .
Although I had just purchased a Snow iMac in late 2000 , once I saw the ad for the Flat Panel iMac I knew this was the computer for me .
The original iMac iMovie for OS 9 had got me hooked on editing home movies I was drooling over the built in DVD-R in the new model .... I had to have it .
Once I ordered the system it took months to come in because they were n't shipping , but I those problems are gone now .
When the computer arrived , the flat panel screen was cocked the fix was too difficult to complete alone as it required opening the flat panel screen .
Apple tech was very understanding of the problem quickly set up a case for me it was fixed at a local shop within a week .
I was a little nervous about switching operating systems since everything I used was on OS 9 , but the learning curve is n't steep.
OS X is very sleek much more user friendly stable than OS 9 , for the few programs that you ca n't get on OS X , it even runs OS 9 in the background you want !
OS X comes with all the tools you need ( the video camera ) for making professional looking DVD 's of whatever you want .
At $ 22 a piece it has almost paid for itself !
Unlike Apple 's previous attempts at stylish computers , they did sacrifice function for fashion in this model .
only is it ingeniously " cute , " it also runs extremely cool ( burning hot CD 's coming out of THIS drive ) .
It is the quietest computer I 've ever owned as well .
The flat panel is beautiful although I 've seen others complain of dead pixels , I do n't have any yet .
( I also this is just the "nature of the beast " with flat panel monitors ) The screen pivoting feature is wonderful in a room where I am constantly showing my work to people around me .
It will run even the most graphic intensive game multi-task like a champ .
I 'm disappointed that they are now coming out with a 17 " model , as I have waited for this had I known .
I know I know , you know with computers whatever you buy is typically outdated within 6 months anyways , but with this machine I went by past experience with iMacs always being 15 inches .

The new Apple 12-inch Powerbook ( PB) notebook computer is a sleek with some special features for a compact computer , but it overheats with extended use .
Specifically , when using the computer for over one hour , especially when multitasking with programs , ( i .e .
The excessive heat is only distracting unpleasant , it is unhealthy as heat inflames the tendon sheath associated with carpal tunnels syndrome ( CTS ) .
This is a new compact model , others have reported this over-heating design flaw ; there are over 200 related postings on Apple 's own website 's discussion forum : ( http ://discussions .info.apple .com
This problem has also been discussed in other non-Apple affiliated sources .
Apple 's warranty for the computer is one year .
In my experience with the 12-inch PB , I spent excessive time on the phone with Apple regarding the overheating .
Apple claims that it is performing within specifications will replace , refund , allow me to trade in the computer for a different model .
On March 26th , Apple released an article concerning the excessive heat : " PowerBook G4 ( 12-inch ) : Feels Warm to the Touch - Article ID:86307" .
In this Apple document , advice is provided to minimize the heat problem by making adjustments to the Power Manager Preference .
Apple Technical has also recommended that I purchase a heat transfer device that goes under the PB to elevate it , to put rubber pads where my hands rest as a barrier from the heat .
This is all commendable advice , but it has resolved the over-heating problem .
More importantly , one pay top dollar for a computer advertised as the top model of its size , only to have to compromise certain features , how many programs operating , speed , etc .
One purchases such a high-end model computer precisely because for high-performance to handle more complicated tasks .
you are considering switching to Apple because it advertises itself as an out-of-the-box , user-friendly , problem-free alternative to PCs , I consider this computer .
Certain flaws , such as overheating , will be until you find yourself at home with the computer .
Also , I do recommend buying the first line of a new model computer , but wait until it has been out a while so the problems be worked out .
The Beginning ...
Apple snagged me as a prospective customer in January of 2001 after a series of problems with my Gateway desktop .
I was in the market for a laptop for school decided to try the local Apple reseller in town .
The technicians were knowledgeable friendly the the price was right .
However , I found that I customize my own iBook through www.apple .com ,
shipping was free .
The chance to avoid the pressure of salesmen was attractive so I quickly placed my order .
A week later I received my new Keylime iBook promptly fell in love it .
A year later ...
That was until I found out that Apple had released photos of it 's upcoming Flat Panel iMac.
I once again placed a customized order through www.apple .com
for the top of the line model : 800 MHZ G4 Superdrive with DVD/CD RW capabilities , 60 GB of memory , I bumped the RAM from 256 to 512 MB.
Some argue that the DVD-RW be necessary , but I wanted to keep my options open just in case I purchase a digital camcorder in the future .
Ground shipping , as always , was free .
All together my purchase came close to $ 1900 .
You also choose from a 700 mhz model that had a CD-RW/DVD-ROM drive ( as opposed to the DVD-RW drive with the 800 mhz ) , an even cheaper 700 mhz model that had just a CD-RW drive .
They were around $ 1600 $ 1400 respectively .
Worth it in my opinion . )
I was able to finance the computer through MBNA , which provides an easy loan application through the Apple website .
I placed the order in the middle of January with the promise of it being delivered in 3-5 weeks .
I settled in for the long wait .
The Verdict ...
Five weeks to the day later , I received an e-mail from Apple stating that it be delayed an additional 7 days .
At this point , I was so used to waiting that the message did n't phase me .
However , I was surprised when I received an e-mail two days later saying it had been shipped .
Five days later it was on my doorstep.
First off , Apple knows how to deliver .
It was in a perfectly square box that had a picture of the iMac on one side , an Apple logo on the other .
I cut through the top of the box was greeted by a heavy-weight poster of the new iMac in various positions .
Do I dare say it looked like it was dancing ?
I removed the poster styrofoam that contained the keyboard , the styrofoam that surrounded the computer .
Set-up was a snap .
I connected one end of the plug into the computer the other into the wall .
Then , I connected the keyboard speakers .
Finally , I connected the mouse .
I was frustrated at the amount of USB slots that were taken up until I realized that the mouse is meant to be plugged into the keyboard ( which contains two USB slots at the top ) .
Whoops .
Apple supplied their customers with a total of five USB slots on this beauty , along with two firewire slots .
More than enough .
I fired up my new beauty by pushing the "power button " located on the left side of the base was greeted by OS X .
It looked absolutely amazing on the 15 inch LCD monitor .
OS X was automatically programmed to get me setup as a new user onto the internet in the fastest way .
I already had a user account through Earthlink I had problems setting it up , but Apple also gave the option to set up a new account .
Ten minutes later I was surfing the internet with my new iMac.
additional access to community features online .
I was able to immediately access my "mac mail " through the mail program in OS X ( when connected to the internet ) but I also wanted to access my Earthlink mail account .
Setting up the mail program to retrieve my Earthlink mail was a piece of cake !
I now retrieve both mail accounts from my Apple .
After a bit I decided to install a game .
Once again , installation was flawless the game ( The Sims , a memory hog ) ran great .
I tried iTunes out right away was impressed the the simplicity of the program .
The music that was preloaded into the program sounded wonderful through the Apple Pro Speakers that came with the system .
I 'm looking forward to starting a new MP3 collection .
I 'm also looking forward to using iMovie iDVD in conjunction with a digital camcorder , when I get around to purchasing one .
I need to win the lottery first .
I 've also gotten a lot of use out of iPhoto , Apple 's digital photo editing software .
I own an Olympus digital camera I love to download my photos to edit them .
However , I 've always had such a tough time keeping track of the photos once they were saved to my computer .
iPhoto eliminatated this problem .
The program saves each set of pictures you download as a "roll " of film to be accessed later .
The pictures be left in the "rolls " I reorganize them as I wish .
I also organize the photos into slide shows with one click of a button .
Apple has a reputation for being different making software that is easy for the average consumer to use .
They easily live up to their name with this computer .
only is the G4 Superdrive ultra fast (arguably faster than my Gateway Athlon ) , it 's quieter than a mouse .
The screen , of course , is a genius .
I pull it closer when I want to read a website .
I push it back when I want to play a game .
All it takes is a little push with one finger it hovers to where I want it to go .
I also push it up down my neck is getting strained .
, the software is a snap to use .
I have n't had any freeze-ups hardware problem yet .
Technical Specifications
Processor memory
700- 800-MHz PowerPC G4 processor with Velocity Engine
256K on-chip level 2 cache at full processor speed
128MB 256MB of SDRAM expandable to 1GB ; one factory installed 168-pin DIMM one open user-accessible SO-DIMM slot
Storage
40GB 60GB Ultra ATA hard disk drive ( 1 )
, CD-RW drive ( writes CD-R discs at 24x speed , writes CD-RW discs at 10x speed , reads CDs at 32x speed )
, DVD-ROM/CD-RW Combo drive ( reads DVDs at 8x speed , writes CD-R discs at 12x speed , writes CD-RW discs at 8x speed , reads CDs at 32x speed )
, SuperDrive ( combination DVD-R/CD-RW drive ; writes DVD-R discs at 2x speed , reads DVDs at 6x speed , writes CD-R discs at 8x speed , writes CD-RW discs at 4x speed , reads CDs at 24x speed , )
for external FireWire USB storage devices
Display
Built-in 15-inch (viewable ) TFT active-matrix liquid crystal display
Typical viewing angle : 120 degrees horizontal ; 90 degrees vertical
Typical brightness : 200 candela per meter squared
Typical contrast ratio : 300:1
Graphics
32MB of dedicated Double Data Rate ( DDR) video memory
Three flicker-free screen resolutions : 640 by 480 pixels , 800 by 600 pixels , 1024 by 768 pixels ( optimum resolution )
24-bit true color at all resolutions for displaying millions of colors
Built-in 56K V.90 fax modem ( RJ-11 connector )( 4 )
Built-in 10/100BASE-T Ethernet ( RJ-45 connector )
Audio
Built-in speaker
Apple Pro Speakers ( 9 watts each ) ( 3 )
Internal 18-watt digital amplifier
Apple speaker minijack for connection to Apple Pro Speakers
Headphone jack
Built-in microphone for speech recognition audio recording
for external USB audio devices
Video
Mini-VGA output port ( requires VGA display adapter )
for video mirroring : external devices display an image identical to that shown on the built-in display
Output resolutions : 640 by 480 pixels at 60 Hz , 800 by 600 pixels at 75Hz , 1024 by 768 pixels at 75Hz
Keyboard mouse
Apple Pro Keyboard with 15 function keys , 4 arrow keys ( inverted "T" arrangement ) , audio controls , media-eject key ; two built-in USB 1.1 ports ; two-position tilt
Apple Pro Mouse with optical sensor for precise cursor control
Peripheral connections
Two 400-Mbps FireWire ( IEEE 1394 ) ports ( 6 ) ; 8 watts shared
Three USB 1.1 ports ( shared on two 12-Mbps controllers ) ; two USB 1.1 ports on keyboard
for FireWire target disk mode for high-speed transfer of files between two computers
Electrical requirements agency approvals
Frequency : 47 to 63 Hz , single phase
Meets ENERGY STAR requirements
Environmental requirements
Storage temperature : -40° to 185° F (-40° to 85° C )
Relative humidity : 5 % to 95 % noncondensing
Size weight
Width : 15.1 inches ( 38.3 cm ) minimum ; 16.3 inches ( 41.5 cm ) maximum
Weight : 21.3 pounds ( 9.7 kg ) ( 7 )

The Unveiling Set Up
I checked my watch before I opened the box .
It took me just under 9 minutes from cutting the tape on the box to having the computer up running .
I can't brag about how quickly I got on to the internet , though , since my darling husband has yet installed the Ethernet wire I bought to connect to our new router .
Needless to say , the set-up was incredibly easy took instructions whatsoever ( though clear visual diagrams are available for the less confident ) .
The software is already pre-loaded ready to go .
How does the New iMac Different Compare to the Previous Version ?
In comparing the two computers , I will be referring to the more recent iMac models , the original fruit colored ones with the hockey puck mouse .
Also , be aware that even though I am an avid devoted Mac fan , I 'm a techno-geek .
Do n't sue me I leave something out - just leave me a comment about my omissions and/or errors ( preferably a kind supportive comment ) .
Although first glance that the new iMac is vastly different than its predecessor , there are a few basic similarities :
~ ~ All in one package : The beauty simplicity of having everything you need in one integrated unit was a major selling point for the first iMacs it continues to be a significant advantage of the new generation of iMacs .
~ ~ Mouse keyboard : Both of these input peripherals are identical on my two iMacs - the Apple Pro Optical mouse the full size Apple Pro keyboard .
Actually , there is one notable difference with this iMac , both the keyboard the optical mouse are snowy white , just like the computer itself .
The white keys are an improvement over the black keys on my other iMac keyboard because they're much easier to see in the dark .
~ ~ Minimal Expandability : There are many options for expanding iMac model , though the need for expansion less of an issue with the feature-packed new iMac.
Both have one available slot for memory ( which I've already filled on both computers ) the option of installing an Airport card .
Now for the differences - some striking some more subtle :
~ ~ Size shape : As you see from the photo , the new iMac is a unique-looking computer .
Rather than looking like a large CRT monitor ( like the old iMac ) , the new one looks like a soccer ball ( closer in size to a basketball ) cut in half with a slender flat screen literally floating in space .
The new iMac only has a 10.6 inch footprint so even with the two speakers , keyboard , mouse , I have tons more room on my computer desk to clutter up with other gadgets .
~ ~ Monitor : of the 15-inch CRT on the older iMac , the new iMac has a brilliant flat-panel 15-inch display which provides almost the same viewable area as most 17-inch CRT monitors , but with twice the sharpness , brightness , contrast .
Therefore , there is ample space to grab a hold of the screen move it actually putting your fingers on the viewable screen itself .
~ ~ Speakers : This high-end iMac also ships with two 9-watt round external Apple Pro Speakers .
The earlier iMacs are all limited to internal speakers that provide a much more limited audio experience .
The Apple Pro Speakers look like softball-sized clear eyeballs .
~ ~ Hard Drive : Though hard drive size is a huge issue for many people , I really appreciate the 60GB Ultra ATA hard disk drive on the new iMac ( as opposed to 20GB on my older iMac ) .
All it took was a little digital video-editing project to max out my old iMac 's hard drive space .
~ ~ Processor : of the 450-MHz G3 in my first iMac , the newer iMac comes with the 800-MHz PowerPC G4 with Velocity Engine .
What this means is that the newer iMac easily handle the data-intensive processing required by digital video , music , graphics applications 3D games .
It also comes with a NVIDIA GeForce2 MX graphics processor with 32MB of dedicated Double Data rate video memory that gives a major boost to 3D graphics .
~ ~ Removable Media Drive : My old iMac was cutting edge ( OK , well really ) , because it came with a DVD player .
Though the removable media drives that ship with the new iMacs differ from model to model , this one is the top of the line - the SuperDrive .
The SuperDrive is a DVD burner as well as a DVD player CD-RW.
The new iMac's drive is also a tray drive as opposed to the slot drive on my older iMac.
According to Apple , the SuperDrive "writes DVD-R discs at 2x speed , reads DVDs at 6x speed , writes CD-R discs at 8x speed , writes CD-RW discs at 4x speed , reads CDs at 24x speed . "
I have n't timed it yet so I 'll have to take their word for it .
~ ~ More USB ports : The new iMacs have one extra USB port than the earlier iMacs , making a total of 5 USB ports ( counting the two on the Apple Pro keyboard ) .
I appreciate the extra port , though I I 'll still need a hub at some point .
~ ~ Operating System : My first iMac was one of the last machines that shipped OS X .
The new one comes with two operating systems : OS X OS 9.2
Other software shipped on the new iMac includes the latest QuickTime , AppleWorks 6 , Mail , Microsoft Internet Explorer , AOL , Quicken 2002 Deluxe , World Book Mac OS X Edition , Otto Matic , Mac OS X Chess , PCalc , Acrobat Reader FAXstf 10.0 Preview .
I have n't checked it all out , though I have had a blast with the World Book ( encyclopedia , dictionary , atlas , more ) .
~ ~ Other Features ( necessarily unique to this iMac ) : The G4 iMac comes with 256 RAM ( I added another 256 immediately ) , a built-in 56K V.90 fax modem , built-in 10/100BASE-T Ethernet ( takes RJ-45 connector ) , two 400-Mbps FireWire ports , built-in antennas a card slot for an optional 11-Mbps AirPort Card .
Adding additional memory an airport card is a simple process of unscrewing the base plate .
However , I had my extra memory installed free from MacConnection so I did n't need to do this .
http ://www.apple .com/imac/specs .html
Enough of the Dry Details , Tell Us About the Intangible iMac Experience !
I admit , I love the all white look .
It's downright virginal !
Besides looking gorgeous , sitting on my desk , this G4 iMac screams in terms of speed !
It 's going to be hard to switch back forth between this my older CRT.
The screen moves effortlessly up down , forward back , while maintaining the same angle .
I was a bit apprehensive about the strength of the chrome arm but after handling it a bit I see that 's more than tough enough .
In fact , you lift the computer by the arm when you want to move it .
The video quality in this computer is first rate .
I've watched several DVDs on this any problem , though I have n't yet burned one .
There is a distinct hum to the computer ( a cooling fan ) , though it 's still quieter than my older iMac.
Though I've been quite curious about this new operating system , I've also been understandably nervous in having it on my new computer since virtually all of my applications ( the ones that came pre-installed ) are OSX compatible .
Fortunately , it also ships with OS 9.2 so I I make that my default operating system , I figure out how .
Some people I know are so paranoid about OSX that they uninstalled it completely .
It takes a few seconds for the classic environment to open but then everything to work perfectly ( so far ) .
The ease of dealing with the operating system question has definitely added to the pleasure of using this new iMac.
One thing that 's taking awhile to get use to is the location of the power button .
It's on the back of the computer on the left side .
You can't see it so you have to around for it .
I still miss the power button on the keyboard ( on my Blue White G3 ) .
Though I 'm thrilled with my new purchase , I do have some doubts about the practicality of this model in certain situations .
For example , I do n't this iMac will ever take off as a computer of choice in the public schools ( a haven for the original iMac ) .
The flat screen is just too delicate for the kind of handling that curious impulsive kids provide .
In fact , I have my concerns about my own kids the flat screen .
Originally , I envisioned this computer serving as the "family computer " where I write Epinions , my husband surf the net , our young children play games .
For now , I 've banned my kids from even coming within 5 feet of this baby , though I know I wo n't be able to enforce the " kid zone " for long .
My six-year-old is already talking about what games he wants to load on to " Mama's new computer . "
Dr 's Recommendation
The 800MHz Flat Screen G4 iMac is everything I want in a computer - fast , reliable , powerful , compact , beautiful , downright fun .
It has the features to delight the experienced computer whiz , yet is simple enough for the novice to enjoy .
You laugh all you want - I know you 're just jealous .
The PowerMac G5 is a computer designed for two types of person : The power-mad user of CPU-sapping programs like Final Cut Pro After Effects , the person who just wants to look like one .
For the latter type , Apple has an entirely new case design , one that is beautifully made , but looks formal , stiff , a little stand-offish .
It is warm fuzzy ; my friend Amber will hug it , as she did my PowerMac G4 at work ; she slide a finger two over it , admiring the smooth , brushed-aluminum surface .
In short , it looks impressive , much more impressive , a formidable piece of engineering .
But those who like to hug computers want to find one of the last old G4 models .
The G5 is taller somewhat thinner than the old model .
It 's lighter , being made of aluminum of steel .
Setup Installation
Setup installation are , as usual , done with the same meticulous good taste sleekness of all Apple products .
You turn it on , plug in the keyboard , mouse monitor while it 's setting itself up , it treats you to a somehow dazzling but tasteful understated " Welcome " in ten different languages .
the process continues , smooth , pleasant tasteful until it is all done you have a set up internet connection all is well .
Do n't do that .
After that , it started to work flawlessly .
I do n't buy computers to look at their case design !
all of this happens with a tiny fraction of CPU use .
Encouraged by this , I decided on a stress test computer I 'd ever owned pass .
I decided to try capturing video then using my machine for other stuff .
Video capture is one of the most difficult things you ask a computer to do , because it all has to be done in real time .
it drops as little as one frame out of the 30 coming at it per second , the capture is useless .
Because of this , video capture is usually a mind-numbingly boring procedure where you sit at your computer , stare at your footage ( since you ca n't edit it at this point ) become bored to tears .
so on the PowerMac G5 !
My first attempt at this did n't work because I was installing LiveType at the same time .
It turns out that you ca n't install something from a CD while capturing video .
But you do pretty much anything else you want .
I was playing music with iTunes , checking my mail every minute , writing a message on my web browser , cruising the web switching between mail web constantly .
The system handled this all perfectly .
On all my older computers ( PowerBook G4 , PowerMac G4/450 dual ) , I do ANYTHING else while capturing video .
On this computer , with the standard 512mb RAM , everything just worked .
I 'm still getting used to the computer , I have a lot to learn about optimizing its performance .
But so far , I 'm very pleased ; it much faster than the benchmarks .
there 's more interest in real-world performance , I 'll add to this epinion later on when I have more results .
The 9 Fans
I am having problems with my home air conditioning , as a result my house has been a bit hot .
It is a bit of a trip to see - well , hear - how my new computer reacts to its difficult environment .
When I start working on it after a period of inactivity , the fans will run loud for a few seconds then restore themselves to silence .
Based on other reviews , I do n't this will be a problem for a typical household environment .
When my air conditioning gets fixed , I 'll post an addendum about the change in fan behaviour , any .
The bottom line , then , is that you have a hot room , prepare for a suprisingly noisy computer as it protects itself from the hostile environment outside .
I recommend a comparably loud speaker system when in a loud environment , remember , you play music through iTunes even when your computer is capturing video .
I emphasize , however , that a comparably powerful PC have a whole bunch of fans that be on constantly .
It 's just that most people are n't going to put that kind of computer in a room where noise is an issue .
Buying Tips
I do advise the purchase of any hot Apple product from the online Apple Store .
In most cases , you will actually get your product faster you purchase it from the retail Apple Stores on the day it becomes available there .
At the time I bought my machine at the Apple Store in the Grove shopping center in LA , there were people stacked up in the mail order queue who had ordered months before I did .
Since the savings for buying via mail order are literally non-existant ( with sales tax full retail prices still charged ) , there is literally reason in the world to buy retail .
Well , there is one .
Certain build to order options , such as getting a 250gb drive of the stock 160 , only be obtained online .
For me , with projects to do stuff to accomplish , it was n't worth waiting three weeks to get a bigger drive .
You always buy your memory upgrades from a third party , Apple .
Apple memory upgrade prices are absurd to the point of comic relief .
For example , upgrading my system from 512mb to 2-1gb sticks ( total of 2gb ) cost over $ 1,000 when purchased from Apple .
Other Considerations
The old G4s accomodate 4 hard drives in the case .
The new G5 , despite its larger case , only accomodate 2. Fortunately , for the new FireWire 800 standard makes this less important than it used to be , but it 's still annoying feels like a step backwards .
Every component of the G5 has undergone a makeover .
Faster video , faster memory , faster disk interfaces , everything 's faster .
Surprisingly , the keyboard on the G5 is a significant improvement from the G4 's .
With the G4s , the mushy keys often did n't register my keystrokes , especially when trying to type capital letters .
With the G5 , the keyboard is still mushier than I 'd like , but it 's at least reliable ; when I hit the shift key , I always get capital letters .
Sound on the built-in speaker is poor , but since most people will buy third-party stereo speakers for a system of this class , that did n't wind up being significant .
MacOS X
MacOS X really started coming into its own when I bought my PowerBook 1ghz system late last year .
Menus snapped into place , everything scrolled quickly , so on .
The dual G5 makes the PowerBook G4 look downright sluggish .
It 's more than things taking .1 second of .5 second , but it feels even more responsive than the old system .
The operating system is every bit as much of a brilliantly designed art object as the computer itself .
you want a good reason to switch from Windows , the tasteful elegance of MacOS X is an excellent one .
, of course , the performance .
This is an expensive product , but unlike 99 % of computers made today , it has the fit , finish , look of something polished to gleaming perfection .
On the paper this machine has everything to please a customer : power , big screen , universal DVD+ DVD- writer .
The first big surprise is the weight .
You wo n't take it with you you 're a frequent flyer !

I have two USB devices that just do n't work on this laptop .
They work on IBM , HP even crappy clones like Acer Dell .
way to have them work .

The Dell Inspiron 5150 starts as low as $ 1499 .

VGA , Ethernet

Why was I so drawn to the iMac ?
You see , for the last 11 years I have been using Microsoft Windows-based machines .
Each version of Windows has been getting better , XP in particular is quite good .
In fact , going into this purchase , I was quite happy with XP.
Still , roaming the aisles of CompUSA I felt myself being drawn to the iMac.
For a few reasons actually .
I still use a Windows machine for work , so I figured I take a chance buy an iMac to replace my Micron PC at home - I have n't looked back since .
My home computer had been used primarily for managing photos , creating editing Microsoft Office documents , videoconferencing (using Messenger in XP) , surfing the net .
With the iMac , I wanted to add making movies to the repertoire .
One thing that I discovered that eased my decision was the fact that MS Office documents now share the same file format for Mac PC .
My was that the Mac version require different file formats ( requiring a conversion at end ) , this is the case .
Discovering that I create a Word , Excel Powerpoint document e-mail it to a PC any worries was a beautiful thing .
The other thing that was a concern was videoconferencing functionality .
We have family on the other coast , used the videoconferencing capability built into XP 's Messenger to virtually visit these relatives .
However , there was an easy solution .
Yahoo Messenger does have videoconferencing capabilities built-in , works cross-platform ( Mac to PC ) .
In addition , the iSight camera that is available for the Mac is incredible .
It is auto-focus , the image quality is excellent .
The new PC 's were shipping with 3 GHz processors , here I was contemplating the purchase of a machine with a 1 GHz processor .
I put a bit of faith in this explanation , let it get in the way of my purchase decision .
Once I found that MS Office videoconferencing work for me on the iMac - put aside the processor speed concern - I got out the credit card .
OUT OF THE BOX
One thing that really bugged me about my PC was the sheer number of cables , connectors general mess it to create on my desktop .
It was so nice taking the iMac out of the box , placing it on my desk , connecting the speakers , keyboard Ethernet cable to the iMac , connecting the mouse to the keyboard , done .
I am stating the obvious when I say the iMac looked stunning .
It truly is a piece of art , the build quality is very impressive .
The bottom of the iMac was even finished off beautifully with a circular piece of brushed aluminum ( which looks very much like a larger version of what you 'd find on the back of a fine watch ) .
Another aspect of the design that is very nice is the fact that the system is very ergonomically pleasing .
It is amazing how much more comfortable it is (especially at 6'3" ) to have the screen up nice high .
The range of movement is vast .
Being tall , I have the screen very high , but someone who likes it lower lower it all the way down so that the bottom of the screen is only a half inch from the surface of the desk !
From the highest to the lowest setting , there is a range of movement of 7.5 inches !
I found that once I started using the iMac , I got way fewer headaches .
With my other monitor , even though the viewing angle was correct after it pivoted upward , I was still looking down at it quite a bit .
This caused the back of my neck to strain after a while , which sometimes lead to headaches .
The iMac monitor also pivots from side to side , which I have n't found all that useful - but I guess people will use it when they want to show others their work , etc .
FEATURES
I anyone buying simply on specs will buy a PC , as they are leading the pack from a hardware per dollar standpoint .
I was more concerned with real world usability .
Still , for those that know , here are the specs :
1 GHz PowerPC G4 Processor
17 " widescreen digital display
80GB 7200rpm Hard Drive
NVIDIA GeForce4 MX 64MB video card

56K V.92 internal modem
2 Firewire ports
