Alcatraz is arguably the most infamous prison on our planet .
Built in the early 1900 's , housing names like Al Capone , Alcatraz is one of the harshest , most impenetrable prisons ever .
The label in particular that he is about is Copastik Records , headed by Jon Saxton .
After "escaping " that "prison , " Rasco found his way to Coup D'Etat Records , he relishes his new freedom with this new album .
The Intro kicks off the album with sampled soundbites describing the hopelessness of Alcatraz , the desolate inescapable prison .
After this setting-setter , we get Get Free .
Here , Rasco uses Alcatraz to symbolize two separate things .
First , he uses it to urge people to "escape " from whatever is holding them back in life .
The second meaning is more personal , which is his own struggles with his previous label .
He calls out Jon Saxton here , talking about his previous adversity in the industry .
Building upon personal setbacks is U Got The Time .
Over a relaxing , soulful guitar loop , his verses flow easily on this uplifting song .
Here he once again urges his listeners to break free of everything keeping them from doing what they want .
Rasco 's songs have an uplifting message , while managing to keep his tracks down-to-earth more happy than sad .
The Sweet Science features Jurassic 5 member Chali 2Na , the two MC 's trade the first two verses share the third .
Here , they use a boxing metaphor as a symbolism for their battle rhymes .
The beat is more bouncy , featuring samples strings , it more geared towards Chali 2Na .
San Fran To The Town features Casual form the Hieroglyphics .
Here the thick guitar loop meshes with Casuals nice-sounding flow , its laid-back relaxing .
Rasco calmly tells of his legal brawls with Copastik Records Jon Saxton , accusing them of stealing his songs , his money , his career .
He tells about how he was fighting to leave them , his reaction now that he is free .
This sort of song is reminiscent of Common 's Cube-diss , because both songs feature an artist who is known for his viciousness who lashes out obliterates his opponent in the most laid-back way .
All I Wanna Be closes out the album , with guitar strings Kisha Griffin singing the chorus .
Here , Rasco raps as he is confessing , telling us what he wants in the future , his desire to "escape " the route his career in rapping has taken to this point in time .
Rasco 's newest LP is one of the best of 2003 , get it now . . his talent on the mic was "imprisoned " on this album , your urge to buy it be .
Ras branches out into many different aspects of rap .
From dissing , to introspect , to retrospect , Rasco lays it down skillfully with enough greatness to make Jon Saxton wish he was n't such a moron .
Congratulations Copastik , Rasco just made all of you look like the conformist "imprisoning " label you really are .
Although Cormega was kicked out of the AZ , Nas , Nature Foxy Brown group The Firm some time before the groups ' debut album , he joined Def Jam records was working on his own released debut album The Testament .
Soon after , he was facing jail time on charges to me released that album .
Some years later , he 's finally released his true debut album , The Realness .
Although I had high expectations for it , it lived up to be everything I had it to be is nothing short of amazing .
Though Nas say different , Cormega is almost a reincarnate him .
With this said , its hard to notice the street poetry , the delivery multi-syllable flow that 's throughout the albums fourteen tracks .
Although many disagree with me , but Cormega 's style is , , better than Nas ever have .
While Illmatic is a classic album of street poetry , The Realness deserves , in every right , to be in that particular hall of fame .

Dramatic Entrance is a classic album opener .
of an intro a skit to level everything out with talking about nothing various sound effects that make sense , we get an actual track .
The low-key , very angelic beat is brought to life by a rather complex drum loop extremely well-fitting harp sound effects a scaling keyboard effect tops everything off .
The actual lyrics are second to .
Cormega does n't fuck around with bragging , various comments just rambling on about nothing , he actually kicks a few verses that touch down on his time before this albums release how few he actually record this classic album .
The one thing I was most surprised at was the fact that he did n't waste any time getting into the actual rhyming deep subject matter that The Realness undoubtedly has .
The following track , American Beauty , is a rendition of the classic Common track , I Used To Love H.E.R.
The overall effect is still the same as ' Mega uses the metaphor of a woman for the various uses that Hip-Hop has for both the underground the mainstream .
His lyrics are second to his flow perfectly suits the slow , saddening beat extremely well .
The only problem I have with this particular track is that even though his lyrics are extremely good , the track is too short for him to actually go into any detail that was n't heard on Common 's version .
A few tracks up , we come to my favorite track , bar on the album .
R U My Nigga is a questionnaire of trust loyalty .
With a beautiful beat provided by Jae-Supreme that consists of a brilliant synthesizer section , a scarce drum loop a bass kick that tops it all off , Cormega retains his poetic lyrical elements .
The being handled this way is a fresh works considerably well .
To top it all off , listening to valid points over a first-class beat with poetic elements thrown in as well , you a classic track which is exactly what comes from this .
( " The insecurity of things they see/Makin' niggas minds corrupt , then my nine erupts/Denyin' what , life you had expired/You tried your luck , then died for what/You asked for forgiveness but my eyes was shut/You was n't wise enough , to stop me from risin' up/Are you my nigga ? " )
Over melancholic bass lines a keyboard effect that is as somber as the bass lines themselves , Cormega reaches into the Heaven 's tries to connect with his deceased friends .
With complex , emotional lyrics that are as simplistic as they be incredibly deep rhyme-wise , you say Cormega is n't emotionally honest .
only is he incredibly serious melancholic in tone , his subject matter touched whoever is lucky enough to hear this brilliant track .
Emotionally lyricism is one thing , but crafting a great beat over poetic lyrics that craft more emotion than the production itself is stellar .
a doubt the introspection here is one of the many stand-outs on The Realness .
The following track , Glory Days , shines because of its original extremely well-produced beat it 's retrospective , professional lyricism .
Rap 's A Hustle is an original metaphorical track that uses the of pimping for emceeing .
' Mega 's pen is the prostitute he is the pimp ; this is an extremely original in of itself .
It does n't come as any surprise that the production is stellar .
Over a scarce drum loop , airy sound effects a keyboard-style background that gets your head nodding immediately , he kicks his original subject matter with faltering moments .
He drops the poetic elements for more Old School-styled lyricism which is slightly simplistic in the rhyme department but just listening to his great use of metaphors is a great listen in of itself .
As well , over a beat that is near perfect in every aspect makes the track all the much better ; a doubt this extremely fresh view of Hip-Hop is something that more Hip-Hop needs to utilize .
You Do n't Want It follows later on in the album is a better example of the battle raps you 'll find throughout The Realness .
Much in the same vein as Get Out My Way but lighter in tone , ' Mega spews venom Nas everyone of his other peers .
Over a piano arrangement a light drum loop , ' Mega drops insult truthful statements to verbally attack Nas with multi-syllabic rhymes a scheme that is both complex on-point flow-wise .
a doubt this even outweighs Nas ' diss to ' Mega , Mobb Deep Nature with Destroy and Rebuild from Stillmatic simply because he does n't use typical battle tactics but uses the honest truth .
' Mega does n't resort to immature insults but relies on great lyricism valid points to explain the situation with Nas , belittle him .
( "You wanna talk violent , but Sig P. 's for solution/ I stalk silent , when I proceed execution/Taught by the , realest niggas to walk the planet/With one you vanish , like the Corp. remanded/You on the Ave with your weak mans frontin'" )
The albums ends with the great freestyle 5 For 40 the introspective They Forced My Hand a classic remix to the already perfect Fallen Soldiers .
Even with the album appearing done , after about two minutes of waiting after the Fallen Soldiers ( Remix ) ends , another track starts up .
An ominous background starts up over a dark bass line , the sound of a record popping low vocals darken the track all the much more .
All three give a great performance with their own distinct flows subject matter for this particular topic .
Although it 's officially the album closer , the lyrics themselves leave a lasting impression leave the album on an extremely good note .
This is one of the greatest albums of all time ; I even go as far as to say it 's the modern day Illmatic .
Out of every one of the fourteen tracks , of them approach being weak are all stellar .
The outstanding lyricism , great subject matter fitting production makes this one of the greatest albums you 're to hear within the category of street poetics .

At last ... My survival in the Epinions community has reached its peak .
Big D has achieved what few have managed , the amazing feat of 150 reviews under his belt .
One that virtually everybody on this network of reviews loves enjoys .
One that is a classic by all ... what better album there be than Ras Kass 's golden classic Soul On Ice .
Albums by Jay-Z , Gangstarr , Mobb Deep , 2pac fueled our thirsts for hip hop , but both coasts were only split by rivalry , but split by style .
However , the west more jiggy gangsta , fueled by the emergence of Death Row Records Gangsta Rap .
Emcees like Dr. Dre , Eazy-E , Ice Cube , Snoop Doggy Dogg , Kurupt , 2pac were giving us the G-Funk style of hip hop .
However , it difficult to find any true competent advanced lyricists in the west .
With the exception of a cadre of underground lyricists Kurupt , there were really good lyrical masterminds from the west .
Along comes Ras Kass .
There was so much buzz surrounding the underground west coast hip hop scene in 1993 over this man that it is ridiculous .
At one point , he caught the eye of a record executive who listened to his Soul on Ice EP , immediately signed Ras for a deal .
It took a little under a year for Ras Kass to complete his first major label debut , entitled Soul on Ice , which was released in 1994 .
Ras Kass was on top of the world , until this album was pulled from stores for its extremely graphic , somewhat racial , controversial lyrics .
Unfortunately , it was put out of print very few real copies were left avaliable on the planet .
Unfortunately , many have heard this album , those who have consider themselves lucky , because Soul on Ice arguably be the most lyrical album in hip hop music... hands down .

Soul On Ice is labelled by many hip hop heads , myself included , to be lyricism at its finest .
Absolutely jiggyness , useless thug rhymes , money-flashing included here .
All you get is extremely well-written , thoughtful , socially conscious lyrics , with a blazing delivery , loaded with a plethora of metaphors , similes , wordplay , punchlines , a multi-syllable flow .
you dont that this is the most lyrical album , it definetely gets the trophy for most metaphor used within an album .
Because Ras Kass complex biblical scientific metaphors explode track after track , giving us a more advanced form of battle rapping braggadiocio , besides all of the intelligent , socially conscious , street-smart moments also included .
Ras Kass kicks it off with " On Earth As It is ..." .
On here , Ras Kass takes the battle rapping style of hip hop to a new plateau .
The first thing you notice is the deep , underground production chosen for this track , which is incredibly good .
Ras Kass gives us one of the most creative tracks ive ever heard , as he gives us a battle rap mixed with braggadiocio , loaded with biblical metaphors similes .
Seemingly every single punchline bar is loaded with a biblical metaphor , where he compares himself to a variety of religious figures , including Jesus Christ himself .
His unorthodox skills on the microphone guarantees that your jaw will drop listening to the lyrics more than once on this track .
Its clear that Ras does his research before writing a track having to resort to reading " Jiggyness 101 " " Sell-Out 101" .

" Anything Goes " is our first showcase of Ras Kass ' street poetry .
Ras gives us some tight verses about getting ahead of life .
He claims that everybody on the planet will do anything to get money , which sort of mocks a lot of people , including commercial rappers who sell-out for money .
Ras Kass ' metaphors insertions of battle rhymes complement the track perfectly .
Ras sort of admits to following the mentality of taking the easy , yet cheap , way through life , but mocks those who do it because he has gotten more advanced in his mind than he was at that time .
The production is well produced , featuring some harmonicly deep basslines , drum / clap loop , low-keyboard violins , some background vocals , which fit with the dark mood of the song the lyrics .
Another masterpiece .
" Marinatin' is next on Soul on Ice .
The instrumental is a slow-paced , jazzy sounding track with some flutes , snares , some synthesized keyboards , a triangle , drum loops a low bassline .
Ras Kass takes the west coast mentality of G-Funk inserts it into the track , rapping a slow song about a party , Ras Kass ' style .
However , do get this mistaken with commercialism , because this is the case .
Ras Kass vividly describes living the good life , very vividly , separates himself from the other west coast rappers with his use of metaphors , clever wordplay , similes , utilyzes a more in-tune multi-syllable flow for the third verse .
Ras continues the jazzy tunes with " Reelyishm" .
Ras Kass drops social commentary of himself , comparing himself to the current state of hip hop music , stating that he does n't care about selling records as long as he keeps it real true to the underground .
On the second verse , his lyricism improves using a more advanced scientific vocabulary a multi-syllable flow .
Ras raps about the streets at times , giving it a more street poetry .
The production is very simplistic , but fits the mood .
Featuring a loud clap , violins , a hard bassline , some old school RandB vocals for the chorus .

At last , we get to defining moment of Ras Kass career , of Soul On Ice , the single most controversial track in hip hop : " Nature of the Threat" .
To summarize it as best i , Ras Kass time travels back to the birth of humankind in itself , tracing the history all the way back to present day .
Ras Kass gives us a plethora of narratives covering the oppression of caucasian individuals / white people towards african american individuals basically the entire world .
Ras Kass raps about nearly all of the mistakes in the past , striking out with tons of a bunch of claims about changing the entire history of Jesus Christ , the Roman Age , the birth of the Smallpox / Aids Viruses , the myth about Thanksgiving .
This lone track has become a pure legend among hip hop heads worldwide .
Ras raps on this track , telling the entire story for nearly 8 minutes straight .
He mentions so many historical figures , too many to count on this particular review .
Ras Kass ' research for this track took months , his effort is extremely appreciate , even though some of the information is a bit off wrong , but way he makes you want to go to your local Public Library actually research these facts yourself , that is how much of an impact this song has .
When it comes to the basic hip hop elements , Ras is on point with top-notch lyricism , metaphors , similes , clever wordplay , a shining delivery .
The production is deep dark , driven by a recurring bassline , low-drums , church bells in the background .
This is a nominee for greatest hip hop track ever recorded , you 're looking for a lyrical sample . . sorry ... try ohhla.com ,
... then buy the album , which is what you 've done a long time ago .

Ras is extremely clever loves to use wordplay on this track , for a partion of the track , Ras uses some amazing alliteration , starting almost every word out with the letter " R" .
The production is more funky , with some vocal samples , scratching , synthesized bassline , flutes , drum / snare mix .

Simply because they are n't on a huge label have their videos on MTV , Zion I is criminally slept on .
The best thing about this CD is it 's wide appeal .
I already compared Zion I to Outkast on one song , but they deserve another comparison : both groups have a universal sound that appeal to both the average listener who simply turns on the radio to hear music , but by the same token both have more than enough artistic merit to please even the most picky , critical backpacker who listens to music simply because other people do n't know about it .
The big difference is EXPOSURE.
I guarantee Zion I sell millions of records the video they made for Revolution (B-Boy Anthem ) (yes , they have a video for it ) was given rotation on MTV , Trippin , One , Inner Light were played on major radio stations .
But enough about their .
Now I 'll talk about the actual reasons of why they 're good .
First off , we have the beats .
Amp Live turns in an extremely impressive performance on this album , putting his own personal spins on hip-hop drum bass .
I 've heard production like this before , but I sure as hell wish I had .
Next , the MCing .
Zion is n't the most complex MC you 'll ever hear , but every song he writes has a message .
Same thing for Amp Live Zion .
This album is a near-classic , my favorite overall album from 2000 , one of the most unique albums I 've ever heard .
Buy it immediately sooner .
Louis Logic has only been around for a short time .
He has released two CD-ROM's , "Music to Drink By : A Collection of Loosies Exclusives " "Debacle in a Bottle : a album" , two excellent releases that basically compile the whole of his discography in two goes , mainly composed of 12" singles , bootlegs , unreleased tracks exclusives .
The title "Sin-A-Matic" is itself a play on "cinematic" , in short Louis Logic decided to present the various "sins " he likes to indulge in , in a various number of creative cinematic ways .
Ironically , the opening cuts of " Sin-A-Matic " are typical of many modern rap albums - something that 's confusing at first . Louis Logic comes out swinging in his opening bars from the Sintro ; " My CD is diseased , please be cautious  each queasy chorus will leave ya nauseous  Each verse is equipped with evil forces  For teachin' your kids how to be remorseless " .
It 's a short freestyle introducing his album - a typical rap album feature - it gives you a good of his skill as an emcee ( check the multi's ) .
Louis then couples his braggadocio with blunt thoughts on the state of the rap game in the magnificent "Street Smarts" : " Whatcha cause ya neck ya wrist go bling  That ya sh !t do n't stink ?
Fa**ot asses doin' the Sisqo thing in a thong  Y'all ai n't had a inkling of thinkin' of bringin' it on  Take my advice shorty  Before I make your life story the sad sh*t RandB bit*hes sing in a song" .
This is one of the angriest songs on the album but most importantly it demonstrates his ridiculous flow hard-hitting wordplay , coupled with a distinctive voice .
But in an industry crammed full of imitation after imitation , Louis Logic does stand out .
The conceptual inventiveness that is found throughout " Sin-A-Matic " is unique .
Take " Freak Show" , an of the rapper's eccentric side , as he adjusts his vocal tone to a highly odd accent vividly describes all kinds of society's weirdos , over a minimalist , bouncy fairground-inspired beat .
"Fair Weather Fan" is one of my favourite songs , it finds Louis presenting both the views of several fans critics about his music his own response to these resulting criticisms , over Memo's wonderfully dark , computer-inspired beat .
The best most controversial song is undoubtedly "The Ugly Truth" .
Over another solemn , eerie beat this time crafted by The Record Collecter , Louis satirises the views of racist America by describing several minority races through mockery of standard racial stereotypes rhetoric .
He 's got one hell of an imagination ; his storytelling is on a par with Nas Ice Cube , the worlds he constructs are fantastical weird .
It follows that one of the main features of Louis Logic's philosophy towards life is that he does n't really take too much seriously ; you wo n't see much political social commentary Louis uses the creative side of his brain .
Spitting lines like "You see as much as I love pu**y  you ca n't feed it to me because I do n't eat anything that bleeds for a week do n't die" sporting ODB lines for the hook it 's a funny way at looking at typical subject matter .
yes , even when he switches up the subject matter , he avoids any laziness keeps the complexity of his rhymes .
"Dos Factuom" is just a beautiful song , as Louis describes a wild night out when heavily inebriated , alcohol is his other main passion .
What's best about this song , however , is the magnificent production by J.J. Brown , we're talking about lilting/JJ guitars a dreamy horn sample creating a really surreal atmosphere .
"Postal" has a wonderful switching beat ; starting off with cheeky trumpets a cavernous bassline then changing to a bouncy piano-blessed instrumental , which is great backing to a hilariously inventive story of two halves from Louis Logic about a fed-up bored office worker who eventually goes "postal" , a sly satire of a plague of modern American society .
The best of the best , though , is the wonderful lead single "Idiot Gear" .
Over one of the catchiest choruses keyboard loops I've heard for a long time , it 's like a distant cousin of Gang Starr's "Mass Appeal" (yeah , THAT good ) , Louis kicks fast flowing charismatic lyrics about why you want to find out about an ex-girlfriend's exploits with her past boyfriends .
Needless to say , the great production is simply only a continuation of J.J. Brown 's work on the rest of the album .

It is intended for adults .
I that one is offended by this opinion , they are , I sincerely apologize .
Let me preface this opinion by stating I have before had a problem with profanity in music .
I have always preferred to buy the unedited versions of CDs .
Having seen the video for " Get Your Roll On " on BET , I I 'd enjoy this CD.
Yet , when I listened to the same song on the CD , I was shocked .
It sounded like an almost completely different song .
A lot of my favorite artists use profanity in their lyrics .
However , I that there is a way to do it so it blends well in the music .
Big Tymers sprinkle curse words in their lyrics in places where only is it necessary , but it detracts from the rhythm .
of the lyrics flowing , as with Ice Cube Dr Dre , Big Tymers ' lyrics have a stutter quality to them that makes listening to the songs unenjoyable .
These lyrics were all taken from the song , " Get Your Roll On" .
That is the chorus , it is said four times .
The chorus is said many times throughout the song .
" Slap that b**ch ,
" Big d**ks we slang ,
" Your wife is ,
God d**n , mother f**ker ,
She 's a good d**k s**ker . "
While some rappers incorporate profanity into their songs in a way that is seamless does n't stand out , the Big Tymers have mastered the art yet .
They 've put profanity insults in their music in places that have flowed much better them .
This was proven by watching the video for " Get Your Roll On " on BET.
I had to get up dance in front of the TV .
The beats rhythm on the CD are still booming , such that you will want to dance to them bob your head to the music .
But you 're like me , you will wish there was a switch on your stereo that allow you to cut the lyrics out just listen to the rhythm .
The I got from this album is that Big Tymers were trying to copy Ice Cube Dr Dre other Gangsta Rappers ' styles , miserably .
you like Gangsta Hardcore Rap , read my review of Ice Cube 's new album , " War Peace : Vol 2 ( The Peace Album )" .
My recommendation on this album , " I Got That Work " by Big Tymers , is get the edited version , just pass it up , save the money that you worked for .

Since then , has recorded albums for several labels .
issues related to identity , having operated under several names personalities .
Employment record spotty , containing numerous periods of inactivity .
In commencing upon this effort , I came across his 1996 album Dr. Octagonecologyst , recorded under one of his many aliases , Dr. Octagon .
Upon listening to this album , I found myself deeply disturbed ; this patient be beyond my medical skills .
A conversation between a patient a doctor , this brief dialogue ( taken from what Mr. Thornton refers to as a "porn flick" ) demonstrates a disturbing preoccupation with sex , particularly in the highly unethical patient/doctor context .
Suspicion of hypersexual and/or sexually compulsive behavior .
Particularly of note : the repeated , echoing cries on the track of the female patient exclaiming , "fuck my pussy , doctor ! "
While his lyrical flow is quite competent , the assistance of Dan " The Automator " Nakamura on production , makes for an overall quality song , it to hide his clear case of dementia .
On " Earth People " , I see that his delusions are even more intense than previously .
Keith Thornton is convinced he is , in fact , from Jupiter .
He also to he is actually a doctor .
While he attempts to mask his delusions with clever lyricism more of Nakamura 's production skills , combined with DJ Q-Bert of Northern California 's Invisible Scratch Picklz work on the turntables , there is doubt : Thornton is most assuredly mentally troubled .
" Real Raw " to that Thornton has an inflated sense of self , filled with declarations of his superiority over others .
Additionally , it to a sub-conscious propensity for violence hidden behind his facade .
Evidence of this is further found in the track immediately preceding it , " Awareness" , which begins with an excerpt from a movie discussing cannibalism , leading into a song with a decidedly Wu-Tang Clan-like tone to it .
Note to self : make sure orderlies are made aware of subject 's for violence , are knowledgeable in the proper use of restraints .
" General Hospital " to be a continuing manifestation of Thornton 's delusional belief he is a doctor .
Showing blatant disregard for proper medical behavior , he proclaims a patient dead of chirrosis of the eye , a disease which does n't even exist .
I am increasingly troubled , curious as to what activities the patient was engaged in prior to treatment .
" Blue Flowers " , outside of the patient 's continuing belief he is a practicing surgeon his description of "green rain " , is unusually cogent , written during a more lucid period in his disease .
" Technical Difficulties " is the most obvious example present of the "word salad " typical of most disorganized schizophrenics .

Let's just face the facts at hand , even Obie Trice was a garbage rapper ( he is ) , he's packed by the Superman of Hip-Hop , the seemingly invincible Eminem - able to make death threats in 16 bars , pistol whip fools for jealousy , everything that Eminem touches really does turn gold .
From the promise that in several copies of his album are golden tickets to meet the blonde one ( why meet Obie ?
Oh yeah , one cares ) , to the cornball lead single , the sky is the limit .
The aforementioned lead single entitled "Got Some Teeth " is classic Eminem material , from its attempt at humor ( it ) , to its elementary lyrics : this is my favorite song / to sing along / when the deejay throws it on/ I leave here tonight I fall asleep/and wake up / hopefully she got some teeth" .
Right .
"Average Man" finds Obie busting more caps than the folks that don't like 50 Cent , which brings me to another important point : Hip-Hop is seeing the resurgence of thug mentality while there are plenty of artists on higher planes , the mainstream is so convoluted with thuggery ignorance that it 's enough to break my b-boy loving heart .
The bad boy persona continues with "Cheers" , a mediocre track that only be described as well , mediocre .
"Don't Come Down " has an ill sample , but then Obie had to go mess it up by rapping .
The parallels to Slim Shady continue with Obie's disdain for the woman who gave him life sadness for the hardships he experience growing up as a young ghetto youth , which is the only requirement for getting a record deal these days .
While Eminem does get the executive producer credit , his beats are just the swap meet equivalent of Dr. Dre's harder edgier material so all of the tracks produced by Em sound budget .

However , in 2001 , they all made the smartest moves in their careers , walked out on Cash Money Records , excluding Lil Wayne , who remained .
The Cash Money empire was all but destroyed as they released mediocre record in which even commercial fans were shunning .
The underground fans cheered as the downfall of one of hip hop 's horrible empires was destroyed worse than Rome .
These guys gave Hip Hop a bad name , it was only a matter of time before they fell .

Styles of Beyond is taking the of west coast rap hip hop in general giving it a 180 degree whirl .
With ample skills from both emcees backed by some of the most prolific dj 's producers of the underground , their unique take on hip hop is one to pay attention to .
While the duo does n't undertake anything as pretentious as rapping off then back on beat creating an unlisteneable , extremely busy production backing like that of the Def Jux label ( sorry ethompson3 , ) the sparse RZA like beats futuristic lyrical subject matter creates images of flying cars lunar colonization .
Formed in 1995 at a community college in L.A. where the duo met each other during break , the two formed an instant bond respect for each others skills .
Using techno-like , futuristic soundscapes skilled turntablism , the duo sounded like Jedi Mind Tricks on LSD.
Favorite Tracks
2. Styles of Beyond performed by Styles of Beyond / DJ Rhettmatic - 4:50

Worst Tracks
There are a couple filler tracks , but even those are entertaining in of themselves .
The Intro is a live track displaying Styles Of Beyond their collection of scratch tracks .
Nice intro , but ultimately it gets skipped .
The album gets kick started with the title track , Styles of Beyond Style Warz .
The production is heavily infuenced by RZA with a repetitive , wobbly bass line some piano keys looped over over .
However , this is an extremely entertaining track , aided by incredible turntablism vocal echo samples .
Lyrical imagery is what these two do best , this track fully emphasizes this concept .
Great track , but better ones up ahead !
With an eerie , piano loop liquid dripping along with an incredible , drum bass like bass-line , Hollograms remains my favorite track on the entire album .
Sampling Pharoahe Monch between verses , the duo continue with more futuristic imagery the two emcees display their lyrical dominance of the mic .
To me , the lyrics are like Canibus ' scientific braggadocio aspects but with a blend of imagined millenial forecasting ( that makes any sense . )
Example :

With a heavy breathing of a dying creature in the background as well as an eerie flute loop a la Apocalypse Now , the track is set up for some apocalyptic , futuristic lyrics .

Spies Like Us is an extremely entertaining concept .
Essentially , the two plot the spying on hip hop , eventually setting their goal as capturing taking it over .
The track production is as immediately engaging as previous tracks , but the genius is still there , with incredible wood flutes looping during the choruses .
WIth a sparse beat composed of repeating guitars a vocal sample , the track is minimalist in that RZA kind of way .
A symphonic sample is also included , engaging the listener ever more into the Styles of Beyond world .
The two emcee 's rep where they are from ; the Valley in Los Angeles .
However , the lyrics are n't as incredible as the earlier tracks because of their more straight forward approach .
Some like it , others , including me , do like it as much .
After these 5 excellent tracks , the album starts dragging a bit .
Muuvon engages the listener in a "head nodding " way , although the lyrics are second nature to the beat , which is a mish mash of speedy bass-heavy track-work .
After listening to it for a while , the listener gets sort of a headache .
This is one of the few track that the listener skip .
Besides the decent , loopy production , Easy Back It Up is more lyrical filler about women live shows .
Nothing misogynistic , but yet , just as dissatisfying .
However , Survival Tactics more than picks up the slack with an excellent track , both lyrically production wise .
With a surfer guitar strumming marracas wood block in the background , the track just screams " creativity . "
The lyrics are on point , using futuristic war storytelling as a metaphor for their live shows .
Gollaxwelcome takes the space/galaxy concept even further .
While a little bit loony , the production incorporates another futuristic Wu-Tang like loop some cowbell along with a stuttered bass-line .
Killer Instinct , their first single , as well as Marco Polo end the album on a positive note , with great production as usual lyrics that are on point .
Hurray for another great album !
Once upon a time there was a rapper named Nas .
He crafted a sheer hip-hop classic , one of the best albums of all time , called Illmatic in 1994 .
The album did n't succeed in sales , but dropped the jaws of hip-hop heads nationwide , as they Nas the savior one of the best ever .
In 1996 , he followed it up with It Was Written , a more mafiosio album , less riddled with Street Poetry .
Both of these emcees , along with Nas himself Foxy go on to form The Firm , a hip-hop super-group .
However , weeks after its inception , Cormega found himself kicked out the group replaced with the slightly weaker rapper Nature .
Cormega had choice but to go out on his own .
After a plethora of label problems , he felt it was hopeless , until 2001 when he released The Realness , in my opinion , a modern new-classic album .
Nas were still his friend , it make him extremely proud ...

" Dramatic Entrance " is a great opening track , but only food for " American Beauty" , the first real classic from The Realness .
Taking the age-old extended metaphor formula , started by Common on " I Used to Love H.E.R." .
Cormega uses his extended metaphoric skills to compare hip-hop music to a female .
His lyrics are some of the best of his career , as well as his delivery , as he shows some amazing vocabulary , a great flow .
The beat , is a soft , synthesized guitar sound , with claps bass stringed together perfectly .
Prodigy Cormega paint themselves like Mobb Deep have constantly on their classics , as street demons prophets , as well as graphic storytellers narratives .
The beat , though saddening melancholy , is beautifully put together , with a gripping , almost-mafiosio-styled cello snare , with a background whistle , some perfectly synthesized bass .
This beat be perfect for a mafia movie , but the lyrics are a bit far-fetched from that .
Cormega goes way back to his childhood , moving up into his teen years , questioning the true factors of loyalty honor in life .
The perfect beat amazing lyrics , mixed together with unique creative subject matter fuel this into being a Cormega Classic .
" Fallen Soldiers " is a touchy , very creative track where Cormega sort of prays at night time , talking to his very close friends who passed away due to the streets .
One interesting lyric pays homage to Killa Black Ill Will , whom Nas Mobb Deep constantly grieve .
Im guessing that the ties in Queensbridge are very strong .
The beat is melancholy deep , with a mixture of low-bass keyboard , some high synthesizer sounds .
This is an extremely honest track , he wastes a lyric on this entire track , which makes it another one of my personal favorites .
On this track , Cormega gives us a flashback of his childhood youth as we get retrospective storytelling about his childhood , which he loved , yet hated due to his involvement in the streets .
This track is perfect for a nice underground single , ' Mega 's lyrics are SO well-written , thoughtful , descriptive , than i actually visualize everything he was talking about , you KNOW a song makes you do that , its a classic .
" Rap 's a Huscle " is strikingly similar , only on this track , Cormega fast-forwards to more recent events , as Cormega uses his extended metaphor skills once again , comparing hip-hop to huscling pimping on the streets .
Of course , as you guess , Cormega lays down some verbal attacks towards his enemies on The Realness , namely his former teacher Nasir Jones , aka Nas .
On " Get out of my Way " " You Do n't Want it " , Cormega attacks Nas with his lyrics .
The beat features an amazing assortment of classical elements , like violins , trumpets , hard bass drums , giving it an epic .
The second track is much more straight-forward as we actually hear the N-A-S being called out .
Firstly , the track 's beat is a sombre , saddening piano beat , with a light , old school drum / snare .
Secondly , Cormega annihilates Nas lyrically .
The complex , multi-syllabalistic , vocabulary , amazing punchlines threats .
Cormega gets intelligent , as he makes some very good points about Nas ' career the fact that it is loaded with hypocrisy .
" 5 for 40 " is an accapella freestyle , very well spat deserving of 4 stars .
" They Forced My Hand " closes out The Realness ( besides the remix ) .
Ironically , this is my favorite song on the entire album .
The beat is epic loud , with some haunting beautiful RandB background vocals , a beautiful piano loop , violins , hard bass , drums .
Cormega solidifies his spot as one of the illest poets emcees in history , giving us an introspective view of the streets , its darkness , but begs for , thinks it happen .
doubt , beautiful .
This is a hauntingly evil , yet perfect way to end The Realness .
The Realness be the best album of 2001 , in fact , it is , one of the greatest of all time .

Many people who listen to hip-hop , even underground hip-hop , have absolutely clue who the Demigodz are .
The Demigodz have been hailed as the new comical version of the Wu-Tang Clan .
Its pretty interesting that they compose an entire label with just these emcees .
Each emcee has his own personality style , but they honestly are all ill emcees who have competed won a variety of battle competitions .
The Demigodz are : the humorous Apathy , who has been hailed as the new Eminem , Celph Titled , Open Mic , Louis Logic , complex intelligent emcee Esoteric , Rise , El-Fudge , Spin 4th , One-Two , Motive .
The DJs are 7L , Chum the Skrilla Guerilla , Franky Needles .
These 13 individuals make up the Demigodz .
In 2002 , they released an underground EP entitled The Godz Be Crazy , which is just a taste of what is in store from these emcees .

Remix albums are usually pointless exercises by a record company to bleed loads of money out of unsuspecting fans into pockets of artists-and moreso , the labels themselves .
Since the remix album exploded in 1989-90 with the likes of Bobby Brown , Paula Abdul the New Kids , there have n't been many remix albums that are average , at best .
This is basically a souped-up greatest hits album .
While some of his hits enjoy a slight adjustment in beat , of these songs is extraordinarily different than te original version , which is a good a bad thing .
you 're like me the man has a couple of hot singles , it 's an OK buy because it means you do n't have to buy of his middling-to-weak albums .
I 'll be the first to admit I 'm a Nelly hater , but he grew on me very slowly .
I respect the dude because he has his own style , he 's afraid to admit that he 's the greatest MC in the world , but he has his own little niche .
Of course , his success far outweights his artistry , but how many artists we say that of ?
hey , the dude wants to make you dance , he 's relatively inoffensive , he does n't traffic into the super-violent and misogynist cliches that most other popular MC 's fall into .
Some of the remixes leave very little unchanged from the original version .
" Country Grammar" , Nelly 's breakout hit , is exactly the same as the original version with one minor alteration in the chorus as well as a verse from E-40 , the hip-hop king of "what the f*** is that dude saying ? " .
" Dilemma " " Work It " add slightly harder beats ( courtesy of Jermaine Dupri Scott Storch ) respectively .
JD brings up Nelly 's vocal , which is almost buried into the mix on " Dilemma 's " studio version , while Nelly alters his flow on " Work It" , which was originally a pretty decent party anthem but now is only interesting because of Justin Timberlake 's best Michael Jackson impression to date .
" E.I. " is remixed by crunk king David Banner , Banner 's rock-etched production is the standout on a couple of tracks here .
He takes it back to the old-school Rick Rubin Casio-drumbeat loud guitar days on this one , despite its ' somewhat sexist refrain of "is that yo ' a** cuz it ai n't yo face " plastered throughout the song .
For whatever reason , it twice on this set .
The album 's two best songs are the most chilled-out tracks here , giving Nelly more of an RandB than a hip-hop vibe .
" Pimp Juice " coasts along on a jazz-kissed soul background with some sultry sax a guest vocal by the legendary Ron Isley .
" Groovin' Tonight " is all about Brian McKnight 's great guest vocal .
However , that 's about it for the good stuff here .
Originally produced by The "tunes also , this remix is helmed by Nelly 's in-house production team , does n't really change the song a whole lot .
How many hip-hop albums do you know that feature a shout out to my " n*gga John Mayer " ?
This reconstruction liberally lifts from mayer 's breakout hit " Such Thing" , while it 's weird to hear Nelly twisting the melody of Mayer 's hit , some experiments are best left untried .
This album also loses cool points for the annoying-*ss interview skits that throughout the album .
of Nelly 's two studio albums is exactly a classic , so I actually recommend this album to folks who want the hit singles wanting to spring for " Country Grammar " "nellyville " .
These songs are n't so radically changed that you 'll miss the original versions-well , most of 'em anyway .
Buy this only you own nothing else by Nelly want his hit singles .

Nope .

As the years pass , it changes , more more white people like rap .
Why ?
It has altered some of its style sound to accomodate others .

From Justin Timberlake to Nelly , Ludacris to Britney Spears , to everything else on your FM dial : you know a Neptunes track when you hear one .
The Neptunes are by far the hottest producers in hip hop , putting their stamp on the industry by making hot joints for nearly every major artist out right now .
From every corner of pop hip pop , the music industry 's envelope has been pushed by the forward thinking of super producers Pharrell Williams Chad Hugo .
With their recent release , " The Neptunes Present : Clones , " the Neptunes showcase up-and-coming artists from their Star Trak label while getting help from some of the hottest names in hip hop , making for a killer compilation of fresh beats featuring the Neptunes ' signature sound .
Busta spits verse after verse about seriously lighting a girl 's backside aflame over a hypnotic dance beat .
With a catchy chorus , N.O.R.E.
Pharrell himself on a number of tracks , including his own single , " Frontin " featuring Jay-Z.
But the album is less focused on Pharrell anyone else 's vocals ; the beats outshine most of the verbal performances on " Clones , " with a few exceptions .
Ludacris spits fluidly on " It Was n't Us , " a track featuring a broken hip hop beat reminicent of his early Neptunes-blessed track , " Southern Hospitality . "
The song is only a standout in terms of the Neptunes ' contribution ; it is also one of the few on the album that have lyrics solid enough to accompany the amazing beat .
Nas also comes through on " Popular Thug , " with his vocals perfectly balancing those of his bride-to-be , Kelis .
The lovebirds provide a notable chemistry on another song with lyrical matching to an above-average beat .
Snoop Dogg also spits a classic ode to chronic over a smooth bell-laced beat on " It Blows My Mind . "
Other noteworthy performances include two cuts by The Clipse on " Blaze of Glory " " Hot Damn , " an odd track by Dirt McGirt ( formerly Old Dirty Bastard of Wu Tang Clan ) .
New Star Trak artists Rosco P. Coldchain ( to be confused with Young Roscoe ) Fam Lay also put down lyrics while of the cuts are skippers , they are n't as solid as those done by the veterans ( Snoop , Nas , Ludacris ) .
However , Vanessa Marquez drops impressive vocals on " Good Girl , " a cut with a great '80s early '90s .
Hip hop heads wish to bypass the diversity on " Clones , " via the three rock contributions found mid-album .
Also slightly out of place , the Neptunes themselves , in the form of their experimental genre-breaking group N*E*R*D , add an odd track , " Loser . "
The song will be featured on the Madden 2004 video game .
While the beats fall short , some of the lyricism does .
Nelly proves it 's hard to ruin a Neptunes beat on his effort " , " a song that borrows it 's chorus from a previous Nelly tune .
Similarly , Rosco P. Coldchain misses the mark on " Hot , " a song with a minimalist beat that allow an emcee to truly display his skills .
While The Clipse hold their own on the track , Rosco to impress .
" Clones " be ill were released as a pure instrumental album , but the performances of a few of the most seasoned veterans in the game add greatly to the overall appeal of the Neptunes ' skillful display of hit making .
With " Clones , " the Neptunes certainly secure their spot as one of the most influential progressive collective minds in music .
They provide a solid foundation of beats from start to finish on " Clones ; " the lyrics hold up to the track is another story .
One thing is for sure : as solid is as a Neptunes beat is , it 's difficult for any artist to ruin their genius , despite the content of the lyrics .
When it comes to a killer beat , the nNptunes got it on lock .
The special edition release also includes a DVD with videos " Frontin , " " Hot Damn " " Rock N Roll " interviews with the Neptunes .
Unfortunately , the disc wo n't work on my computer 's DVD player .
Coming out of the streets of New York city , through Chicago , as a former member of the Mental Giants crew , hot off the success of the lead single on the LP , " Hot Ya Hot" , Akbar has released his debut full length on Ill Boogie Records , the imprint of production/DJ guru M-Boogie .
Akbar means " the greatest " in Arabic , so right off , this kid had better have skills , because it 's obvious he has cockiness in spades .
In terms of vocal style , Ak sounds pretty generic , a lot like any of the hundreds of MC 's that have tried to ply their craft coming out of NY .
So does it work ?
Let 's check it out .
***
1)Hip Hop Is ...
As the title , a basic track giving a breakdown on what Akbar thinks hip hop is .
Some nice cuts provided by Fredones , the lyrics are on point too , with Ak using a laidback , Nas-like flow to give his thoughts on hip hop .
A great opener .
" Hip hop is
A style that 's wild
A ghetto child looking for a reason to smile
Hip hop is
The application of street knowledge
Some ill cuts intro the track here , as M-Boogie makes his first production appearance on the LP.
He provides a moderately paced beat with a funky bass line , some nice 70 's sounding organ synths , with scratches interspersed throughout the beat .
Ak decides to take on wack MC 's on this track , spitting some serious venom in their direction .
His voice be a bit generic , but he is REALLY good with his flow... I mean SERIOUSLY good .

The Demigodz ; first of all , what exactly is a Demigod ?
According to Webster himself , he states that a Demigod is a person who is partly divine' .
that is really the case , then this group of 10+ MCs be hiding their latent skills until the LP drops .

Heads unfamiliar with the name Defari have been paying much attention to the resurgence of West Coast Hip-Hop over the past few years .
A deejay-turned-teacher-turned emcee , Defari Herut has gained respect in Hip-Hop the old-fashioned way , through skill , hard work , determination .
With high-profile verses on Dr. Dre's Chronic 2001 Dilated Peoples much-admired 2001 release , Expansion Team hipping a larger audience to Defari , the artist returned to the lab to craft his new album , Odds and Evens .
Duane Johnson ' as a major fixture in the West's rap scene from this moment on .
Having survived a long turbulent career , Defari has beaten the odds ; now it 's time to get even .
Since it 's an album from a member of the Likwit Crew , you know you collaborations with Tha Liks , Defari definitely delivers in this department on Odds and Evens .
Featuring lyrics production by E-Swift , "Inner City " is a great album opener .
Tash brings his inexhaustible energy to "Xtra Thump , " the perfect personality for taking Fredwreck's archetypal keyboard-crafted party anthem to a higher level of rowdiness .
Likwit Crew member Phil Da Agony also manages to jump in a session for "Stay Bubblin , '" though he have been better waiting for a different song to on .
The production work on this is far too innocuous to properly complement the combined venom Agony Defari lay down , killing the collabo's .
With vocals that almost cry out hard drums a grinding bassline , hopefully a remix will pop up as a bonus on a later release .
However , the Likwit Crew are the only ones to bless Odds and Evens with an appearance ; Dilated Peoples makes their presence felt on one of the singles from this album , the remix of "Behold My Life . "
Defari reminisces , "behold my life , a deejay turned emcee/ T La Rock It's Yours ' blew my m-i-n-d/ made me want to be the D-to-the-E/ crowned 310 king of Los Angeles city . "
Despite the impressive roster of guest artists , Defari is certainly capable of tearing down the mic any collaborators does so often .
He continues the hostilities with "Spell My Name , " the lead single , co-produced by Evidence Porse .
Musically , Ev Porse's work sounds a bit like a fresher rendition of some of Dr. Dre's best work ; a defiant march with critical musical points fortified supplementary samples , including a strangely appealing blubbery trombone .
a doubt , Odds and Evens is a nothing less than stellar release for Defari .
The production is excellent , pulling some of the sharpest beats from respected names relative unknowns ( hell , Alchemist's cuts even made it onto the final release , you won't miss em ) .
Evidence proves to be just as solid an asset behind the boards for Defari as he is on the mic for DP ; his remarkable production work here only heighten the anticipation of Dilated's next effort .
Lyrically , Defari knows exactly how to complement the beats with a versatile dexterous flow , rocking rhymes that blend only the best of Cali Hip-Hop , aggressive the trite gangsta posturing , fun-loving but with an undeniable sense of responsibility .
Even Defari has long since abandoned teaching as a profession , his new album Odds and Evens proves that there's still much to learn from this man .
Nia , meaning purpose , is one of the seven principles of Kwanzaa .
It is defined as making our collective vocation the building of our community to restore our people to their traditional greatness .
This is the principle upon which Blackalicous members Chief Xcel Gift of Gab built Nia , a masterpiece highlighting the fusion of soul , jazz , poetry , hip-hop , while still maintaining a dedication to positivity which is in so much of today's music .

The fourth track " Deception " tells the fictional tale of an aspiring hip-hop artist whose immediate success causes him to lose perspective , as a result , leads to his downfall .
To reinforce the theme , the group recites " Don't let money change you " as the hook .

" A to G " was obviously designed to display Gift of Gab's lyrical precision .
In this song , a sample is played which announces a letter of the alphabet , from the letter A to G. Then the rapper freestyles several bars using that letter , manages to make a point rhyme , despite the limits of alliteration .
It's great to listen to a true MC go to work .
" Cliff Hanger " is a throwback to the days of classic hip-hop , when MCs did n't have to take themselves so seriously .
The song reminds me of Special Ed's " I'm on a Mission " other songs along that vein , where the rapper takes on the role of a protagonist in some fantasy/espionage/sci-fi tale .
In this one , Gift of Gab becomes " The Chosen One " , a warrior who was chosen to wield a mystical sword vanquish evil from some foreign land .
The beat is very catchy the lyrics are so descriptive that the listener almost see the tale unfold .
In my opinion , poetry has a natural place on a hip-hop album .
Rap's lyrical delivery follows poetic form , so the two often work very well together .
Lyricist Lounge Vol . 1 , Black Star , Killah Priest all had great works of poetry on their albums , Nia does as well .
On Ego Trip by Nikki Giovanni , Blackalicious takes a recitation of Nikki Giovanni's poem sets it over a laid back drum and bass hook .
The words flow effortlessly over the beat for a very pleasing effect .
" Shallow Days " soulfully relays the message of the need for positivity in hip-hop music culture .
Poignant observations of life are shown in " As the World Turns " .
Classic battle raps permeate " Trouble ( Eve of Destruction ) " All these many other songs contribute to one of the most original rap albums I have ever heard .
I honestly find anything to say about Blackalicious ' Nia , that there be a lot more albums out there like it .
Give this one a listen , you will be disappointed .

My roommate is into the whole "jiggy " rapper routine I am decidedly against it .
Let me tell you , whatever "hot " is , it has to be synonymous with "crap. "
My tastes lie in the underground , where most true hip hop artists remain .
These artists see the success that mainstream rappers have , which good bad at the same time .
Usually when a hip hop artist sticks to the underground , they stick with what got them into the game in the first place (usually thoughtful rhymes , but always . )
When one of these artists decides to jump the ladder into mainstream acceptance , they drop any resemblance of a hip hop artist become whor*s of the music industry , molding themselves to what sells .
I have developed a step by step theory by which hip hop artists follow in order to change into jiggy rappers .
Basically , what it takes to become a mainstream rapper nowadays is :
a ) Catchy , jiggy , club friendly beats ( 50 Cents " In Da Club " comes to mind ) .
That's the step by step process .
Of course everyone makes it every mainstream rapper is like this , but typically , this outline is pretty all encompassing .
Examples abound of such rappers .
One such rapper is Fabolous .
His album Street Dreams is an example of a mainstream creation .
Remember the process , ladies gents , you'll see it comes in very handy .

so with the Arsonists .
Going from a sprawling group of five original members , to a smaller three , actually helps the flow makes the album a much more consistent showing .
The original Arsonists release titled " As The World Burns " was essentially a mish-mash of old material recorded since 1993 up to 1999 the variance in production skill throughout that time period is overwhelming .
The original five was cut to just three , Jise , Q-Unique , Swel 79 .
These three MC 's released the album " Date of Birth" , a much more thorough unique listen than the original .
Lyrically , the three play off of each other very well , seemingly finding a perfect fit .
Usually an intro on modern hip hop records is purely there for album filler , but even this trend is torched by the Arsonists .
" Date of Birth " summarizes the new Arsonist sound keeps the listener updated on the trials tribulations of the crew .
Introducing all three MC 's style it makes for a moving foray .
" Stay Lo" , the second track on the album is a total destruction of mainstream rap the platinum status achieved by many such artists .
" A million sold do n't make you pro " Jise alerts .
The beat is pretty standard affair it takes a backseat to the lyrics , as it .
The next two tracks are just as good as the second one , continuing to scorch mainstream rap moving towards a hip hop nirvana .
Nirvana is reached on
" Language Arts " an absolutely incredible track .
Using traditional Japanese kabuki theater strings with a deep bass beat along with some scratching .
The lyrics surprisingly are the main focus because the production is so truly innovative .
Its something you witness to .
Nothing on the album reaches the perfection achieved by " Language Arts " " Alive" , but the overall album is up there among the best underground releases of 2001 .
I recommend this release to anyone who likes to hear more than just the typical gangsta "bling bling " mentality .
Sad to that this group will always remain beneath mainstream radar , reaching more than a cult status , but then again , is n't that the point ?
Zion I is a group of 3 men : MC Zion , producer Amp Live , DJ K-Genius .
Their futuristic sound is one I have yet to hear reproduced .
They originate from Atlanta have since moved to Oakland .
An incredible club-banger that has MC Zion dropping pure hiphop lyrics that talk about everything there is while still making it a party track .
The production is revolutionary .
Scratching , violin sounds , a chopped bassline .
I usually prefer high-vocabulary strewn lyrics but this music is hip-hop as its very purest .
The next song , " Critical " has lyrical mad-man Planet Asia trading verses about the mission of the emcee over a beat that sounds like the whole song is a sample , the way it thumps repeats stops .
To quote Planet Asia , " My brother hit me on the game/Said that we original man/And we manifested here to spit slang/ I a minute , let it sink /Deep like the Titanic /We wider than the ocean of Atlantic/Pacifical mythical styles / In the west it 's gettin' wild/ I 'm chillin' like the Sphinx upon the Nile/
Reverberating/ Why is you hatin' hip hop we creatin ?/Across the desert sands we be bakin'/My melanin/The key to lock rock spots flocks /Walk the rugged avenue with my B-Boy bop/It 's evolution toss a pebble at the devil smile/
I 'm rebellion while propelling freestyles " Sure , it haphazard at first , but you need to understand the state of mind these emcees are entering to comprehend .
The beat to come straight out of that region of the world , with flutes the sound of what be some kind of magic dust being dropped .
But this supernatural vibe does n't last forever as the truth of reality strikes us .

" Dark streets/swoll feet/where massive trash heeps/You speak/Most weep/SORROW/runs deep/Pain/Escape through cocaine .. . " he goes on in a staccato tempo that freakishly embodies the city 's moral horrors .
I 'm from NYC this song always hits me when I hear it .

I ca n't find another word .

you 've been alive for the last 15 years so , you have at some point encountered MC Hammer 's smash hit single U Can't Touch This .
Based upon the bass guitar riff from Superfreak , the jivey little number was a massive hit worldwide , was once voted the greatest song of the 1980 's .
It to appeal to just about everybody : matter which audience I play it to , it to go down well amongst everybody .
Accompanying this ditty was the album Please Hammer Do n't Hurt Em , in which MC Hammer takes a stand against all the issues of the day .
Basically , this is the quintessential rap album of the age .
In the liner notes , as with most of the disc , he rants about racial discrimination a mixed bag of other capitalist society flaws .
You will find yourself grooving to songs you know you hate , just for the retro effect .
In the fun little intro Here Comes The Hammer , he raps about the album you 're about to experience in what is basically the bridge to U Can't Touch This .
After that track comes the slow moving romantic number Have You Seen Her ? , the only one of it 's type on the album .
Yo! ! Sweetness with a rather redundant second exclamation mark , is a very beat-heavy ( hell , the whole album is beat-heavy ) track with men chanting about a "sweetness " across the room .
On Your Face , Dancing Machine , Pray , Crime Story Black Is Black are exactly the same : like Janet Jackson in Rhythm Nation 1814 , MC Hammer complains about all the difficulties facing modern Western society , racial discrimination in particular , to way too many beats fairly crappy lyrics .
He even contributes a series of preachy poems to the booklet about these topics .
She's Soft Wet Work This are also the same : There's a girl .
She's hot , eh ? Yes , she is .
She certaintly is .
Let me explain why this is so .
So , you buy Please Hammer , Don't Hurt Em ?
While it 's one of the essential rap albums of the day , it comes across very dated cheesy , so No.
However , you get your hands on Please Hammer at garage sale prices , a single of U Can't Touch This , make sure to pick it up : Can't Touch is a must-have for every music collection !
Boston rapper Ray Benzino is one Hip-Hop's most puzzling enigmas .
This year , the rapper returns to try to capitalize on his hit with his latest solo album , Redemption .
Will the album redeem Benzino in the eyes of those who doubt the validity of his career to begin with ?
.
Track Listing
1 . Stayin 4eva
2. Call My Name feat .
Mario Winans
4 . You feat .
Mario Winans and Lisa Raye
5 . Make You Wanna Holla
6 . Neva Shuvin' feat .
Wyclef and M3
7. Gangsta's Touch feat .
Cadillac Tah and Black Child
8. Redemption ( Rosary ) feat .
Fatal Hussein and Kid Juvi
9 . X-Tra Hot feat Daz Dillinger and Jewel
10 .
I Remember feat .
11 . Get It On
12 . 44 Cal .
Killa feat .
Scarface and M3
13 . Hoola Hoop
14 . Different Kind of Lady
15 . Pull Your Skirt Up
Mario Winans , Lil Kim , and Petey Pablo
He's already scored a major success with "Rock the Party , " a lively track reminiscent of Busta Rhymes Missy Elliot's wild club hoppers , showcasing syncopated jungle beats warbling synth chords .
Ray takes more shots at a lame club hits on the grinding "Get It On , " dancehall derivative "Hoola Hoop. "
Fully cognizant of the importance of appealing to the XX-chromosome demographic , Redemption has two softer compositions for the ladies .
" I Remember " exudes a sentimental with Ray ruminating over a relationship .
Conversely , "Different Kind of Lady " is Benzino's dedication to his current love , but with a twist in the lyrics that Hip-Hoppers have seen repeatedly since Common 's " I Used to Love H.E.R. " Though certainly the first thespian to make an appearance on a rap CD , it 's still unexpected to hear actress Lisa Raye ( The Players Club , The Wood ) share the mic with Ray on yet another variation on the Bonnie and Clyde love song theme , "Would You . "
picking up a thing two from her time as a host on the Source : All Access television magazine , Raye sounds almost natural in the spirited duet , though the likelihood of a solo career resulting from this collabo is negligible .
To be sure , there are actually a few genuinely tight tracks on Redemption .
"Gangsta's Touch " shows the true of Benzino's Hangmen 3 production squad ( Benzino , Jeff Two Times , JB) with a forceful head-nodder featuring live drums , flowing orchestral strings , harsh funk guitars .
Featured emcees Cadillac Tah Black Child are nice with their rhymes , but Benzino comes through with some truly forgettable lyrics .
remarkably , the weakest track on this disappointing effort is the manufactured diss track aimed at Eminem , called "Pull Your Skirt Up. " It's still why Benzino really decided contrive this battle between he Em .
He claims it 's because Slim Shady is a white so-called "culture stealer " denoting his use of Hip-Hop to obtain success in mainstream audiences .
However , when the purported "bible of Hip-Hop" Zino co-owns has recently dedicated itself too flooding its pages with bling bling half-naked chicks galore , to mention the fact that the other co-owner is white , what weight does his argument really have ?
The beef most is nothing but a tool for Benzino to coax a few more units of Redemption off the shelves , promote the "Hip-Hop Is Under Attack " articles in upcoming issues of The Source .
the overall wretchedness of "Pull Your Skirt Up" reflects this flimsiness of argument .
The song is nothing but a poorly put together arrangement of marginally insulting couplets aimed at Slim Shady over a washed out rendition of Nas ' original Jay-Z assault "Ether . "
satisfied to spew only at Em , the Boston rapper stings together anemic assaults on Obie Trice D12 , but wisely sidestepping 50 Cent .
this is the kind of "saving " Hip-Hop needs , then the culture truly is doomed .
Redemption by Ray Benzino is nothing less than a prime example of why The Source magazine longer is taken seriously in regards to Hip-Hop music culture .
one of the chief figureheads at the mag seriously believes that this album passes as a credible effort , there's way the issues in anyway be representative of anything Hip-Hop .
While many do dream of being a high profile rap star , many also dream of being a co-owner of a major rap publication .

Dr. Dre had managed to disentangle himself from the talons of Suge Knight Death Row Records .
Dre had started his own label , Aftermath , was ready to sit back , renounce his gangsta image watch the money roll in .
So out he came with this Aftermath sampler compilation , we did n't hear from him again for three years .
The reason ?
The album more less sucked , Dre 's midas production touch was on most of the four five songs he actually had a hand in .
It 's a shame , too , because the one Dre track on the album , " Been There , Done That , " is really good .
( " I 've got a palace in the hills overlooking the sea / It 's worth eight , but I only paid 5.3." )
An entire post-gangsta Dre album in this vein have sold through the roof , but alas , he had n't the creative energy for it .
The other album highlights be summed up in a couple paragraphs .
KRS-One , Nas B-Real of Cypress Hill perform under the name Group Therapy with " East Coast / West Coast Killas , " a Dre-produced track that picks up where " Natural Born Killas " left off .
The vocal trade-offs are seamless , the bass is solid the whistling Dre synth is bad@ss as ever .

Our upstairs cordless phone was near death .
Time to go phone shopping .
I was attracted to of the new expandable cordless phone systems ... the kind with a single base station the ability to add several handsets .
The many benefits of such systems include the ability to use the handset base stations as intercoms the ability to transfer calls from one handset to another .
Those items are just the beginning of the long list of cool features of the Panasonic KX-TG5110M.
There are two ways you buy this phone system .
The first is as a package with the base station one handset ( Model KX-TG5100M) .
You also buy a package that contains the base station TWO handsets ( Model KX-TG5110M) , which you usually find for around $ 265 .
This is a good deal , because the individual handsets sell for $ 79-89 each .
you know you need more than one handset , definitely try to find the two-handset package , save yourself a few bucks .
When I was buying , Circuit City Best Buy carried the two-handset package .
Sears Amazon.com
I bought mine from Amazon.com .
THE TECHNICAL STUFF
This phone system works in the new 5.8 GHz frequency range .
Also , you have an 802.11b wireless computer network in your house building , that works on the 2.4 GHz frequency range , it cause interference with that kind of phone system .
In my experience , it works flawlessly ...
This phone really sounds exactly like a good corded phone .
At my house , the range is about the same as what I got with my previous 900 MHz phone .
I go outside on the front porch , but I venture about 30 feet down the driveway , the reception goes away quickly .
Inside the house , there are dead spots , reception is flawless , both upstairs downstairs .
THE BASE STATION
The base station is a sleek , attractive compact unit with a large LCD screen that displays its many functions .
Unlike Panasonic 's 2.4 GHz models , which come in gaudy shades of purple silver , these phones have an attractive , businesslike platinum color .
The LCD screen displays caller ID info , your phone book , which store up to 50 numbers , the interface for the digital answering system , the menus that you use to set up the phone 's features .
The display is backlit , large , with nice big readable text .
There is a large circular , 4-way rocking navigation control which allows you to scroll through your phone book , caller ID list , as well as menus .
The base station be used stand-alone as a speakerphone there is handset handy .
HANDSETS
The KX-TG5110M system handle up to eight handsets .
Even though the screen is smaller , the handset contains fewer buttons , you perform nearly all of the functions on the handset that you on the base station .
Most of the buttons on the handset are backlit , light up when you touch any button .
MINOR GRIPE # 1 : For some reason , Panasonic did backlight the four most important buttons ( Talk , Speakerphone , Off , Hold ) .
The handsets are solidly built , good in your hand .
They are a little larger than those on some of the competing phones , but I 'm bothered by that .
The center of the handset has a rocking joystick-like navigation control , which performs the same functions as the big one on the base station .
MINOR GRIPE # 2 : For some reason Panasonic labeled some of the buttons with slightly different names ... for example on the base station there is a button labeled " Hold/Clear " .
There is an equivalent button on the handset , but it 's called " Erase " .
They both do the same thing , but they have different names .
Needless confusion .
It is really loud , but it does work , it beats holding the phone to your ear while you 're on hold for 45 minutes .
Headset fans plug in to a jack on the side , use the included belt clip .
Each handset is an intercom that call any all of the other handsets the base station .
you answer an outside call , you want to transfer the call to another handset , it 's really easy to do so .
The base station has a handset locator button , so you find that handset that got buried under the dirty laundry .
It is to use up to 4 handsets the base station simultaneously in a conference call .
A handset also be used as a baby monitor , but I guess that that eat up your battery pretty quickly .
One really cool feature is that you transfer an entire phone book list an individual phone book entry from any handset the base station to any other handset .
MAJOR COMPLAINT # 1 : Panasonic decided to use NiCad handset batteries with this phone , of the much superior NiMH batteries .
Many reviewers had complaints about poor battery life , charging memory problems with Panasonic 's 2.4GHz line , this new model was an opportunity for them to fix that by using better batteries .
I 've seen reviews elsewhere that say that the batteries do work better on these phones , but time will tell .
The handset also has a signal booster mode , which you turn on when reception becomes iffy .
It give you a little more range , but it also cuts down on your battery life .
THE ANSWERING SYSTEM
The base station contains a digital answering system that supports an outgoing message of up to 3 minutes , 15 minutes of message recording time , all digitally recorded .
The system has three separate voice-mail boxes ( which is perfect at our house , because there are three of us ) .
You use your outgoing message to instruct callers to hit pound-1 to talk to Dad , pound-2 to talk to Mom , etc. .
Messages for any of the mailboxes be retrieved at the base station on any of the handsets .
A flashing indicator on the LCD lets you know which mailboxes contain fresh messages .
All messages have a time/date stamp .
There is an option for slowing down the playback of messages .
The system uses flash memory , so the power goes out , you do n't lose your messages .
The answering system works just the way you 'd it to , it 's very intuitive to use .
CONCLUSIONS
I long hard before spending this kind of dough on a phone .
But when you balance that high price against the long list of great features that you use every day , along with excellent build quality , great sound , good looks , ease of use , the Panasonic KX-TG5110M becomes a solid choice .
I compared it to the even more expensive Siemens systems , found it to be a better choice .
After using it for a few weeks , I do n't regret the purchase at all .
you 're looking to buy a really nice an honestly good 5.8GHz system with some very nice features , then seriously consider this one you do n't mind the price .
Bought the system a few weeks ago with 2 extra hand sets for a total of 4 hand sets .
Although our home is big we do enjoy having the option of several hand sets .
Its one of those "why did n't anyone of this before " options .
This system replaced another one that we bought at a local discount club , which was horrible much hated from the moment it was connected .
have know better since the price was $ 60 for three a hand set system .
A good example of you get what you pay for .
Before deciding on this system I seriously was looking at the Seimens system came 'oh-so-close ' to buying it .
But something told me to look a little further then I found this system .
The Seimens system looks really sleek but all the reviews are neutral , in some cases very .
This gives me interference what so ever with the wireless network in the house , which was a major gripe with the older 900 MHz system we had .
you home requires more then you have enough money to install a professional system .

We used to own a Siemens 2415 , a predecessor to the 4215 .

In case anyway reading this is aware , getting a 2.4Ghz 5.8Ghz digital cordless is very different to getting an analog cordless phone .
Analog phone call quality is typically poorer will degrade the further away from the base station you get .
You also notice they have more visible antenna on both the base the phone .
The other often missed difference is the security of your calls .
Its just too easy to receive analog telephone calls using something as cheap as a baby monitor !
You be able to listen into a digital cordless transmission as easily .
The phone is packed with all the features you , directory , caller id display so on .
The answer machine does everything you want including remote access .
A small gripe be that it comes with Ni-Cd rechargeable batteries I have preferred Ni-MH as these do have the memory effect of Ni-Cd , however as the batteries are standard size AA rechargables you replace them very easily with Ni-MH when the Ni-Cds give up .
One final cool feature is the voice activated dialing .
Available on some cellular wireless phone for sometime now , the 4215 allows you to pick directory entries simply by speaking the persons name .

I also needed a new answering system .
Our office has gone through a number of answering systems over the years .
After reading reviews here at Epinions we decided to change to the Panasonic KX-TG2000B.
The base unit is well constructed has a very large useful LCD display , which is a nice change of pace from the Lilliputian LC D 's found on most phones .
The base unit has a corded handset offers a jack for headset use .
A very nice addition is a " Headset " button , which is used to answer calls when then headset is in use .
Finally a manufacture understands how a headset is actually used .
The headset be programmed with both speed dial directory listings .
One draw back here is that the handsets do share the base station directories .
You program the handsets individually .
Setup of the base unit is simple is achieved by a few well marked buttons in conjunction with the LCD display .
The answering system " Auto Attendant " functions are a little confusing .
The answering machine function be turned on to answer calls on phone line offers one general voice mail delivery box .
The " Auto Attendant " feature however route calls to individual handsets on answering the phone .
This function offers a separate voice mail box for each handset used .
This is a draw back as you use multiple mailboxes in the answer mode .
We have liked to use several mailboxes to announce address appointment information .
This is however .
We do use the "auto Attendant " feature , but it be useful in a larger office with receptionist to field calls .
The answering system is efficient fast .
The electronic voice is a pleasant female voice which announces mailbox activity .
New messages are easily spotted as the voice mail button is a large clear button which flashes a red icon when a new message is taken .
The voice is fast does slow down the user .
The handsets are well constructed have a solid heavy .
Buttons are well marked the LCD display keypad light up on use .
Sound quality is exceptional with little discernable difference between the handsets a corded phone .
Truly first class sound .
Transferring calls from one phone to the next is a bit of a task .
We have placed small notes on the phones with instructions on how to transfer .
After a few more weeks we will have learned the system then be able to remove the notes .
I that the KX-TG2000B has given us a far more reliable phone answering solution .
There is a serious of high quality phones answering systems on the market .
The Panasonic KX-TG2000B is thankfully one of these poor quality contenders .
It is a first class product with few weaknesses .
For the price it is a steal .
I wish I had bought one long ago !
