Therefore , I decided that I was going to go with another Panasonic , I was going to make sure the unit was powered by a NI-MH ( Nickel Metal Hydride ) battery pack .
Ni-cad batteries were always plagued by what is known as the "memory " effect .
Basically , what this boils down to is the batteries needed to be almost fully drained before recharging .
As you 'll see , it I guessed correctly .
The newer Ni-MH batteries also are n't totally immune to this issue but they are much less to suffer from this memory effect .
The newer batteries are starting to in more more phones recently though .

For starters , it has a high capacity ( 1500 mAh)Ni-MH battery pack .
The feature that sent it over the top was the lighted keypad .
It 's almost unheard of for a phone with these features to be less than $ 50 !
Initial impressions - Ok , I 've been through this before .
I was surprised to find that the white does n't bother me as much as I it .
It has absolutely sloppy gaps anywhere that I find .
The layout of the keypad caller ID is pretty nicely done , although I miss the old navigator key .
There 's still a navigator key but it 's a four-way key like the one on the older units .
Still , navigating through the menus doing everything you need to do to set up the phone is all easy enough to learn once you read the manual ( maybe even you do n't ) .
As it was with the older Panasonic , the Backlit caller ID has excellent contrast is large enough to be read at a comfortable distance .
Oddly , there 's way to turn this feature off in the menu you want to conserve power .
I guess it 's a huge deal anyway , since the battery pack is listed a being good for over five hours of talk time 14 days in standby .
*Voice Enhancer Technology- I have n't got a clue how this works but it does .
As long as you do n't turn the handset volume up to max , it has an overall pleasing effect .
Voices do sound more natural than on Panasonic 's older 2.4 GHz units this technology .
Still , it 's kind of gimmicky you have to wonder why a company like Panasonic need to "enhance " the clarity of the call when last year 's models were to be so great ( According to their own packaging last year ) .
Backlit 3-line LCD - Frankly , I liked the display on the old phone slightly better .
When this phone rings , you have name number caller ID service , it displays only the name first .
This a convenience but it does n't help much when your caller ID service lists all cellular calls as " Cellular call" .
Of course , it eventually alternates shows you the actual number but it takes a few seconds , valuable time when you 're trying to decide to answer a call .
The old phone , I remember correctly , displayed both the name the number in the same frame .
That 's about the only gripe I have with the LCD.
Otherwise , the text is clear legible as I mentioned , contrast is excellent ( also adjustable you do n't like the default setting ) .
This phone also has a 30 number memory for the caller ID the ability to store 50 names numbers ( Far more than I 'll ever need ) .
Ultra charge - It 's nice to see that cordless manufacturers are finally taking notice of people 's desperate pleas to shorten the length of time it takes to recharge the battery packs in their phones .
On top of the incredible 14 day standby time for this battery pack , it will take a full charge in six hours .
This is a vast improvement but I guess these manufacturers us to forget that we 're living in a world where you charge your cell battery pack in three hours keep a spare charged up ready to go .
It 's also the same world in which I fully charge two AA Ni-MH cells for my digital camera in about an hour .
How does this phone sound ?

I hear understand what the person on the other end is saying they hear understand me , I 'm satisfied .
Naturally , I 'm a big fan of static .
So far all of the calls I 've made on this phone have been clear relatively static free .
It makes me wonder when I hear persistent complaints about static "horrible audio quality " with very similar phones in Panasonic 's lineup .
It 's really bad though does n't really affect my overall impression rating of the phone .
The only time when I noticed a really procounced form of this echo was when someone else in my house was on the other line at the same time .
The Speakerphone - Panasonic to be one of the few manufacturers that builds speakerphones into their handsets sells them for a reasonable price .
The sound comes out of the speaker on the rear of the handset loud clear .
Yes , I so .
I have n't encountered any of the problems that I had with the old phone in this unit .
So far , both talk standby times have been great !

PHYSICAL FEATURES
The base station is reasonably small has a telephone jack wall-wort AC adaptor for power .
It is approximately 2 handsets in size it allows you to place one handset (either one ) face down face up ( latter allows you to see caller ID picking it up first ) .
There are 3 intercom buttons which allow you to locate intercom to any of the handset units .
A single antenna is used to transmit/receive with the handsets .
A rigid 3 inch antenna sticks out at the top for the most part does n't manage to get in the way .
The buttons are reasonably laid out , but they are a little small for aging eyes ( over 60 ) to see .
The OFF CALL buttons , the most commonly pressed buttons ( END SEND on your cell phone ) are curiously smaller than the number pad , which makes it a short hunt for people unfamiliar with the unit to find ... ie guests .
The screen is green back lit LCD display which is easy to read .
I was a little concerned that the basestation only has 1 antenna , compared to our older Panasonic 2.4GHz unit which has 2 antenna for diversity ( more immune to "pockets " of bad reception ) .
However , in practice I have found that these units have extremely good reception have yet to experience the pockets of bad reception anywhere in the house garage .
The range easily covers our entire home property .
I also mention that in addition to our other 2.4GHz phone , we also have a 802.11b wireless network in our house ( which also uses the 2.4GHz spectrum ) .
We have experienced any interference on the phone by the other devices , we have n't noticed interference with our network .
CALLER ID OPERATION
The phones are easy to use bring a more "cell phone like " functionality to the home phone .
As calls come in , the phone performs caller ID.
It takes till the 2nd ring to figure out the number , but I this is typical .
you have previously saved the number labelled it , then that text label will also show up with the number .
All the standard functions like redial , flash , constant button tones are all there .
As mentioned above , there is a phone number directory which allows you to enter save caller ID numbers with labels ( ie " Grandma" ) to a phone directory .
Manipulating the menu be a little confusing counter intuitive ; this part stand for improvement .
However , the most annoying thing is that each hand set maintains it 's own directory , which means you have to enter each entry twice ; once for each phone , for both phones to have it .
There is directory synchronization feature .
Panasonic really consider adding this functionality .
It 's convenient to spontaneously add the caller ID received phone call to both directories .
An extra speaker on the back of the phone serves as the loud speaker .
Battery is a rechargeable NiCd which easily last several days .

Sorry the above review sounds a little ... guarded .
I 've purchased several of these devices with a lot of disappointment .
But this one is really great !
The base unit is corded the handset sounds like a corded phone .
There are mailboxes ( 3 ) a lots of utility regarding privacy , conference , transferring , caller id , call waiting , paging , even radio contact between several handsets .
For those with really young kids , there is a "baby monitor " mode !
In short , this is a nicely designed phone system with a lot of expansion , sounds great is priced well .
After researching , this system jumped out .
The handset inevitably ran out of power at the wrong times I was a phone .
Panasonic smartly provides a base unit remote , each with a dialing pad .
It is an attractive , high quality device I recommend highly .
There are too many features to list including speakerphone ( also from remote)conferencing , ring tones , etc .
Their products are well designed well built .
First problem : Sound quality .
Memory chips are inexpensive , but Panasonic saved money by putting a small memory chip in this system .
Compression technology is utilized to fit 15 minutes of recorded messages onto the chip , you tell -- sound quality is AWFUL.
( So much for technological advance . )
Second problem : The power pack consists of three cheap NiCd AA batteries encased in plastic .
Even worse , they 're very low capacity NiCds -- just 850 mAh .
( NiCd is the old technology for rechargeable batteries .
Cadmium is a nasty environmental toxin .
NiCd batteries drain quickly , even when in use , they have a "memory effect " : you do n't drain the power completely before a recharge , they 'll only charge up to the current level on the next charge . )
The phone handset only works a few hours before recharging is needed , storing it on the charger base will significantly reduce the life of the batteries .
Panasonic had opted for the current technology of 2200-mAh NmH ( nickel metal hydride ) batteries , the 4-hr usage time have been boosted to 10 hrs more , with memory effect .
Third problem : You have to endure a goofy voice that tells you things that be more efficiently conveyed through visual indicators .
I an electronic voice is Panasonic 's way of adding a " Gee-wow " factor , but it 's another example of how new technology makes our lives less efficient .
Older answering machines have an LCD display that tells you how many new messages you have .
This machine has just a tiny red light , so you call-screen a message do n't erase it , you have other messages have been added (unless you start pushing buttons ) .
You have to waste time pressing buttons listening to the voice every time .
Also , you have to press extra buttons like Mailbox 1 every time , even though you use other message "mailboxes " (used for password-protected messages that be storage for other users of the system ) .
More gripes : The antennas on the base unit are five inches high .
They get in the way .
Also , you ca n't hear your own voice in the handset , as you with other phones .
It takes a while to get used to that .
On the plus side , the range of a 5.8 GHz phone is fairly good ( although quality does degrade with distance ) .
I still worry about zapping my brain with high-energy radio signals , but going cordless is nice .
Wish list : In addition to fixing the above-mentioned gripes , it be great there were a way to speed through boring messages .
I 've had the 2431 for 3 years .
I have gotten 3 hours use from it .
It works fine for the first 5 10 minutes that 's when the volume fades .
Then it returns then it fades again does n't stop .
Calling was the fastest way to get the run-around that I 've ever seen .
I packaged mailed it back after many weeks was sent a brand new replacement .
Same problem .
I eliminated all environmental possibilities such as disconnecting other phones , computer , VCR , etc .
The problem still existed .
I 've learned a $ 130 lesson
